webTitle: 'This eruption would have occurred even without Sharon's act'

fields.headline: 'This eruption would have occurred even without Sharon's act'
fields.trailText: Press review: Derek Brown on what the Middle East papers have to say about the crisis
fields.body:
There is little meeting of minds on the causes of the surge of violence this week - though there is some agreement on its potentially dire effects.

In the Jerusalem Post, columnist Tallie Lipkin-Shahak writes despairingly of the continuing hatred between Jews and Arabs. It was that hatred, she said, which fuelled the violence, and not the provocative visit of rightwing leader Ariel Sharon to a Jerusalem mosque: "So Sharon and his crew only provided the wind that fanned the flames - leading us to this dark time. Evidently, this eruption would have occurred even without Sharon's act. Evidently, the Palestinians would, anyway, have found the crack of hatred in the false wall of dialogue, and broken through, expressing their frustration with a seemingly endless process. Evidently, the Israeli Arabs would have, in any event, reached the boiling point and discharged the rage that had been simmering for so long".

The liberal Israeli daily, Ha'aretz, appeals to Israel's ten Arab members of parliament, who have strongly criticised the government and the army, to show moderation. The paper warns that if they bring down Barak's fragile minority coalition and allow the Israeli right to regain power, it will have drastic implications for the peace process. The leading article concludes: "Moderation of the extremist postures of the Arab MKs and the restoration of calm within the pre-1967 borders could have the effect of placing the derailed relations between Israel and the Palestinians back on a renewed track of optimism, perhaps even bringing about the signing of an agreement soon. The Arab MKs have a role to play that is greater than their relative weight in the Knesset."

Ha'aretz columnist Dan Margalit perpetuates the myth that Yasser Arafat and other Palestinian leaders personally direct the riots. " It is easy to secure the sympathy of the world with the photograph of a dead child; however, the responsibility lies squarely on the shoulders of the Palestinian leaders, who so cynically dispatch children to the frontline," he writes.

Even more provocatively, Margalit ponders the implications of the largescale rioting by Arab citizens of Israel, who, as he points out, identify with the Palestinian cause. He concludes: "This total identification and the absence of any voices in the Israeli Arab community publicly calling for an end to the violence gives rise to the suspicion that the members of this community constitute a fifth column."

Fellow columnist Danny Rabinowitz writes much more sympathetically of the frustrations felt by Israel's 1m Arabs, to whom the Jewish state is little more than a "supplier of administrative accessories such as a passport, social services, health services and schooling". Rabinowitz suggests that the alternative to Jewish-Arab coexistence is "the hopeless attempt to perpetuate foreign rule over unwilling subjects".

The Jordan Times, normally a restrained voice of Arab moderation, carries graphic accounts of the latest violence, laced with heavy anti-Israeli comment. Its leader writer strongly supports Arafat's calls for an international inquiry, and is outraged by Israel's attempts to pin all the blame for the bloodshed on the Palestinian leadership. "Was it the Palestinian president who visited Al Aqsa Mosque on Thursday, escorted by 3,000 security men, and enraging a whole nation?" he asks. "Was it the Palestinian president who ordered Palestinian babies and children shot and commanded helicopters and tanks to fire? Was it the Palestinian president who turned the Israeli police against Arab Israeli citizens?"

The Khaleej Times, in the United Arab Emirates, reports an ominous call by Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei for all Islamic countries to allow their citizens to take part in a jihad - holy war - for the defence of Jerusalem. "The Islamic countries must open up the way for a jihad, and allow Muslims to perform this duty, the only way to victory. That is what the Muslims want," his message said.

Further afield, The News of Pakistan carries approving coverage of the Palestinian youths "embracing martyrdom" in their doomed fight against the Israeli army. It also solemnly reports Saddam Hussain's boast that if only he had a land border with Israel, he would destroy the Jewish state.

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.trailText: October 5: Sunday People is using Article 10 of the new Human Rights Act to try to overturn a gagging order on its coverage of the alleged killing of an IRA sympathiser by a British army unit.
fields.body:
Press Gazette splashes on two cases brought by national newspapers under the new Human Rights Act, which became law on Monday. It reports that the Sunday People is using Article 10 of the new law to try to overturn a gagging order on its coverage of the alleged killing of an IRA sympathiser by a British army unit.

In a separate case, the Times is attempting to overturn a court ruling in which it was ordered to pay £75,000 in damages to Lance Corporal Lee Clegg, a paratrooper jailed for life for shooting a joyrider in Northern Ireland. The paper is trying to establish qualified privilege for journalists reporting material from press conferences.

Press Gazette also reports that the Sun's sacked UK Confidential columnist Marina Hyde is understood to have been offered a job on the News of the World by editor Rebekah Wade.

The BBC's head of news, Tony Hall, defends his decision to move Panorama to Sunday night, saying it was necessary to keep it on BBC1.

And Allan Rennie, acting editor of the Scottish Sunday Mail since the departure of Peter Cox for the Daily Record last month, has been confirmed as his successor. <BR

fields.headline: The Mobo awards
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the Music of Black Origin awards
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the Music of Black Origin awards.
fields.body:
1. The boy done good. In fact, he done best. Singer Craig David made history last night by becoming the first triple winner of coveted Mobo gongs.

2. David, whose debut single Fill Me In entered the charts at number one earlier this year, collected the Music of Black Origin awards at Alexandra Palace in north London. (Ally Pally, was an appropriate venue for last night's entertainment razzmatazz - it is the birthplace of television.) He picked up best single, best newcomer and best R&B act prizes.

3. Not bad, you might think, for a teenager from Southampton - although it looks like the city's grown-ups have yet to wake up to the existence of their newly famous son, if the council's website is anything to go by. David shares a home there with his mother. But he's kept shtoom about whether he also shares her reported love of 1970s boy band the Osmonds.

4. David does, however, admire US rapper Puff Daddy, listing his website as one of his favourites. And shockingly, he also quite openly rates the site of adolescent males' squeaky-clean pinup Britney Spears.

5. But last night wasn't entirely the triumph of the teens. Woodstock veteran Carlos Santana, whose career spans three decades and who has sold more than 50m records, was named best world music act. Other old timers got a look in, with reggae band Aswad receiving the outstanding contribution to music accolade.

6. Years of topping the dancehall charts in Jamaica won Kingston's ragga star, Beenie Man, best reggae act.

7. Back from serenading former South African president Nelson Mandela at the Labour party conference, south London's finest, Gabrielle, walked off with the best UK album award.

8. Classically trained oboist turned garage guru MJ Cole was named best producer. Jamelia won the prize for best video; best jazz was guitarist Ronny Jordan featuring Mos Def; and best gospel act Mary Mary. Fortune smiled on DJ Luck and MC Neat featuring JJ, who were voted best UK garage act.

9. BBC Radio 1 DJ Tim Westwood recovered from last year's gun attack to win best radio UK DJ. (If you want a peak at the man in action, try a studio web cam.) Best UK club DJ award went to Steve Sutherland.

10. The controversial rapper Eminem was named best hip hop act. His outspoken lyrics have upset a number of people, including gays and women. Oh, and his mum, Debbie Mathers-Briggs. She's said to be less than happy with some of her son's pronouncements. Unlike Craig David, Eminem's unlikely to receive a big family welcome after his success at the Mobo awards.

webTitle: Five batsmen absent hurt in a Test

fields.headline: Five batsmen absent hurt in a Test
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Please you tell me more about the fourth Test between West Indies and India at Kingston in April 1976? It looks like a bloodbath! Five Indian batsmen were absent hurt in the second innings. What happened? asks Dean Ilott from Mexico City
fields.body:
Please you tell me more about the fourth Test between West Indies and India at Kingston in April 1976? It looks like a bloodbath! Five Indian batsmen were absent hurt in the second innings. What happened? asks Dean Ilott from Mexico City

The match was played on a recently relaid pitch, which offered unpredictable bounce to the West Indian fast bowlers. Michael Holding and Wayne Daniel were in the super-fast category, while Bernard Julien and Van Holder weren't far behind. India went into the match in good form - they had made 406 runs (for only four wickets) in the final innings to win the previous Test, at Port-of-Spain - still an all-time Test record. But at Kingston two people retired hurt in their first innings of 306. Aunshuman Gaekwad was hit on the left ear and spent two nights in hospital, while Brijesh Patel had to have stitches after being hit in the mouth (remember that these were pre-helmet days). Neither of them played any further part in the match - and neither did Gundappa Viswanath, who was caught off a ball which broke a finger of his right hand. Bishan Bedi, India's captain, declared before he and Bhagwat Chandrasekhar - two of Test cricket's worst batsmen - had to face the music. India's gentle pace attack couldn't take advantage of the pitch, and West Indies made 391. Then India went in again, without the three injured batsmen. They reached 97 for 5 - 12 ahead - but that was it. Bedi said both he and Chandrasekhar had suffered hand injuries while fielding, and were also unable to bat. All 17 members of India's touring party fielded at some stage during the match - and one of the substitutes, Surinder Amarnath, was carted off to hospital during the game for an appendix operation. West Indies won the match by ten wickets, and won the series 2-1. It was the start of their surge to the top of world cricket. Their previous series had ended in a 5-1 humiliation in Australia, but after this West Indies ruled the roost until the end of the 1980s.

What are the ten ways you can be out in cricket? asks Tim Varley

Six of them happen regularly (far too regularly if you're me) bowled, caught, hit wicket, leg before wicket (lbw), run out and stumped. Three more are rare enough to get a little section all of their own in the Wisden Almanack - handled the ball, hit the ball twice and obstructing the field. And the tenth method hardly ever happens - Timed Out. That's when the incoming batsman wilfully takes more than two minutes to come to the crease. The only man to have been given out this way in first-class cricket Is Hemulal Yadav of Tripura, during a Ranji Trophy match against Orissa at Cuttack in India in 1997-98. Wisden 1999 says: "A drinks interval had been called at the fall of Tripura's ninth wicket, during which Yadav sat near the boundary, but the umpires said he made no attempt to come to the crease after the break, and upheld Orissa's appeal."

Who was the first Pakistan batsman to reach 5000 runs in Test cricket? asks Paul Bennett

It was Zaheer Abbas, the stylish right-hander with the extravagant backlift. He passed 5000 during the first Test against New Zealand at Lahore in November 1984, and finished his Test career shortly afterwards with 5062 runs. Two others have passed 5000 since: Javed Miandad (8832 runs) and Salim Malik (5768). The next one to get there will probably be Inzamam-ul-Haq, who currently has 4504 runs in Tests.

I was surprised to discover, from the Australian Wisden, that the highest Test batting average for an Australian is not held by Don Bradman but one AE Trott, who played three Tests in the 1890s and had a batting average of 102. He is also listed as having the best bowling debut, with 8 for 43 against England. He later played for England, and died young in 1914. Can you tell me more about him? asks Matthew Brown

Albert Trott, an attacking right-hand batsman and a medium-pace bowler, did indeed have a remarkable career. Born in Melbourne in 1873, he was called up for the third Test against England at Adelaide in 1894-95, and took 8 for 43, which remains the best bowling analysis on debut by any Test player. His scores of 38*, 72*, 85*, 10 and 0 gave him an average of 102.50. For reasons which remain unclear he was left out of the Australian team which toured England in 1896. It may have been that the captain didn't want to be accused of favouritism - it was Trott's older brother Harry. Albert Trott came to England anyway, and started playing for Middlesex in 1898. He played two Tests for England in South Africa in 1898-99, without much success, but played on at county level until 1910. In 1899, while playing for MCC against the Australians, he became the first - and still the only - batsman to hit a six over the pavilion at Lord's. After his career finished he suffered health problems, and in 1914, still only 41, he shot himself dead.

Please could you tell me the result of the last first-class match in Sheffield, which I think was in 1973? asks Peter Kerry

I think you mean the last match at the Bramall Lane ground in Sheffield (Yorkshire played matches at Abbeydale Park, Sheffield, for a few years after 1973). The last match at Bramall Lane, before it was given over entirely to Sheffield United and football, was in August 1973. Appropriately, it was the Roses match, but inappropriately the match was ruined by rain and left drawn. Yorkshire were bowled out for 99 (seamer Peter Lee 6 for 43), Lancashire made 111 (John Sullivan 48*), then Yorkshire reached 114 for 2 (Phil Sharpe 62*). Geoff Boycott made only 9 and 6.

I'm an Englishman exiled in New York, and I work with a couple of Aussies. We miss cricket more than you can imagine, and have resolved to make a pilgrimage to Lord's next summer for the Test against Australia. What are the dates? asks Neal Davies

Next year's Lord's Test against Australia will start on Thursday, July 19 (there's also one against Pakistan starting on May 17). Ticket details will eventually appear on the Lord's website, but they're not there just yet.

fields.bodyText: Please you tell me more about the fourth Test between West Indies and India at Kingston in April 1976? It looks like a bloodbath! Five Indian batsmen were absent hurt in the second innings. What happened? asks Dean Ilott from Mexico City The match was played on a recently relaid pitch, which offered unpredictable bounce to the West Indian fast bowlers. Michael Holding and Wayne Daniel were in the super-fast category, while Bernard Julien and Van Holder weren't far behind. India went into the match in good form - they had made 406 runs (for only four wickets) in the final innings to win the previous Test, at Port-of-Spain - still an all-time Test record. But at Kingston two people retired hurt in their first innings of 306. Aunshuman Gaekwad was hit on the left ear and spent two nights in hospital, while Brijesh Patel had to have stitches after being hit in the mouth (remember that these were pre-helmet days). Neither of them played any further part in the match - and neither did Gundappa Viswanath, who was caught off a ball which broke a finger of his right hand. Bishan Bedi, India's captain, declared before he and Bhagwat Chandrasekhar - two of Test cricket's worst batsmen - had to face the music. India's gentle pace attack couldn't take advantage of the pitch, and West Indies made 391. Then India went in again, without the three injured batsmen. They reached 97 for 5 - 12 ahead - but that was it. Bedi said both he and Chandrasekhar had suffered hand injuries while fielding, and were also unable to bat. All 17 members of India's touring party fielded at some stage during the match - and one of the substitutes, Surinder Amarnath, was carted off to hospital during the game for an appendix operation. West Indies won the match by ten wickets, and won the series 2-1. It was the start of their surge to the top of world cricket. Their previous series had ended in a 5-1 humiliation in Australia, but after this West Indies ruled the roost until the end of the 1980s. And the tenth method hardly ever happens - Timed Out. That's when the incoming batsman wilfully takes more than two minutes to come to the crease. Wisden 1999 says: "A drinks interval had been called at the fall of Tripura's ninth wicket, during which Yadav sat near the boundary, but the umpires said he made no attempt to come to the crease after the break, and upheld Orissa's appeal." webTitle: EMI and Warner Music merger still on

fields.headline: EMI and Warner Music to persevere with merger
fields.standfirst: Merger called off
fields.trailText: 10.30am: EMI and Warner Music will continue to push ahead with their £14bn merger, despite this morning's decision to abandon the deal in the face of EU regulatory opposition, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
EMI and Warner Music will continue to push ahead with their £14bn merger, despite this morning's decision to abandon the deal in the face of EU regulatory opposition.

The record companies said they will continue discussions with each other, the European competition commission and other regulators in an attempt to regroup and get the deal through.

The temporary termination of the deal follows reports that EMI and Warner had offered to sell their respective Virgin Records and Warner Chappell publishing operations in order to secure regulatory approval.

Analysts said the Virgin and Warner Chappell operations were core assets of the companies and were too valuable to sell, a sentiment which EMI chairman Eric Nicoli seemed to confirm in a statement.

He said: "The withdrawal of our application allows additional time to reassess regulators' concerns and to pursue solutions simultaneously in Europe and the U.S.

"We have been, and will continue to be, flexible in responding to the European Commission's concerns. However any concessions that are ultimately made must be consistent with our shareholder value objectives."

EMI will now be vulnerable to potential predators, which include Bertelsmann of Germany, the Sony Corporation and Spanish telecoms operator Telefonica. EMI's shares fell 22.5p to 551p in early trading.

"EMI is vulnerable because it is no longer part of a deal. As for possible buyers, it's a case of the usual suspects such as Bertelsmann and Sony," said Derek Terrington, analyst at Credit Lyonnais Securities.

webTitle: Comment: War of words in the Middle East

fields.headline: War of words in the Middle East
fields.standfirst:
Covering the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is a challenge for writers as words can cause political offence, and attempts to be fair can lead to inaccuracies, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
Photo gallery: The death of Mohammed al-Durrah
fields.trailText: Covering the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is a challenge for writers as words can cause political offence, and attempts to be fair can lead to inaccuracies, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Whatever happens to the Middle East peace process, the killing of 12-year-old Mohammed al-Durrah in Gaza is going to remain with us for many years.

There have been dozens of equally tragic deaths over the last week but Mohammed's end, as he sheltered helplessly with his father behind a water barrel, happened to be recorded by a TV cameraman.

Personally, I cannot recall a more powerful piece of news footage since the unarmed man in a white shirt halted a column of tanks in Tiananmen Square, back in 1989.

My first thought was that the killing of Mohammed should be required viewing for every American voter, so that they can see what their $3 billion-a-year aid to Israel pays for. But a few days later, I'm not so sure.

Inevitably, video clips have appeared on the internet and now all you need do is click your mouse to have Mohammed brought back to life and shot again and again and again. Apart from being unbelievably ghoulish, this removes the event from brutal realities of Middle East politics and dumps it in the realm of fantasy video games.

For those of us who try to portray the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in words rather than pictures, the last week has been especially difficult.

When so much is happening we can't always be in the right place at the right time; we often have to use material from other sources, such as news agencies, doing our best to evaluate it in the light of our own experience, but always working against a deadline.

It is now clear that Mohammed was shot by the Israelis, probably deliberately (and anyone who still doubts that should read the detailed article, Making of a martyr, by my colleague, Suzanne Goldenberg. But on Saturday, as the British Sunday papers went to press, the facts were still unclear.

The first report of Mohammed's killing came from the American agency, Associated Press, just before 6pm last Saturday. Unedited, the relevant part said: "Among those killed was a 12-year-old boy who was caught in the crossfire. The boy, Rami Aldura, and his father, were crouched behind a metal barrel, trying to seek cover and pleading for a ceasefire. The father held his hand protectively over the boy, who was screaming with fear, only to see his son fatally shot in the stomach."

A few minutes later, Reuters circulated a report which said: "In Netzarim, 12-year-old Rami Aldura and his father Jamal were caught in the crossfire."

Both reports got the boy's name partly wrong and both mentioned "crossfire". As the picture of what really happened became clearer, "caught in the crossfire" began to look like an Israeli-inspired phrase to deflect blame, but I suspect that is not how it actually arose.

The Israeli army's first explanation was that Mohammed was a stone-thrower who had been pulled back by his father which in their eyes presumably made it perfectly all right to shoot him dead.

More usually, "crossfire" is inserted into stories by journalists who are not sure who was at fault. The trouble is that it implies that nobody in particular was at fault. It would be much better to say something like: "It was not immediately clear who fired the fatal shots" but professional pride sometimes stops journalists admitting their ignorance.

It would be wrong, however, to imagine that journalists don't think about these things before rushing into print. A colleague working on a Sunday newspaper tells me there was a discussion in the office about where the shots that killed Mohammed might have come from.

Although the first impression was that he had been shot from in front, the holes in the wall behind him indicated to some people in the office that he might have been hit by bullets passing through the wall from behind.

One problem that writers have to grapple with in this kind of conflict is the way both sides attempt to impose their own terminology on the debate and journalists who make the mistake of using it risk being caught up, as it were, in the verbal crossfire.

The Israelis, for example, regularly call the occupied West Bank "Judea and Samaria" (to emphasise their claim to it), and sometimes this creeps into newspaper stories, particularly where direct quotes from Israeli officials are used.

There is also the contentious issue of what to call the Arab-Israeli (or Israeli-Arab) wars. Israelis like to call the 1967 war the "Six-Day War" (to show how quickly they won it), and the 1973 war the "Yom-Kippur War" (a reminder that the Arabs started it on the holiest day in the Jewish calendar). My own preference is to refer to them simply as the wars of 1967 and 1973, though "Six-Day War" seems to have entered general usage outside the Arab world.

For many years, Arabs avoided mentioning Israel by name, using such phrases as "the Zionist entity" instead. Today, most accept its existence behind the pre-1967 borders, so it is usually uncontroversial to refer to "Israel" in a newspaper article, provided that does not include the West Bank, Gaza, Jerusalem and the Golan Heights - the disputed parts occupied in 1967.

A minority still reject that, and I once got a severe ticking-off from Palestinian refugees in Lebanon for referring to "Israel" at all.

Many Palestinians, implying that their state already exists, like to call Yasser Arafat "President Arafat". His official title in Arabic is "ra'is", which translates into English equally well as "president" or "chairman". Conveniently, this allows us to address him in English correctly, without necessarily accepting that he is the head of a state. Usually, though, newspapers refer to him as "the Palestinian leader".

During the current troubles, I have had to mention several times the controversial visit by Ariel Sharon to the place known to Israelis as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as al-Haram al-Sharif. Inevitably this ends up sounding very long-winded and so a couple of times I have said that he went to the Dome of the Rock a name which is politically uncontentious, though not quite as accurate geographically because it refers only to the most prominent building on the site.

Just when I was beginning to feel that the Guardian had kept its nose reasonably clean on this point, an email arrived from Dr Mike Diboll in Rotherhithe, London, saying: "The familiar-sounding English proper noun "Temple Mount" reinforces the idea that the Israelis are Western and us*, whereas the unheimlisch Arabic name "Al Haram ash-Sharif" seems unremittingly Oriental and "other" to Anglophone ears unfamiliar with Semitic linguistics.

"A fairer use of language would either use both the Arabic and the Hebrew proper nouns - "the Muslim holy site of Al Haram ash-Sharif, also revered by Jews as Har-ha-Bayt", or would use English approximations for both: "the Muslim holy site of the Noble Sanctuary, also revered by Jews as the Temple Mount"."

Last Monday, while writing about Sharon*s antics, I was running short of time and asked one of our researchers to compile some biographical details on him. Among other things, the researcher dug out the information that in 1953 he had founded the notorious "Unit 101" commando group which had killed 69 civilians, mostly women and children, "by accident" at Qibya in Jordan.

Unfortunately, I was not familiar enough with the Qibya tragedy, and the researcher had relied on a 1990 cutting from the New York Times which happened to be wrong. Next day, a reader wrote in to point out that Qibya was no accident. Again, I suspect the 1990 mistake originated from a journalist trying to play safe and not apportion blame or possibly a nervous lawyer worrying that Sharon might sue the New York Times.

On another occasion this week, a sub-editor, who was puzzling over an article from an Israeli freelance writer, came to me and asked, "What is the PA?" I explained that the initials should really be PNA - the Palestinian National Authority - though Israelis like to omit the word "national", for obvious reasons. An official at the PLO office in London confirmed that this is the correct title.

Later, I mentioned this to an English friend who is a long-standing supporter of the Palestinian cause. He replied that he also drops the word "National" when talking about the authority on the grounds that it does not represent the whole Palestinian nation. Sometimes, you just can't win.

webTitle: US acts to stave off further Mideast violence

fields.headline: US acts to stave off further Mideast violence
fields.standfirst: Israeli tanks withdraw as new ceasefire takes effect after Paris talks between Arafat and Barak
fields.trailText: The United States has helped set up a security committee to try to stave off further violence in the West Bank and Gaza after a week of clashes in which 67 people, mostly Palestinians, have died.
fields.body:
The United States has helped set up a security committee to try to stave off further violence in the West Bank and Gaza after a week of clashes in which 67 people, mostly Palestinians, have died.

The announcement came as Israeli and Palestinian security officials agreed a fourth ceasefire this morning, after talks between Israel's prime minister Ehud Barak and the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat in Paris yesterday.

"President Clinton has already announced that the parties have agreed that the United States will chair a trilateral security committee to facilitate the process of security cooperation," US secretary of state Madeleine Albright said at a press conference in Cairo.

In a sign of positive results from the Paris talks, the Israeli army today withdrew tanks from flashpoints in the West Bank in a respite from the worst violence between Israelis and Palestinians in years.

Although Mr Arafat and Mr Barak failed to clinch a formal agreement, a ceasefire on the ground appeared to be holding in the quietest day since fighting erupted a week ago.

The two men agreed to order their military commanders to separate their forces in three key flashpoint areas, according to US officials. The orders were issued simultaneously by Mr Barak and Mr Arafat during six hours of discussions in Paris arranged by Mrs Albright.

The three areas are the Netzarim junction in northern Gaza, Joseph's Tomb in Nablus on the West Bank and the Circle area of Ramallah, also on the West Bank. An Israeli military official said the army was taking steps to avoid confrontations.

"The guiding principle is to see but not be seen," said Colonel Yossi Adiri, commander of Israeli forces near the Palestinian-ruled West Bank city of Nablus, after meeting his Palestinian counterpart. "We understand that a visible force causes agitation, which we do not want. At the same time, these forces will be prepared for any development in the field."

There have been no major clashes today, but street battles have usually erupted later in the day and three previous ceasefires have collapsed.

Efforts to capitalise on this quiet period continued in Cairo, where Mrs Albright held talks with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, and Mr Arafat. Mr Barak was supposed to have taken part but returned to Israel instead, saying there was no point in continuing the discussions. Mrs Albright said that "remarkable progress" had been made in Paris and that both sides would follow through on security arrangements agreed there.

The most contentious issue during the Paris talks was that of an inquiry into the causes of the fighting. Mr Arafat wanted an international inquiry with UN involvement, while Mr Barak preferred a joint Palestinian-Israeli investigation. At one point Mr Arafat stormed out - only to be stopped when Mrs Albright called guards to shut the residence's gates to block him.

But the talks were described as productive, with US officials crediting both leaders with a sincere effort to restore the trust essential for peacemaking to proceed.

US officials briefing reporters on Mrs Albright's plane said, for instance, that Mr Barak had agreed that Israeli forces would fire live ammunition only when their lives were threatened.

The fighting was triggered by last Thursday's visit by rightwing Israeli politician Ariel Sharon to Jerusalem's Al Aqsa mosque compound - a site claimed as holy by both Jews and Muslims.

fields.headline: Clashes outside Yugoslav parliament
fields.standfirst: Radio B292
fields.trailText:
Serbian police have clashed briefly with protesters who tried to enter the Yugoslav parliament building a few
hours before a huge anti-government rally in Belgrade, according to the latest reports.
fields.body:
Serbian police have clashed briefly with protesters who tried to enter the Yugoslav parliament building a few hours before a huge anti-government rally in Belgrade, according to the latest reports.

The situation has calmed down, with several protesters hugging police in a bid to win them over. But the incident seemed to signal a build-up in public pressure ahead of a demonstration due to start at 2pm BST aimed at forcing Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to accept defeat in the presidential election.

Eyewitnesses said police, who have shown unusual restraint during this week's campaign of civil disobedience, seemed to have reacted only when some protesters had pushed through one line of police and appeared to be trying to enter the building.

Shortly after the incident, the crowd outside the building swelled to more than 10,000. At one point some of them hurled stones at police before tension eased. About 150 riot police lined up around the building.

One opposition leader, Velja Ilic, urged people not to provoke incidents. "I beg you not to hurl stones at the police. There was an incident because someone stoned a policeman just now. They are ours, they have to be with their people, so please do not provoke any incident," Ilic told the crowd.

Meanwhile, the Yugoslav constitutional court says the presidential poll must be repeated.

The ruling confirms an initial judgment by the court late yesterday, which invalidated part of the 24 September elections, a ballot Milosevic opponents say was won outright by his rival Vojislav Kostunica.

It was not immediately clear if this means a complete repeat of the elections would be required. A run-off election was scheduled for Sunday, but opposition forces said they would boycott the vote.

Tens of thousands of protesters seeking to oust President Slobodan Milosevic streamed toward the capital today to join a mass rally billed as the final push against the embattled strongman.

Police offered little resistance to the largest convoys but appeared to stand firm to some of the smaller groups. A convoy of about 2,000 people was blocked near the town of Smederevska Palanka about 30 miles south of Belgrade.

Independent radio B2-92 said police were blocking a main highway just outside Nis, the third-largest city, from which dozens of buses and cars were trying to reach the capital. Some of the crowds appeared too big to stop.

Protesters used a front-end loader to shove aside two sand trucks used by authorities to try to block a 12-mile line of cars and buses with about 15,000 people travelling from the opposition stronghold of Cacak. Riot police stood by without intervening.

At another roadblock, trucks were pushed away and demonstrators negotiated with a police commander to be allowed through. At yet another blockade, angry protesters overturned a police car and dumped it into a ditch.

Opposition leaders issued an "ultimatum; for Milosevic to resign by 2pm BST today - the time set for the Belgrade rally. "This flame will engulf the whole of Belgrade," said Vladan Batic, an opposition leader.

Although authorities appear unwilling to strike back at the crowds, Milosevic turned to other options to try to cling to power.

The constitutional court ruling - by judges loyal to the president - could be aimed at allowing Milosevic to stay in power longer. His term would have expired next June if he hadn't called early elections and now he might be trying to get back to the previous status as if the elections didn't take place.

Milosevic's government conceded that Kostunica gained more votes than Milosevic, but that he failed to win the majority legally required for outright victory.

The court ruling came just hours after police were forced to abandoned plans to take over a striking coal mine after confronting fearless anti-Milosevic crowds - a stunning development unprecedented in a former communist nation with no history of major worker uprisings.

"He saw that he cannot push through the second round against the majority of the people," opposition campaign manager Zoran Djindjic said of Milosevic. "His solution is ... to create a new situation for totally new elections; allowing him to cling to power for further months.

The tribunal met in emergency session to hear claims by the 18-party opposition coalition that Milosevic's cronies manipulated election results by using a sophisticated software program.

Even before the court ruling, however, Milosevic, showed no signs he was contemplating defeat. His prime minister, Momir Bulatovic, repeated the position that Milosevic can remain in office until June 2001 regardless of the election outcome, which is when Milosevic's present term runs out.

webTitle: Kingston's affair with Hull turns sour

fields.headline: Kingston's affair with Hull turns sour
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Kingston Communications' love affair with the residents of Hull is coming under strain just seven months after the former municipal phone company's elevation to the FTSE 100 sparked celebrations among locals and triggered the biggest financial windfall ever landed by a British city.
fields.body:
Kingston Communications' love affair with the residents of Hull is coming under strain just seven months after the former municipal phone company's elevation to the FTSE 100 sparked celebrations among locals and triggered the biggest financial windfall ever landed by a British city.

A seven-fold rise in Kingston's share price that propelled it into the benchmark index in March made Hull city council the richest local authority in the country thanks to its £2.5bn stake. The company's success had the one in three residents in the city who owned shares logging on to financial bulletin boards to check the value of their soaring portfolios.

However, recent changes to the company's untimed internet access charges, combined with a fall in Kingston's share price that has seen it evicted from the FTSE 100 has soured relations with some customers to such an extent that they have nicknamed the firm "Kingston-cons".

The criticisms stem from problems users experienced in connecting to the internet - which some claim made the service "virtually unusable at times" - and a subsequent rise in the price of untimed access charges from £15 to £25 per month.

A web-based petition at kingston-comms.co.uk has been set up to allow customers to vent their anger. One posting reads: "Kingston sort it out! I've seen better connections on my four-year-old's lego."

A Kingston spokesman said yesterday that many of the sharper criticisms were unfair and that the company had taken steps to improve its technology and customer service. He added that the company felt its two subscription internet access offerings represented good value.

Kingston pioneered unmetered internet access in March 1999 but, in common with many other service providers, found it was a loss-making activity and heavy usage created technical problems.

"We accept that a minority of customers have found the move to a higher charge of untimed access unacceptable, but the vast majority of our 10,000 customers have moved happily to the off-peak tariff," the spokesman said.

Customers are now offered two tarriffs: all-day untimed access for £25 per month and an off-peak evenings and weekend tariff for £9.99.

Kingston shares closed down 19p at 373p.

webTitle: TV watchdog rupholds complaint against BBC

fields.headline: TV watchdog rules against BBC over ITN libel case coverage
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Broadcasting Standards Commission has upheld a complaint from ITN against the BBC's six o'clock news about its coverage of the libel proceedings earlier this year at which ITN won damages from LM magazine. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Broadcasting Standards Commission has upheld a complaint from ITN against the BBC's six o'clock news bulletin about its coverage of the libel proceedings earlier this year at which ITN won damages from LM magazine.

ITN claimed that the BBC's media correspondent, Nick Higham, summed up the case in a way that was "misleading and unfair to ITN and its reporters", giving the impression that the case had been won on a technicality.

Earlier this year ITN won the long-running court case following the publication of an article in LM magazine. The author of the piece, Thomas Deichmann, had claimed that reporters Penny Marshall and Ian Williams, in their reports for Channel 4 News, had presented a distorted view of refugees at a camp at Tronopolje in Serb-occupied Bosnia.

The article claimed that the reporters had made it appear that the refugees were incarcerated behind barbed wire, when they were actually free to come and go as they pleased.

ITN won damages of £375,000 for itself and the reporters, along with an apology from LM magazine, which was forced to close in order to pay the damages and the legal bill for the case, estimated at £500,000.

In its response to the complaint, the BBC said it had "utmost respect" for ITN and its reporters, and that Mr Higham's report had been edited down. It added that viewers of the programme would have had no doubt that the refugees were incarcerated in an inhumane place, and that ITN had won its case.

The BSC found that the BBC's paraphrasing of the judge's summing up could have left viewers with the false impression that ITN had got its facts wrong and won its case on a technicality.

Mr Higham was unavailable for comment.

A BBC statement said the corporation accepted Mr Higham had used an "unclear phrase", but it stood by the report's accuracy.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.body:
 "I'd never do anything topless, it's just not my thing. My female fan base is important to me, and I know what I think when I see someone doing that sort of thing. Besides, I don't need to do it, it doesn't sell me any more records. The only reason I'd do it is cos they'd airbrush my tits and make them look really good. But I'd still have to face the reality when I got home, so I don't see the point"

Sharleen Spiteri, lead singer of Texas, on why she won't be posing nude in a lad mag, Evening Standard

 "Essentially, he comes across as someone who has never been socialised by female company: bagging the comfiest seat, swigging down his drink before mine is poured, lighting his own cigarettes. More alarmingly, he swings into moaning mode"

Jan Moir meets Big Brother's Nasty Nick, Daily Telegraph

 "I do not believe this is some male-led movement designed to get females out of the workplace (more than 70 per cent of housewives work) and back to their rightful domain (the home). Rather I think it is a misguided attempt by a number of homely women to keep men off the domestic agenda. A fight back, if you like, against poor, put-down, nearly-new man, who might not be up for baking fairy cakes but is perfectly happy to cook a curry and, what is more, to clean up after himself... Just as some men have felt threatened by our entry into the workforce, so we, in turn, feel displaced by the idea of men coming into our kitchens. Women, these books seem to suggest, want total domination. They want to be breadwinner and breadmaker at the same time"

Jane Gordon on recent books that encourage women to re-embrace home and hearth, such as Nigella Lawson's How To Be A Domestic Goddess, Times

 "Reader: 'Now you're a lesbian, which of the Corrs do you fancy?'

Sinead: 'I don't fancy any of the Corrs. They're all beautiful but... too much blusher' "

Reader Q and A with Sinead O'Connor, Q magazine

 "Women have been terribly important to me. Not that I understand them. I just like the tangible comfort they give me and their different point of view ... I prefer the expression 'enlightened self-interest'. I'm used to working for women in the theatre and don't at all feel they should be kept in their place. But I prefer being with women who are intellectually my equal"

Peter O'Toole responds to accusations of male chauvinism, Daily Mail

webTitle: EU in talks over AOL/Time Warner

fields.headline: EU regulators in talks over AOL/Time Warner
fields.standfirst: EMI/Warner Music merger off
fields.trailText: 11.45am: EU regulators meet today to discuss the £92bn AOL/Time Warner merger, amid hopes that the failure of the EMI/Warner Music link-up will help the deal through.
fields.body:
European Union regulators are meeting today to discuss the £92bn merger between AOL and Time Warner, amid hopes that the failure of the EMI and Warner Music link-up will help the deal through.

EMI and Warner's decision to withdraw their application for EU approval of their merger removes one of the competition commission's key concerns over the AOL/Time Warner deal. Regulators were worried that Warner's parent company, Time Warner, would combine with AOL to dominate the online market for music distribution.

The EU's advisory committee on mergers has already received assurances from AOL and Time Warner that they would not discriminate against rival internet service providers for five years in the market for music downloads over the web.

But analysts are concerned that Mario Monti, the EU's competition commissioner, will maintain his tough stance after blocking three mergers in the past year.

Nicola Stewart, media analyst at Commerzbank, said: "The concerns are still there about downloading music over the internet, but how can the regulators define dominance of that market? It is very difficult to measure it."

The EU must make its decision on the AOL/Time Warner merger by October 24.

webTitle: WH Smith to publish own mags

fields.headline: WH Smith to publish and sell its own mags
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: WH Smith is to publish and sell its own magazines - some 24 new titles - in a series of launches from January, writes Maggie Brown.
fields.body:
WH Smith is set to publish and sell its own magazines - some 24 new titles - in a series of launches starting in January.

Contract publisher John Brown has won the contract to produce the titles. Each magazine, priced £2.99, will be a one-off addressing key decision-making times in people's lives, featuring real life stories and advice from experts.

John Brown's chief executive, Andrew Hirsch, said: "This time next year we will have magazines in the homes, weddings, hi-fi, computer, internet, health, kids and women's markets - plus a dozen others."

The first four titles appear in January, with four more appearing every two months.

The publisher's editor-in-chief, Paul Colbert, said the company was taking on an extra 25 editorial and advertising staff for the project.

The move will intensify competition for magazine sales at a time when the retailer is trying to force through a rationalisation of its wholesaling arrangements.

webTitle: Heavyweights and new names make up this year's Booker shortlist

fields.headline: Heavyweights and new names make up this year's Booker shortlist
fields.trailText: Atwood and Ishiguro make the Booker Prize shortlist announced this morning but Zadie Smith misses out
fields.body:
The shortlist for the ever-controversial Booker Prize was announced this morning and is likely to create the usual speculation and debate.

It contains some highly-tipped big-hitters, including Margaret Atwood for The Blind Assassin, her fourth appearance on a Booker shortlist, with a tale of an 82-year-old woman's reflection on her life and sister's suicide, and Kazuo Ishiguro (winner of the 1989 award with The Remains of the Day) for When We Were Orphans, the story of a celebrated 1930s detective haunted by the disappearance of his parents. It does not, however, feature this year's most-tipped book, White Teeth by Zadie Smith.

Instead, we have the unexpected inclusion of Welsh writer Trezza Azzopardi for her first novel, The Hiding Place, which is set in the Cardiff criminal underworld of the 60s. Only published in August, it has received much critical acclaim and has also made the longlist for the Guardian First Book Award.

The other contenders are Michael Collins's tale of murder in a dying industrial town, The Keepers of Truth, and Matthew Kneale's English Passengers, the story of a priest determined to prove what he sees as the truths of the Bible. The sixth title is The Deposition of Father McCreevy by Brian O'Doherty, a dark tale of a near-extinct Irish village in which all the women die in mysterious circumstances.

Early rumours from within the Booker camp are that this year's most talked-about judge, TV presenter Mariella Frostrup, was keen to promote books with strong storylines - a keynote of this year's list. It is also rumoured that Anne Enright's novel, What Are You Like?, about a set of twins separated at birth, only just missed out on the shortlist.

Chairman of the judges, journalist Simon Jenkins, said: "Selecting the shortlist has not been easy but we have been greatly impressed by the range of books presented to us. The shortlist shows narrative energy, imaginative treatment and original voices from unpredictable quarters".

The judging panel also included Roy Foster, professor of Irish History at Oxford University, Caroline Gascoigne , literary editor of the Sunday Times and bestselling author Rose Tremain. The judges will meet again on November 7 to choose the winner to be announced at a dinner on the same evening at the Guildhall in London. The winner receives a total of £21,000 and a guaranteed upturn in sales. The other five shortlisted authors each receive £1,000.

The shortlisted books are:

The Blind Assassin by Margaret Atwood (Bloomsbury)

The Hiding Place by Trezza Azzopardi (Picador)

The Keepers of Truth by Michael Collins (Phoenix House)

When We Were Orphans by Kazuo Ishiguro (Faber and Faber)

English Passengers by Matthew Kneale (Hamish Hamilton)

The Deposition of Father McGreevy by Brian O'Doherty (Arcadia)

fields.headline: Tobacco ads: agency boss warns of 'blanket ban'
fields.standfirst:
Advertisers welcome ad ban ruling
Tobacco industry reacts
fields.trailText: 12pm: Nick Mustoe, chief executive at Mustoe Merriman Herring Levy, which handles the account for Imperial Tobacco, gives his reaction on the tobacco ad ban to Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Nick Mustoe, chief executive at Mustoe Merriman Herring Levy, which handles the account for Imperial Tobacco, said he believed the government would now make a concerted effort to push through primary legislation and warned that this could lead to a blanket ban on tobacco ads.

He said: "We could see a blanket ban on tobacco advertising as soon as next spring assuming that the government can push primary legislation through smoothly.

"This is likely now to be more far-reaching - it could completely ban all print and poster advertising, put a block on all point of sale material as well as all database marketing, loyalty schemes and brand extension work."

"This is likely now to be more far-reaching - it could completely ban all print and poster advertising, put a block on all point of sale material as well as all database marketing, loyalty schemes and brand extension work."

webTitle: Tobacco ad ban overturned by European Court

fields.headline: Advertisers welcome overturning of EU tobacco ad ban
fields.trailText: The advertising industry has welcomed the decision by the European Court of Justice to overrule EU plans to ban tobacco advertising, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The advertising industry has welcomed the decision by the European Court of Justice to overrule EU plans to ban tobacco advertising.

The move will come as an enormous relief to the tobacco industry, which has invested a huge amount of time and money fighting the EU crackdown on smoking and advertising.

If the ban had gone through, it would have seen an end to billboard and cinema advertising by 2001, and newspaper and magazine adverts would have been made illegal by 2005. Sports tobacco advertising would have ceased by 2003, although Formula One had an extension until 2006. After that time the only tobacco ads allowed would have been in specialist trade journals and in-store promotions.

Tobacco advertising on television is already banned in 15 EU countries.

Rupert Howell, president of the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising, said this morning: "Everyone tried telling the government that this would happen but it got on its high horse and wouldn't listen. This outcome was completely inevitable and the government should have been prepared to reach some compromise. The only option it left the tobacco industry was to take it to court.

"The voluntary codes of practice were increasingly putting restrictions on the tobacco industry's freedom to advertise. Deadlines were bought forward and then the whole Ecclestone affair caused great political embarassment, ensuring that everyone clammed up and stopped talking."

Andrew Brown, director general at the Advertising Association, said that the government had ignored legal advice that it was likely to lose if the case went before the European Court of Justice. He added that for now certain restrictions will remain in place - all tobacco advertising will have to be certified before it breaks and limits on expenditure will remain.

The campaign fell through on technical grounds, because the European Commission introduced the measures under EU single market legislation and not as a health and safety issue. Now that the judges have thrown out the ruling, the Commission is expected to reintroduce the plans as health and safety legislation before the end of the year.

Tobacco companies have insisted for years that Brussels had no legal basis to legislate across the EU on advertising. But, the Commission chose to use the single market legislation because it requires only a qualified majority of member states to go through and is therefore quicker.

fields.headline: Vojislav Kostunica
fields.standfirst: Opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica carries the hopes of Serbians and the west in his battle to take power from president Slobodan Milosevic. But his hardline nationalist views mean he is no lover of Nato
fields.trailText: Profile: Opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica carries the hopes of Serbians and the west in his battle to take power from president Slobodan Milosevic. But his hardline nationalist views mean he is no lover of Nato.
fields.body:
In their thirst for change, Serbians have turned to Vojislav Kostunica, an obscure constitutional lawyer with a reputation for integrity. The west is also placing its hope in the man poised to take over from Slobodan Milosevic if the current campaign of civil disobedience succeeds.

But the 56-year-old Mr Kostunica is no liberal. He is a fervent Serb nationalist who rails against Nato, as much as the present regime, for Belgrade's distressed state.

He has said he would refuse to turn Mr Milosevic over to the Hague war crimes tribunal, does not recognise Montenegro's existence as a republic and would demand that Nato forces leave Kosovo and Serb forces be allowed to return.

The soft-spoken and dour lawyer was even photographed last year in northern Kosovo brandishing an assault rifle, paramilitary-style.

But given Serbia's desperate wish to end its pariah status, the west can count on Mr Kostunica not to indulge in the kind of military adventurism that has spilt so much blood and led to a truncated Yugoslavia, shorn of Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, and effectively Kosovo.

At the very least, Mr Kostunica can be expected to back off from moves to destabilise Montenegro in return for desperately-needed western aid. He has said he would accept a pro-independence referendum in Montenegro, but expects the majority of Montegrins to stay within what remains of Yugoslavia.

And he has gone on record as saying that Serbia should make its peace with Europe.

Mr Kostunica's primary appeal to his long-suffering compatriots is his reputation for honesty - in contrast to other opposition leaders, tainted by allegations of corruption and their willingness to compromise with the regime.

Unlike Vuk Draksovic and Zoran Djindjic, two other opposition figures, who favoured large Audis and long holidays on Montenegro's coastline, Mr Kostunica drives a battered Yugo. Whether by design or necessity, Mr Kostunica's habit of driving around Serbia during the election campaign struck a chord with voters more used to chauffeur-driven limousines and carefully staged rallies.

Even Mr Kostunica's lack of charisma works in his favour as Serbians see his penchant for academic jargon rather than glib sound bites as evidence of his integrity.

His supporters have also played up the legend that the man to save Serbia will come from the place of the same name. Mr Kostunica's roots go back to Kostunici, a village on the slopes of Mount Suvobor.

In the late 1980s, Mr Kostunica turned down an offer to join Mr Milosvic's government. Instead, he formed a small political party, the Democratic Party of Serbia.

Throughout the Bosnian war, Mr Kostunica kept a low profile, although his public statements mirrored public sentiment that the west was mainly to blame for the country's state.

Mr Kostunica, who is fluent in English, is confident that the historical tide is going his way. He doubts that that Mr Milosevic has the strength to resort to force and thinks if there is bloodshed, the Yugoslav leader will be finished.

webTitle: Tobacco industry wants to keep voluntary practice

fields.headline: Tobacco industry seeks retention of voluntary agreement
fields.standfirst:
Ad agency boss warns of blanket ban
Agencies welcome EU ruling
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: John Carlyle, a senior spokesperson for the trade association Tobacco Manufacturers' Industry, said the industry would fight for its right to retain direct communication with its customers, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
John Carlyle, a senior spokesperson for the trade association Tobacco Manufacturers' Industry, said the industry would fight for its right to retain direct communication with its customers and hoped that the government would opt to retain the voluntary code of practice.

He said: "For us the best case scenario is that we retain the voluntary agreement which in the past has meant that tobacco companies can not advertise in magazines that have a young readership or within 200 metres of schools or in shop windows. It also ensures that every ad is monitored by the Advertising Standards Authority prior to release.

"This system has worked so well in the past and we want to be allowed to continue personal communication with our customers - that is a priority."

Mr Carlyle also pointed out that the new Human Rights bill which came into operation this month may make it difficult for the government to ban the flow of literature between tobacco companies and smokers who ask for it.

webTitle: England canter to victory over Bangladesh

fields.headline: England canter to victory over Bangladesh
fields.standfirst: England (236-2) beat Bangladesh (232-8) by eight wickets
fields.trailText: England cantered to a comfortable eight-wicket win against Bangladesh in the third and final preliminary match in the ICC Knockout Trophy at Nairobi. Set 233 to win, they reached 236-2 with more than six overs to spare. And there was a welcome return to run-making - if not quite to full form - for Nasser Hussain, who hit an increasingly rumbustious 95 and even made a fluent Alec Stewart look tardy. England now meet South Africa in the quarter-final on Tuesday.
fields.body:
England cantered to a comfortable eight-wicket win against Bangladesh in the third and final preliminary match in the ICC Knockout Trophy at Nairobi. Set 233 to win, they reached 236-2 with more than six overs to spare. And there was a welcome return to run-making - if not quite to full form - for Nasser Hussain, who hit an increasingly rumbustious 95 and even made a fluent Alec Stewart look tardy. England now meet South Africa in the quarter-final on Tuesday.

Bangladesh needed a tidy start from their opening bowlers, but the first over was the stuff of nightmares. Hasibul Hossain, a right-arm medium-pacer, bowled six no-balls and a leg-side wide and conceded two boundaries - a pull each for Stewart and Marcus Trescothick. By the time he finished, England had 17 on the board.

It meant they could afford to take it easy for a few overs, but Trescothick was in attacking mood. He cut Mushfiqur for four as the ball bounced off the dry turf over the head of gully, and in the next over punched Hussain through mid-off in that upright way of his. Then he lost concentration. The ball after aiming a big heave outside off stump he played another uncontrolled drive and this time edged it to the keeper. With a furious Trescothick gone for 15, England were 33-1 - the same score at which Bangladesh had lost their first wicket, but reached in six fewer overs.

Stewart took over. When Mushfiqur over-pitched, he drove him between extra-cover and mid-off for four, and when Hussain strayed in length, Stewart drove him straight for four more. Two balls later, Stewart worked the ball through midwicket with a perfect piece of timing.

At the other end, Hussain was carrying on where he left off at the end of the English season, struggling to lay bat on ball and groping at thin air outside offstump. But he broke his duck off his 12th delivery with a glorious stroke, spanking Mushfiqur through the covers for four to bring up England's 50 and straight-drove the same bowler to the boundary five balls later.

After 15 overs England were motoring at 86-1 - the highest score at that stage of the innings of the competition - and Stewart moved to 50 soon after, slog-sweeping Enamul Hoque over midwicket for six. It was Stewart's fifth consecutive score of 50 or more in one-day internationals after his golden NatWest Series in the summer.

Hussain brought up the England hundred with a late glide to the third-man boundary off Rafique, before going down on one knee to waft Hoque over midwicket for six - a shot that took his to 1000 runs in ODIs. But although the runs were - at long last - coming, Hussain didn't look entirely convincing, aiming an array of mistimed sweeps and slogs at the spinners.

It was only when he decided to hit the spinners over the top that he really started to bat with real authority. Hussain registered the century partnership with a straight six off Naimur Rahman's off-spin and got his first 50 in nine one-day international innings in the next over, sweeping Hoque for four. Stewart drove Rahman straight for another boundary, to bring up England's 150 in the 30th over.

It was a signal for a rare Hussain purple patch. He lifted Rahman for a straight six, swept Hoque for four more, then launched successive sixes off Rahman, the second landing upon the canvas covering over the cameramen. In those three overs, Hussain went some way to exorcising the ghosts of a miserable summer.

But with his first ODI hundred another big hit away, Hussain poked a tame return catch to Rafique and departed with an angry swish of the bat. At 208-2, though, it didn't matter and Hick provided the finishing touches.

Earlier, England fielded as poorly as they have done under Duncan Fletcher to concede 232-8 in 50 overs. Five catches of varying difficulty were dropped, two run outs were missed, and there were three lots of overthrows to go with several other misfields. As England wilted, Bangladesh flowered, upping the tempo as they went along and blasting 83 from their final ten overs.

Their total was built around an unbeaten 63 from opener Javed Omar, who had retired hurt on 14 after being struck on the right index finger by a rising ball from Andy Caddick but returned to reach an aggressive half-century with a big six over cover off Mark Alleyne.

Omar shared a pulsating partnership of 64 with captain Naimur Rahman, whose 46 was full of daring drives and included a six off Craig White over midwicket. While they were together, England looked distinctly ordinary. It's been a while since anyone has been able to write that.

Bangladesh Javed Omar, Al Sahariar Rokon, Habibul Bashar, Aminul Islam, Akram Khan, Naimur Rahman (capt), Khaled Mashud (wkt), Mohammad Rafique, Mushfiqur Rahman, Enamul Hoque, Hasibul Hussain.

England ME Trescothick, AJ Stewart (wkt), N Hussain (capt), GA Hick, GP Thorpe, C White, MW Alleyne, MA Ealham, A Flintoff, AR Caddick, D Gough.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com.

webTitle: Vivendi chairman in 'strategic accord' talks with Murdoch

fields.headline: Vivendi chairman in 'strategic accord' talks with Murdoch
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Vivendi chairman Jean-Marie Messier has confirmed he is discussing a "managerial partnership" or "strategic accord" with Rupert Murdoch. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Jean-Marie Messier, chairman of French media giant Vivendi, has confirmed he is discussing a "managerial partnership" or "strategic accord" with Rupert Murdoch.

Mr Messier is keen to take a stake in Sky Global Networks, the umbrella company formed by Mr Murdoch's satellite TV interests. The ambitious chairman has threatened to sell his 21.5% holding in BSkyB - Murdoch's digital and satellite broadcast operation - if it is not converted into Sky Global shares.

Mr Messier has been encouraged by Mr Murdoch's recent deal with US cable operator Liberty Media, which saw the company take a 4% stake in Sky Global.

Meanwhile, Vivendi has refused to comment on reports of a fall-out between Mr Messier and Pierre Lescure, chairman of Canal Plus - Vivendi's pay-TV subsidiary. French newspaper Le Monde has claimed that Mr Lescure is close to resigning after arguing with Mr Messier over the company's future plans.

Mr Lescure is said to be unhappy over plans to split Canal Plus between its domestic and international operations if Vivendi's proposed £23bn merger with Seagram of Canada is completed.

fields.headline: Patchy England become the underdogs
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain's run famine didn't just end in Nairobi today - it turned into a run feast. After reaching his first fifty for England since January, Hussain opened his shoulders and hit Bangladesh's spinners for a flurry of sixes. He shot past his partner Alec Stewart, who had made the early running, and although he fell five short of a hundred, he did make the highest one-day score of his 11-year international career.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain's run famine didn't just end in Nairobi today - it turned into a run feast. After reaching his first fifty for England since January, Hussain opened his shoulders and hit Bangladesh's spinners for a flurry of sixes. He shot past his partner Alec Stewart, who had made the early running, and although he fell five short of a hundred, he did make the highest one-day score of his 11-year international career.

Yesterday Stewart had said that England should treat Bangladesh as a minor county. For most of the morning, that remark threatened to come straight back to haunt England. Their bowling was innocuous and their fielding worse than that. The Bangladeshis threw the bat with abandon in the last 10 overs to reach a highly respectable total of 232.

England were one batting collapse away from stumbling out of the ICC Knockout with a sore head and a red face. But Stewart quickly showed what he had meant about treating amateur bowling with disdain, racing to his fifth consecutive one-day international fifty following his deep-purple patch in the summer.

Hussain began warily, as befitted a man who had made only 162 runs in 18 international innings since January 30. When he accelerated, he got a bit manic, reverse-sweeping rather than just milking some very friendly slow bowling. But after 50 he finally found his form, just as Duncan Fletcher had said he would. He hit Naimur Rahman for two sixes off successive balls, and cleared the boundary five times in all. He even smiled.

It still wasn't a great day for England. Allowing Bangladesh to score 230 is like conceding 400 against Australia or South Africa. And although they knocked the runs off with ease in the end, that can create its own problems, as England know from the 1999 World Cup. All three of their wins were by large margins batting second, so the middle order only got a bat when they were under intense pressure - and crumpled each time.

England's recovery means that for the neutral observer, the Knockout has yet to come to life. All three games have gone to form and all three minnows are out - Kenya, Bangladesh and West Indies, who came here with a side that was second-rate even by their recent one-day standards. Now that England are safely through to face South Africa in Tuesday's quarter-final, please can we have a few surprises?

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com.

fields.headline: Do they mean us?
fields.standfirst: There are few women, nobody works and a sizeable portion of the population subsists on a diet of boiled eggs and amphetamines. With the triumphant Billy Elliot about to pirouette through the world's cinemas,  Emma Brockes  takes a look at Britain - the way it looks on the big screen
fields.trailText: There are few women, nobody works and a sizeable portion of the population subsists on a diet of boiled eggs and amphetamines. With the triumphant Billy Elliot about to pirouette through the world's cinemas, Emma Brockes takes a look at Britain - the way it looks on the big screen
fields.body:
Names

The British don't have Christian names as such, but identify each other by an elaborate range of nicknames, possibly derived from rhyming slang or Saxon folklore. British children will answer to Begbie, Spud, Sick Boy (Trainspotting), Spike (Notting Hill), Lomper and Horse (The Full Monty), Soap, Bacon, Dog and Plank (Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels) and their regional variants.

As in ancient times, many British men are named for ease of identification with their trade, such as Tinker, an Irish labourer (The Crying Game), William Thacker, a bookshop owner in Notting Hill, or Mr Bean, a man whose escapades evoke the British love of toilet humour, engendered by the laxative effect of baked beans. (See sense of humour, below.)

At the lower end of the social scale, nostalgia for the second world war still resonates, with chocks-away names such as Bunty (Chicken Run) and Daffy (The Beach) enjoying a resurgence, while at the higher end of the scale, anyone who isn't the Duke of Norfolk or the Earl of Sussex is called Charles or Rufus, or if they live in Scotland, Angus or "Mac". There aren't many women in Britain, but the few there are derive their names from US movie history (Scarlett, Four Weddings) or are called Victoria and Elizabeth and are the Queen of England.

The economy

The engine of the British economy is driven by cannabis farming (Saving Grace; Lock, Stock), a booming cottage industry that fluctuates in accordance with the laws of plunder and gang in-fighting. Northern cities such as Sheffield used to be great centres of industry, but had to close when the demand for cutlery on the southern wedding circuit used up all their materials. There is a bitter divide between the prosperous south, where owners of money-losing bookshops maintain houses in London's most expensive districts, and the north, where levels of deprivation are such that repressed former steel workers have to strip to earn a crust and striking miners burn pianos for firewood. Ireland is mostly under water (Angela's Ashes).

Class system

Britain operates on a more or less feudal system. Slave labour (allegorically addressed in Chicken Run) is a reality for the serfs who live north of the Wash and subsist on a diet of boiled eggs and amphetamines. Cultural deprivation has turned them wild: they underline their points by upsetting teacups and sob after their annual glass of wine at Christmas. Exposure to the Royal Ballet renders them infantile.

Leisure activities in Britain are deeply divided by class. Children in the north of England start drinking cider at the age of 11, and their fathers box or pursue the popular working-class pastime of loitering (Billy Elliot; The Full Monty; Brassed Off). They are cold, but they've got rhythm. Middle-class men in the north of England collect garden gnomes, and those from the south attend the screening of foreign language films and learn sign language to better communicate with the deaf (Four Weddings).

In Scotland, the Darwinian principle of survival of the fittest is a daily reality, where drug addicts compete with Scottish nationalists on the streets of Glasgow and the highlands are populated by red-haired giants known as "clansmen", harbouring ancient hatreds and nursing glory in their hearts (Rob Roy).

Job opportunities

Nobody in Britain works, except for a few caterers on the London party circuit and some Irish terrorists posing as builders. Instead, men of working age picket their employers for reasons unknown - possibly for a better dress allowance - and attend job clubs, converted classrooms in which they are tempted out of the iron age by being taught how to operate a word processor (The Full Monty). However, their permanent state of outrage renders most northern men unemployable. When their wives (or more probably, ex-wives) are prised out of the kitchen, it is only to work in an environment where they are permitted to smoke, such as a municipal hall, the fields, or behind the bar in a working men's club.

The social commitments of the metropolitan elite make full-time work out of the question, although they play at the fringes of the more genteel trades, such as antiquarian book selling, the voluntary sector and the business of opening a restaurant.

Transport

The National Express coach net work is the only way of travelling up and down the country, although it's a journey that few undertake, given the shock awaiting them on arrival. Men entering London from the north for the first time are disoriented by its lack of coalmines and the suspicion that all southern men are repressed homosexuals. Southern men taking the coach north close their eyes until they reach Scotland, when they are whisked away from the terminus to their highland estates (Four Weddings; Elizabeth; Mrs Brown).

Londoners get around in four-wheel drive vehicles or hail a taxi, or if they are on urgent business, steal a van. There are buses in London, but they are decorative rather than functional and cater largely for the tourist market. In Scotland people make do with walking or, more commonly, running, with the law in pursuit.

Communication

A Briton from the south who trips over a paving stone might exclaim "oops-a-daisy" (Notting Hill), whereas a northerner might say "fook". (Billy Elliot). A northerner defending himself against a verbal attack might plead "keep your blob on", which is patois for "remain calm". Other key words in the northerner's vocabulary are, "twat", "wanker", and "chuffed", and most northerners communicate by using combinations of these three basic terms.

The Scottish speak a pidgin language that requires subtitles in more evolved parts of the English-speaking world. For example, "fling yir fuckin jaykit oan well" means "hang your coat up", and "ye ken she's really intae ye" stands for "you know she finds you attractive". "Ya plukey-faced wee hing oot" has no known English equivalent.

In London, men affectionately greet each other as "bruvver", as in "nice one, bruvver", or "geezer", as in "all right, geezer?", or confine themselves to the universal greeting of the east end, "safe", which means, "hello" (Lock, Stock).

Dress

The British are unjustly targeted as poor dressers, when in fact they adhere to a strict set of tribal dress codes. Donkey jackets are the uniform of the northern man, where the recession has hit the manufacture of any colour brighter than grey, and northern women wear gold hoops through their ears and tracksuit bottoms that have lost their elastic. In the south, it is customary for men to wear suits, with an optional cummerbund around the waist, and for women to wear wide hats and ethnic jewellery, or to dye their hair burnt orange in protest against the burden of privilege under which they live (Four Weddings).

Sex

Sex in Britain, if it exists at all, is a quick and unfulfilling affair. British men prefer the company of other British men and are predominantly asexual (Mr Bean), unless they are pursuing the age-old highland sport of rape and pillage. Since most British women are either recently deceased, of retirement age, or members of the royal family, sex is off the agenda. They tend to regard men as feeble under-performers who don't live up to their fathers (A Fish Called Wanda) or as brutes liable to pawn their jewellery as soon as they hit the pathologist's slab (Billy Elliot). A British man called upon to court a woman will go through a series of extraordinary contortions, culminating in a slapstick attempt to embrace her and ending in total humiliation, probably in his socks and underpants (Notting Hill). When it comes to sex, most British men would rather sit on a park bench reading Captain Corelli's Mandolin or marry their labradors.

Sense of humour

Since the British laugh at their own shortcomings, they are in a perpetual state of amusement. They are particularly aroused by stories turning on the triumph of the underdog, such as a boy from a northern housing estate getting into the Royal Ballet school, hens escaping from a slaughterhouse, or a humble bookseller from Notting Hill wooing a Hollywood movie star with hilarious consequences.

When the underdog spills things, walks into doors and is caught picking his nose by the object of his affection, the average Briton will be diverted for hours. Anyone who speaks in an accent three or more counties removed from his listener is guaranteed a delirious audience.

webTitle: Bank keeps interest rates unchanged at 6%

fields.headline: Bank keeps interest rates unchanged at 6%
fields.trailText: The Bank of England today announced it was leaving interest rates on hold at 6%.
fields.body:
The Bank of England today announced it was leaving interest rates on hold at 6%.

It is the eighth month in succession that the bank's nine-member monetary policy committee (MPC) has left the official cost of borrowing unchanged.

With latest figures showing underlying inflation at just 1.9% - well below the government's 2.5% target - industry and unions have argued that there would be no justification for a rate rise.

They fear an increase would drive the pound even higher against the euro, adding to the difficulties of exporters struggling to compete aboard.

But the "hawks" on the MPC remain concerned about inflationary pressures in the economy.

There are also worries about the impact of rising oil prices. The August inflation figures were so low because of a fall in petrol prices - which have since risen again.

One union leader has argued that the MPC should be talking about cutting interest rates rather than raising them. Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Finance and Science union, warned that 30,000 jobs could be lost unless the cost of borrowing started to come down.
