webTitle: Harry Potter writer rallies to aid of lone parents

fields.headline: Harry Potter writer rallies to aid of lone parents
fields.trailText: JK Rowling yesterday donated £500,000 to the cause of one-parent families and launched a fierce attack on the widespread assumption that most single mothers are 'feckless teenagers trying to get council flats'
fields.body:
JK Rowling, author of the Harry Potter books, yesterday donated £500,000 to the cause of one-parent families and launched a fierce attack on the widespread assumption that most single mothers are "feckless teenagers trying to get council flats".

Ms Rowling, 34, has been a lone parent since her marriage broke up seven years ago. She began her literary career while drawing benefit, writing in Edinburgh cafes as her daughter Jessica slept beside her. Last year she was Britain's highest-paid woman, earning £20.5m from her novels.

In her first appearance as "ambassador" for the National Council for One Parent Families, she described "feelings of worthlessness during interviews with the Child Support Agency and the Benefit Office" as she tried to escape the benefits trap and train as a teacher.

"I had a degree, a profession and friends who were willing to lend me money when I badly needed it. So if I met obstacles pulling myself out of the benefit system, how much more difficult must it be for people who don't have the same advantages?" she said.

Ms Rowling's £500,000 donation will almost double the council's charitable income this year. She is to lead a fundraising drive to find a further £500,000 from other sources to give on-line advice to lone parents on a website, launched yesterday.

The author said her daughter was a source of pride, joy and motivation. "I don't want her to grow up in a society where children just like her are trapped in poverty because they have had the misfortune to see their parents split up.

"It is convenient to look right over these children's heads at the parent left raising them and place blame, rather than seeing the reality: somebody striving, in the face of great odds, to give their children every opportunity they can."

Only 3% of Britain's 1.7m lone parents were teenagers, while 60% had been married and separated, divorced or bereaved.

"Seven years after becoming a lone parent, I feel qualified to look anyone in the eye and say that people bringing up children single-handedly deserve, not condemnation, but congratulation," she said.

The author said she was pleased with the help for lone parents under the government's New Deal. "But there are still about a million children living in poverty so obviously a great deal more needs to be done."

Kate Green, the council's director, said a quarter of British families were headed by a lone parent. "Most didn't choose to be alone and are doing their best in a tough situation."

Lone parents had overtaken pensioners as the poorest group, with more than three in five living in poverty. Ms Green said she was disappointed that Conservative plans to give more support for mothers to stay at home were to be only for married couples. Similar help was required by lone parents whose children were often distressed and most needed the remaining parent to be at home for a while.

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.trailText: October 5: Granada Media and Carlton are in the early stages of discussions about pooling resources.
fields.body:
Granada Media and Carlton are in the early stages of discussions about pooling resources in areas including resources, distribution, transmission, broadband and publicity, according to sources. The two leading ITV companies are said to be talking about setting up joint ventures to run various areas of their non-programming operations. The move would lead to redundancies.

Granada Media is expected to merge the LWT and newly acquired United Productions drama departments, under United controller of drama Michele Buck. The move follows the departure of LWT controller of drama, Jo Wright, to TalkBack Productions - and her deputy, Laura Mackie, to the BBC.

Broadcasting minister Janet Anderson is understood to have guaranteed that the BBC will have to stick to the 25% independent production quota, across all licence-fee funded channels.

BBC Knowledge head of programming Liz Cleaver is to become controller, new media, in the factual and learning division. The BBC is to advertise internally for a new managing editor for the channel, who will report to digital channels and arts controller Roly Keating. BBC Knowledge is to become BBC4.

Hat Trick Productions has appointed Channel 4 entertainment editor Cheryl Taylor to the newly created position of head of comedy.

webTitle: Tory MP Peter Bottomley's conference diary

fields.headline: Do the conference watchers understand what they are observing?
fields.trailText: Virginia and I enjoyed the best fringe discussion with Bert Massie and his colleagues of the Disability Rights Commission.
fields.body:
Virginia and I enjoyed the best fringe discussion with Bert Massie and his colleagues of the Disability Rights Commission.

The chief executive, Bob Niven, had in 1985 helped me attend the Liverpool-Juventus game at the Heysel stadium. Death and disaster are part of life. I think, provisionally, that it is possible better to contribute sensibly to strategies for casualty reduction with some experience of the consequences and causes.

The line "It is worth it if it saves only one life" too often conceals the bruising truth that many more may be lost unless there is generally effective action.

Tobacco advertising is the topic now. Bluntly, the 5,000 of last week's smokers who won't smoke again are replaced by 5,000 teenagers - not because of advertising, but because of example and the stupid adult habit of declaring that the young are too young to smoke.

That should be banned. Try saying: "Fifteen? Just the age - smoking is a frequent childish thing to do. Ask adult smokers when they started."

All the radio and television interviewers are making the same mistake. Our smoking dropped from 80% of adult men to less than 30 % for reasons other than discussion of advertising (not that there is a good argument for tobacco promotion - it is just that the ban would be a balsa wood crutch against smoking).

Here are two more media observations.

Newsnight managed to get two thirds through its time last night before turning to the conference - and even then did not manage to refer to Ann Widdecombe on prison reform. The coverage of civil fines for illegal drugs could have been portrayed the other way round.

Memory corner: when organising random surveys to confirm the real incidence of drink-driving, I anticipated criticism for interfering with civil liberties. Instead, I welcomed the attack for allowing the illegals to accept an offer to avoid driving off.

Guardian stereotype: John Bercow comes up in today's paper for speaking at the Blue and Black inclusive IPPR meeting before apparently impersonating Enoch Powell elsewhere. Is there space in the paper to let readers know what he said on widening Conservative representation?

When I received my welcome dismissal from government in 1990, the Guardian invited me to write an article on any subject of my choice. I questioned whether this was real. The piece was in praise of the values of the civil service and of the BBC. It was not published. The initial reason may have been the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The subsequent line was: "Not quite what we were expecting."

If the watchers of politicians and of conferences do not understand what they are observing, neither can their readers and viewers. My normal plea is for the same standards of accuracy as in sports coverage: assume many of the media audience could have been watching the event too.

Peter Bottomley is Conservative MP for Worthing West

Guardian stereotype: John Bercow comes up in today's paper for speaking at the Blue and Black inclusive IPPR meeting before apparently impersonating Enoch Powell elsewhere. Is there space in the paper to let readers know what he said on widening Conservative representation? When I received my welcome dismissal from government in 1990, the Guardian invited me to write an article on any subject of my choice. I questioned whether this was real. The piece was in praise of the values of the civil service and of the BBC. It was not published. The initial reason may have been the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The subsequent line was: "Not quite what we were expecting." If the watchers of politicians and of conferences do not understand what they are observing, neither can their readers and viewers. My normal plea is for the same standards of accuracy as in sports coverage: assume many of the media audience could have been watching the event too. Peter Bottomley is Conservative MP for Worthing West

fields.headline: BBC names its pipeline teen publication
fields.trailText: 11.45am: The BBC has confirmed that its long-awaited celebrity teen mag Project G is to be named star, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC has confirmed that its long-awaited celebrity teen mag Project G is to be named star.

star will launch on October 18 with a £2m marketing budget, two weeks after the launch of a TV slot with the same name during the BBC's Live and Kicking.

Editor Jeremy Mark said the magazine would be "cooler, more aspirational and more sophisticated than anything currently available". The magazine takes its cue from US-based teen celebrity magazines like Entertainment Weekly and Teen People.

BBC Worldwide's decision to brand the TV slot with the magazine has attracted criticism from commercial publishing houses, who claim the BBC is using licence-fee funded programming to promote a commercial service.

webTitle: Seven ITV firms seek licence renewal

fields.headline: Seven ITV firms apply for licence renewal
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Seven ITV franchisees have applied to the Independent Television Commission to have their licences renewed from April 1, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Seven ITV franchisees have applied to the Independent Television Commission to have their licences renewed from April 1.

Border, Central, Channel, Grampian, Granada, LWT and Scottish have all submitted business plans and details of their proposed services for the 10-year licence period.

The ITC will use this information to decide at what level to set each franchisees' annual licence payment.

Border and Central applied to have their licences renewed in the initial round of submissions in 1998, but decided against accepting the ITC's offer. Central's annual payment would have increased by £17.5m, while Border's would have gone up by £440,000 a year.

All 18 ITV licensees have now applied to the ITC to have their licences renewed.

fields.standfirst: Polish director of a cult film which prefigured the work of Gilliam and Ruiz

fields.body:
What is the connection between Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead and the Polish film director Wojciech Has, who has died aged 75? Several years ago, Garcia offered funds to Los Angeles's Pacific Film Archive to buy a print of Has's most celebrated work, The Saragossa Manuscript (1964), in its complete 180-minute version. It had only been shown abroad in a truncated 120-minute version. Garcia's only stipulation was that he would always be given the privilege of seeing it, since it was his favourite film.

It took some years to track down the original, until Has realised that he had the only complete print hidden away. As the negative had been destroyed, a new one was struck with the help of money from Martin Scorsese, who was also interested in acquiring a print for his collection. Sadly, Garcia never lived to see the restored version , which was first shown in New York on May 21 1999.

It came as no surprise that Garcia, described as "the master of marathon, time-bending music", should have loved this Chinese box of a film (ie a story within a story within a story). It was based on the 1813 Polish novel written in French by historian and travel-writer Count Jan Potocki, who thereafter committed suicide. The film's cultish reputation - mainly because it was unseen for so long - not only survived the revival but was increased by it.

The tall tale, prefiguring the films of Terry Gilliam and Raul Ruiz, tells of a Belgian army officer, travelling to Madrid, who meets two beautiful princesses who send him on a fantastic journey to prove himself worthy of them. On the way, he meets ghosts, fights duels, wakes up from sexual ecstasy surrounded by bones and sculls, and puzzles over cabalistic signs. The director's use of the wide screen and the amiable performance by plumpish rebel-idol Zbigniew Cybulski, looking rather like Bob Hope on the road to somewhere or other, enhance this ambitious film.

The Saragossa Manuscript was the sixth feature directed by the Cracow-born Has. He graduated from the film institute of his home town, and began a distinguished career in documentary and educational film production. Has turned to fictional films in the mid-1950s, at the time of the regeneration of Polish cinema, but unlike many of his contemporaries, notably Andrzej Wajda and Andrzej Munk, he avoided specific preoccupation with the second world war and its immediate aftermath.

His few modern-day films, such as How To Be Loved (1963), concentrated on the way bourgeois intellectuals tried to assimilate into post- war Polish society. However, period pictures were his forte, eccentrically transposing challenging novels to the screen.

Alas, only one or two films from his rather meagre output were shown widely outside Poland. The first to be seen was The Noose (1958), a successful adaptation of Marek Hlasko's despairing story about the last day in the life of an alcoholic. Four years after the shortened The Saragossa Manuscript made a huge impact worldwide, with no less than Luis Buñuel lauding it, came The Doll (1968), Has's first film in colour, a story of unrequited love combined with a sharply satirical observation of Polish society during the turbulence of the mid-19th century, exposing snobbery and greed. It was long (nearly three hours) and enigmatic, but was as visually rich as its predecessor. The Hourglass Sanatorium (1973) was an imaginative stream-of-consciousness film dealing with the painful childhood memories of the Polish author Bruno Schulz.

At the heart of nearly every Has film is the idea of the journey - sometimes tangible, as in The Saragossa Manuscript, and sometimes spiritual, as in The Hourglass Sanatorium. In the course of these odysseys, his protagonists enter exotic and often menacing worlds that seem as much projections of fears or desires as they do real locations.

From 1990 to 1996, Has was head of the celebrated Lodz school, and also created the Indeks Foundation to help graduates launch careers and raise money when state subsidies for films dried up after the 1989 communist collapse.

He is survived by his wife, Wanda, and a son, Marek.

 Wojciech Has, film director, born April 1 1925; died October 3 2000

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Bags of trouble

As the last of the summer is gusted away, many of you are still sobbing over the ruination of your holiday dreams thanks to the incompetence of airlines. At Athens airport I overheard a British youth refusing to check his rucksack into the hold because, he claimed, he'd had stuff filched from his bag previously. Airport officials spirited him off to be dealt with; I checked my luggage on to the same flight and found it had been pilfered when it reappeared in London.

The unhappy truth is that airlines can force you to surrender your possessions to their care, but bear little or no responsibility if things go wrong.

Case for compensation

Ken Hutchinson of Sale, Cheshire, had intended to show his daughter the town in the former East Germany where he worked as a prisoner of war. Alas, their luggage did not follow them to Berlin. Lufthansa promised it would arrive on the next flight to Berlin. It didn't. Then it was to be delivered overnight. It wasn't. Lufthansa said it had been put on the wrong aircraft and would be there the following afternoon. It wasn't. That evening they were told there was no trace of the luggage on the computer; the next morning they learnt that one suitcase had shown up, but it was up to them to collect it; the other, containing vital medication for his daughter's back problems, had not. "By then my daughter had used up all her tablets in her hand luggage and was in such distress that she took an early flight home," says Hutchinson. He hoped to recoup the cost of the spoiled holiday from Lufthansa but has only received £57.

The overbook club

Sumita Datta of Basingstoke didn't even manage to get herself, let alone her luggage, on her Air India flight to London. In the morning of her departure she was rung by airline officials wanting to confirm her seat, and she arrived at check-in three hours early as advised. She was told, however, that the flight had been overbooked and there were no seats available. She and numerous others were told to come back the next day.

Poorly treated

Harold Fineberg of London and his wife booked a package to China involving several internal flights, but family illness prevented him from travelling on the scheduled date. Instead he bought another flight out and proposed to continue with the holiday as planned, but Air China informed him that the rest of the package was invalid because of his altered departure. Air China explained that it was governed by International Air Transport Association rules, which state that flight coupons must be used in date order or be forfeited, although, too late, it offered to amend his booking for £60 as a goodwill gesture.

Faithful followers of this page will already be aware of the bizarre rules governing airline liability. For instance, you get a maximum of £14 per kilo if your luggage is lost, a sum set by the Warsaw Convention in 1929. If it's delayed you're supposed to get money to fund emergency kit, provided you have receipts, but there's no scale to determine how much you get under specific circumstances. And the Air Transport Users' Council (AUC) reports that complaints about mishandled baggage have risen by a third in the past year.

As for overbooking, displaced passengers get 300 euros if they are travelling more than 3,500km, and that's halved if they arrive within four hours of their original scheduled time. Business travellers pay over the odds for tickets that entitle them to skip their flight without notice and claim a refund. It's to ensure that their empty seats are filled that airlines overbook, and it's the poorer passengers on use-it-or-lose-it tickets who must bear the consequences.

There is happier news on the horizon. This year's AUC annual report highlighted unfair contract terms which protect airlines and discriminate against passengers, and the office of fair trading has since ordered changes. These will include refunds if the airline is to blame for significant flight delays or if it reschedules flights without warning and can't provide an acceptable alternative. Passengers with non-refundable tickets will receive a credit note if unforeseen events prevent them from travelling. And if, for reasons beyond their control, they can't use a portion of their ticket, they'll no longer be barred from using return or onward flights. A while ago we related the case of a Ryanair customer who had to check in a pushchair and sign a limited release form absolving the airline from blame if it was damaged in the hold (which it was). Now Ryanair has agreed to accept responsibility for bulky or fragile luggage. And should Ken Hutchinson's suitcase be delayed again, the airline will have to deliver it to his hotel. "The old terms unnecessarily compromised air passengers' rights and gave airlines unreasonable advantages," says John Bridgeman, the director general of the OFT. "These changes will ensure that airline contracts are much fairer."

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip fined £100 for smoking the herb "for medicinal purposes"
fields.trailText: Chelsea have found a short-term replacement for the injured Roberto Di Matteo, according to the Daily Mail, the 32-year-old Yugoslav international Slavisa Jokanovic. Jokanovic, who plays for the Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna would cost £3.5m. The paper also believes that Chelsea will move for Emmanuel Petit before the end of the year, and that the former Arsenal midfielder would not see a return to England as "a retrograde step".
fields.body:
Chelsea have found a short-term replacement for the injured Roberto Di Matteo, according to the Daily Mail, the 32-year-old Yugoslav international Slavisa Jokanovic. Jokanovic, who plays for the Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna would cost £3.5m. The paper also believes that Chelsea will move for Emmanuel Petit before the end of the year, and that the former Arsenal midfielder would not see a return to England as "a retrograde step".

The Mail also suggests that David Seaman's time at Arsenal could be drawing to a close. The England keeper has asked for a one-year extension to his current contract, the paper reports, but the Gunners are stalling. At the same time, Arsene Wenger is stepping up attempts to sign the talented Polish international keeper Jerzy Dudek from Feyenoord.

Barcelona are willing to pay Liverpool £35m for Michael Owen according to the Mirror. They believe that the England striker would be an ideal fillip for the beleaguered Catalan giants.

Teamtalk claim that there is soon to be a three-way scrap for the signature of Jason Euell. Spurs, Chelsea and Newcastle United are all interested in Wimbledon's former England under-21 international who has been in impressive form for the Dons in recent weeks.

Manchester City may attempt to sign Newcastle's Peruvian winger Nolberto Solano. The Daily Express reports that Joe Royle has turned his attentions to the 25-year-old after being knocked back in his approach for defender Laurent Charvet.

The Daily Express also believes that Blackburn Rovers are to make another attempt to sign Liverpool's Brad Friedel. The US international has been denied a work permit at Anfield, but Rovers are confident of adding Friedel to their roster.

Rio Ferdinand has asked West Ham fans not to believe rumours linking him with a move to Leeds United. "I know where I am and I am happy at West Ham," Ferdinand is quoted as saying in the Daily Star. "What frustrates me is that fans will start thinking I'm putting it in the papers, or that perhaps my agent is. That is simply not the case."

fields.headline: BBC to hail Wembley stadium online
fields.trailText: 11.30am: BBC Sport is to screen a 40-minute tribute to Wembley stadium this Friday - exclusively on its website, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
BBC Sport is to screen a 40-minute tribute to Wembley stadium this Friday - exclusively on its website. The webcast, which is being screened at 1.30pm, is presented by Ray Stubbs live from Wembley.

The programme will feature a selection of people who have contributed towards making the stadium an important sporting landmark, including Mark Lawrenson, World Cup hero Martin Peters, Rugby League's Ellery Hanley and the soccer referee Roger Milford, and other interviews with personalities such as Midge Ure, one of the organisers of the Live Aid event.

There are no plans to screen the programme on BBC's TV channels, although according to Mike Hales at BBC Sport publicity, there will be a tribute within Saturday's screening of Football Focus.

The specially set-up website, bbc.co.uk/wembley, also features a virtual tour of the stadium, archive material and a competition to win a piece of Wembley turf.

Pete Clifton, project leader of BBC Sport Online, said: "We hope we can use all the interactive features at our disposal to organise a fitting tribute for the stadium."

webTitle: In brief: Vigilante US theatres bar underage punters

fields.headline: Vigilante US theatres bar underage punters
fields.trailText: Plus: Redford defies wrecking ball, Resident Evil greenlighted, murdered Irish hack to get Schumacher treatment, Kathy Bates moves in next door to Kevin Costner, Luke Wilson for Legally Blonde and Wanted: 1 Green Goblin
fields.body:
 Washington's recent charge that Hollywood is targeting teenage consumers with inappropriate material appears to be having ripples in America as a whole. This week two New York cinemas took the matter into their own hands by refusing to admit anyone under 17 to Darren Aronofsky's R-rated Requiem for a Dream - even if they are accompanied by an adult. But the move by the Loews Lincoln Plaza and United Artists Union Square has drawn barbs from some sections of the press. Writing in the New York Daily News, Jack Mathews damned it as "political pandering" and "a knee-jerk response to the recent political furore". There was a danger, he claimed, that such actions "could turn theatre operators into freelance moral guardians".

 In keeping with his heroic image, Robert Redford has stepped in to save a forlorn and decrepit cinema from the developer's wrecking-ball. The actor is determined to protect Santa Monica's Aero movie house - a venue he attended regularly as a child - from demolition. Redford plans to turn it into a showcase for independent cinema.

 British director Paul Anderson has received the green light to script and direct an adaptation of the Sony PlayStation game Resident Evil. The film follows on from Anderson's commercially successful treatment of another game - Mortal Kombat - three years ago. Having filmed his much-hyped but unloved debut Shopping in the UK, Anderson relocated to Hollywood, where he was responsible for the rabid sci-fi actioner Event Horizon.

 Despite the poor performance of When the Sky Falls earlier this year, another film based on the life of Irish journalist Veronica Guerin is already in the pipeline. Entitled Chasing the Dragon, the film will be powered by the heavyweight team of producer Jerry Bruckheimer and director Joel Schumacher. Asked what attracted him to the project, Schumacher (creator of the likes of Batman Forever and 8mm) was his usual bullish self: "Veronica Guerin was a totally unique human being, a complex character who took on the Dublin drug barons and paid the price of her life." And what, pray tell, was her key appeal? "She was young and sexy and the mother of a small boy," points out Joel.

 Kathy Bates has signed on to co-star opposite Kevin Costner in Universal's supernatural thriller Dragonfly. Bates - who won an Oscar for her turn in Misery - will play the next-door neighbour to a troubled doctor (Costner) who believes his dead wife is communicating with him through his more sickly patients.

 It's been confirmed that Luke Wilson is to star opposite Reese Witherspoon in the MGM comedy Legally Blonde. Prior to that, Luke will be starring with his brother Owen in The Royal Tannenbaums, the next film from Rushmore creator Wes Anderson.

 According to latest reports the Green Goblin is up for grabs again. The role of the villain in Sam Raimi's hotly anticipated Spiderman role was expected to fall to John Malkovich, after Nic Cage turned it down. Now Ain't It Cool news quotes a "reliable" source who says that Malkovich bailed out a week ago. Tim Roth and Willem Dafoe have been mooted as possible replacements.

Writing in the New York Daily News, Jack Mathews damned it as "political pandering" and "a knee-jerk response to the recent political furore". There was a danger, he claimed, that such actions "could turn theatre operators into freelance moral guardians".  In keeping with his heroic image, Robert Redford has stepped in to save a forlorn and decrepit cinema from the developer's wrecking-ball. The actor is determined to protect Santa Monica's Aero movie house - a venue he attended regularly as a child - from demolition. Redford plans to turn it into a showcase for independent cinema.  British director Paul Anderson has received the green light to script and direct an adaptation of the Sony PlayStation game Resident Evil. The film follows on from Anderson's commercially successful treatment of another game - Mortal Kombat - three years ago. Having filmed his much-hyped but unloved debut Shopping in the UK, Anderson relocated to Hollywood, where he was responsible for the rabid sci-fi actioner Event Horizon.  Despite the poor performance of When the Sky Falls earlier this year, another film based on the life of Irish journalist Veronica Guerin is already in the pipeline. Entitled Chasing the Dragon, the film will be powered by the heavyweight team of producer Jerry Bruckheimer and director Joel Schumacher. Asked what attracted him to the project, Schumacher (creator of the likes of Batman Forever and 8mm) was his usual bullish self: "Veronica Guerin was a totally unique human being, a complex character who took on the Dublin drug barons and paid the price of her life." And what, pray tell, was her key appeal? "She was young and sexy and the mother of a small boy," points out Joel.  Kathy Bates has signed on to co-star opposite Kevin Costner in Universal's supernatural thriller Dragonfly. Bates - who won an Oscar for her turn in Misery - will play the next-door neighbour to a troubled doctor (Costner) who believes his dead wife is communicating with him through his more sickly patients.  It's been confirmed that Luke Wilson is to star opposite Reese Witherspoon in the MGM comedy Legally Blonde. Prior to that, Luke will be starring with his brother Owen in The Royal Tannenbaums, the next film from Rushmore creator Wes Anderson.  According to latest reports the Green Goblin is up for grabs again. The role of the villain in Sam Raimi's hotly anticipated Spiderman role was expected to fall to John Malkovich, after Nic Cage turned it down. Now Ain't It Cool news quotes a "reliable" source who says that Malkovich bailed out a week ago. Tim Roth and Willem Dafoe have been mooted as possible replacements.

fields.headline: The way you see it
fields.trailText: Should 4-4-1-1 stay or should it go?
fields.body:
Should 4-4-1-1 stay or should it go?

One topic dominates the mailbag today: England v Germany. But despite our Euro 2000 victory, many of you are nervous; play it safe Keegan, you plead; stick to 4-4-1-1 - after all, it worked against France didn't it?

The most lucid argument of the "play it safe" brigade comes from Peter Lee. "It seems inconceivable to me that a formation and a way of playing that was good enough for the World and European Champions is not good enough for a very poor German side," he thunders.

"The German midfield is probably the strongest part of their team and it will overwhelm an England midfield playing 4-4-2 with Scholes playing behind the front two and Barmby and Beckham playing out wide," he continues, glossing over the fact that England won in Charleroi - albeit unconvincingly - by playing 4-4-2.

But that doesn't deter Peter. "Surely we must stick to the formation that got us a draw in Paris, with the notable exception of playing our one decent left-footed crosser on the left wing," he says, suggesting a team of: Seaman; Neville, Adams, Keown, Barry; Mcmanaman, Beckham, Ince, Le Saux; Scholes; Cole.

Goodbye Wembley

Elsewhere, many of you shed a nostalgic tear for the demise of England's national stadium. "I really enjoyed Frank Keating's article on Wembley, and it brought to mind some of my favourite memories," says John McGrath. So does he start reminiscing about his favourite goal and game? Well, not exactly

"To be more original, I thought of two of the best flags and banners that I've seen," he says, throwing a curveball into the proceedings. "The first was at Wembley at the 1984 FA Cup Final: 'Victory to Everton and the Miners'. The second was: 'Mandy Jordache is Innocent'. The latter was huge, but the people holding it outside Wembley appeared deadly serious about the plight of a soap character - and I don't think it was post-modern irony either!"

Meanwhile Andy Carter's Wembley tribute is simple, but heartfelt. "Let's give the old lady a fitting send off - and win in style," he says, as the nation nods its head in agreement.

webTitle: European court overturns ban on tobacco advertising

fields.headline: European court overturns ban on tobacco advertising
fields.trailText: A European Union ban on tobacco advertising was today ruled unlawful by the European court of justice. The 1998 directive had called for the phasing out of all tobacco advertising and sponsorship by 2006, but the EU's highest court ruled that the commission had "no power" to introduce the ban under single market legislation.
fields.body:
A European Union ban on tobacco advertising was today ruled unlawful by the European court of justice. The 1998 directive had called for the phasing out of all tobacco advertising and sponsorship by 2006, but the EU's highest court ruled that the commission had "no power" to introduce the ban under single market legislation.

The court's ruling followed a demand by the German government to cancel the directive, and a complaint by Imperial Tobacco Group plc and other tobacco producers, referred by the UK courts.

The court said the directive should not have been adopted as an EU internal market directive aimed at removing market distortions. Germany and the producers argued it was a public health measure.

The commission chose to use its single market provisions partly because EU laws on the single market only require a qualified majority of member states to approve them. Germany and Austria had opposed the original directive banning tobacco advertising.

The commission is expected to attempt another ban under health and safety issues before the end of the year.

John Carlyle, executive director of public affairs of the Tobacco Manufacturers Association, said: "We welcome this judgment as we have always believed that the European Commission and the British government were acting illegally.

"We now hope that the government will talk with the industry and we look forward to talking to them.

"We still believe that we have the right to communicate with our adult customers to sell a legally available product and we will fight to retain that right."

The court found that a publicity ban did not do away with distortions of competition between EU member states, which could be because of different production costs.

"The court estimates that a general ban on advertising for a large range of forms (posters, umbrellas, ash trays, hotel objects, film trailers) does not contribute to easing trade in the products," it also said.

However, the court noted that some measures partially banning certain forms of publicity and sponsorship could be acceptable as an internal market measure.

Different national rules, such as a ban on sponsorship in certain member states, can distort competition by determining where a sports competition may take place and affect the firms involved, it said.

The publishing industry, as well as tobacco companies, had been arguing for years that Brussels had no legal basis for attempting to legislate across the EU on advertising.

webTitle: Cameron's space homework: how far will he go?

fields.headline: Cameron's space homework: how far will he go?
fields.trailText: Rumours are circulating in Hollywood over the precise extent of James Cameron's commitment to two upcoming sci-fi projects
fields.body:
Rumours are circulating in Hollywood over the precise extent of James Cameron's commitment to two upcoming sci-fi projects. That Cameron has taken his homework seriously is well-established. Whether he is prepared to take the giant leap into space itself is more open to question.

In prepping the two projects - a space-travel picture and a book he is co-writing about Mars - the Titanic director has flung himself into his research and recently flew aboard the Russian Ilushin-76 jet (a cousin to Nasa's "vomit comet") that is used to familiarise cosmonauts with weightlessness.

But a further report in the New York Times suggested that Cameron was also planning a trip out to the Russian space-station Mir and had already undergone physical tests in order to qualify for the mission.

Untrue, says Rae Sanchini, president of Cameron's production company. "He is diligently pursuing every aspect of the cosmonaut experience", Sanchini told reporters, but she went on to dampen down the space-trip speculation. "I can't say the idea of going into space wouldn't appeal to him tremendously. It's just that right now he's earthbound and busy working on these projects."

webTitle: Norton and Williams in line for 'Smoochie'

fields.headline: Norton and Williams in line for 'Smoochie'
fields.trailText: Robin Williams and Edward Norton are under consideration for the two lead roles in Death to Smoochie, a satire on the TV industry to be directed by Danny DeVito
fields.body:
Two very different actors - Robin Williams and Edward Norton - are under consideration for the two lead roles in Death to Smoochie, a satire on the TV industry to be directed by Danny DeVito. Williams is already reported to be deep in talks with the film's backers, Warners, while Norton abruptly has a window in his schedule after bailing out of Hart's War, following apparent differences with co-star Bruce Willis.

According to Variety, Warners are eager to sign up Norton (currently vacationing in Africa) for the title role. Norton would play a clean-cut actor who achieves instant fame romping around in a blue rhino suit on a kids' TV show.

Williams would co-star as Smoochie's snubbed predecessor, a childrens' entertainer sacked from the show who vows revenge. The film is scripted by Adam Resnick and is scheduled to begin shooting in January.

Whether the producers can lure Norton aboard is open to question. Williams, however, is reputedly poised to sign on the dotted line. In the meantime, the winsome comic is about to begin shooting the Fox thriller One Hour Photo and is apparently still considering playing Liberace in a movie biopic.

A few months back a supposedly disillusioned Williams (scarred by the response to flops like Bicentennial Man and Patch Adams) hinted at a retirement from movies. His current work-rate suggests he was merely having us on.

webTitle: Baldwin lands Hopkins for devilish debut

fields.headline: Baldwin lands Hopkins for devilish debut
fields.trailText: Alec Baldwin is set to make his debut as a director on a remake of the 1941 drama The Devil and Daniel Webster, heving secured the star services of Anthony Hopkins
fields.body:
Alec Baldwin is set to make his debut as a director after securing the star services of Anthony Hopkins. The pair will collaborate on The Devil and Daniel Webster, a remake of the 1941 drama by William Dieterle. The project has been a long-term labour of love for Baldwin, who has been battling to roll the cameras since 1992.

Based on the novel by Stephen Vincent Benet, The Devil and Daniel Webster tells the tale of Jabez Stone, a hack writer who sells his soul in order to gain ten years of literary acclaim.

When the Devil comes to claim his spoils, Stone recruits a Clarence Darrow-esque lawyer by the name of Daniel Webster to defend him. Baldwin's version updates the action to Manhattan's literati scene, and will star Hopkins as the lawyer. As well as directing, Baldwin will take the role of the hapless writer, though the (apparently female) Devil has yet to be cast.

Baldwin and Hopkins had previously struck up a solid working relationship on the set of David Mamet's survivalist drama The Edge. "Tony is my favourite actor," a delighted Baldwin told the Hollywood Reporter. "When he said yes, I thought: How could I be any luckier?"

The Devil and Daniel Webster looks set to be the latest in a growing sub-genre of satanic-themed pictures. Already poised for release are Lost Souls (in which Ben Chaplin finds himself possessed by Mephisto), Little Nicky, starring Adam Sandler and Harvey Keitel, and Bedazzled, which casts Liz Hurley as a posh-girl Satan.

fields.headline: Netscape relaunches UK operation
fields.trailText: 10.45am: AOL subsidiary Netscape has ditched its Netcenter moniker and today relaunched its UK operation as Netscape.co.uk. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
AOL subsidiary Netscape has ditched its Netcenter moniker and today relaunched its UK operation as Netscape.co.uk.

The new portal is part of a global strategy to develop strong regional portals under one name.

Netcenter never really took off in the UK because of the name's US spelling and the fact that Netscape did not even own either the US or English spelling of the domain name.

The new-look website is neater and better coordinated with Netscape's core services - its browser software. In addition to featuring Netscape applications such as webmail, the site contains content from external partners such as CBS MarketWatch, Reuters and ZDNet.

The development of the UK and other seven European sites (Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain and Sweden) is being overseen by Patrice Schneider, who in May was appointed European general manager at International Netcenter.

While the European office of International Netcenter/Netscape.com is based in London, it is operated as a separate business to the AOL-run internet service provider Netscape Online, and staff are based at a separate office.

In the past few months, Netscape.co.uk has been recruiting staff on the content and business development side of the business and talking to potential partners about commercial deals.

fields.headline: New Middle East ceasefire called
fields.trailText: Israel and the Palestinians have agreed a fresh ceasefire in the strife-torn West Bank and Gaza strip after peace talks broke down in acrimony early today.
fields.body:
Israel and the Palestinians have agreed a fresh ceasefire in the strife-torn West Bank and Gaza strip after peace talks broke down in acrimony early today.

Israeli officials said Palestinian president Yasser Arafat had made a verbal agreement to halt the bloodshed. It is the fourth ceasefire since violence erupted in the region a week ago; three previous truces have collapsed quickly. There were no immediate reports of major clashes this morning, though on previous days street battles have usually erupted later in the day.

An army spokesman said that, during the night, the commander of Israel's central command, Major-General Yitzhak Eitan, had met senior officials of the Palestinian security services. "It was agreed at the meeting to stop the violence, disturbances and shooting incidents at confrontation points between the two sides," a statement said.

Meanwhile, the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, will try and pick up the pieces after her failed attempt to broker an agreement to end the violence.

After initial optimism, a marathon session of talks in Paris between the Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak and Mr Arafat broke up without agreement.

At one point, Mr Arafat briefly stormed out of the meeting, returning only after Mrs Albright persuaded him to do so. Mr Barak has refused so far to attend a second round of talks in Egypt, brokered by President Hosni Mubarak. Mr Arafat held talks with the Egyptian leader this morning, and Mrs Albright is also heading for the Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheik.

The Palestinian leader was angered by the Israeli and American refusal to set up an international inquiry into the recent bloodshed in Israel and the Palestinian areas. UN secretary general Kofi Annan, who joined the Paris talks late in the day, agreed to work with the Americans to devise a formula acceptable to both the Israelis and the Palestinians for an investigation.

The session finally ended at dawn with Mr Barak saying he saw no point in going to Egypt later in the day as planned for more talks. He and Mr Arafat predictably blamed each other for the impasse, as they have for the week of violence which has wracked the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Arab towns in Israel, killing at least 66 people, most of them Palestinians.

The stumbling block was Israel's rejection of the Palestinian demand for an international inquiry. Israel does not want any other foreign powers besides the United States, its traditional ally, to join the process. But the Palestinians want experts representing other powers.

Israel's acting foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, said in Israel that an international inquiry would have involved too many parties at a time when Israel hoped to focus on reaching a final peace deal with the Palestinians within two weeks. A senior US official said the Americans still hoped to pin down an agreement to end the violence.

In the Paris talks, Israel offered to pull back tanks and personnel carriers from forward positions on the West Bank and Gaza, according to Israeli and Palestinian officials. Mr Arafat was willing to order his followers to avoid sites of recent clashes.

In Paris, Mrs Albright held two rounds of separate talks with each of the leaders before convening the three-way session. She had urged Mr Barak and Mr Arafat to return to the "psychology of peacemaking."

The worst violence in the West Bank and Gaza broke out after a 28 September visit to Jerusalem's Al Aqsa mosque compound by right-wing Israeli politician Ariel Sharon, escorted by hundreds of security personnel.

fields.headline: EMI and Warner Music call off merger
fields.trailText: 10am: EMI and Warner Music have abandoned their £14bn merger after they failed to convince EU regulators that the deal should go ahead, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
EMI and Warner Music have abandoned their £14bn merger after they failed to convince EU regulators that the deal should go ahead.

The shock decision was taken following press reports that EMI had offered to sell Virgin Records and Warner Music was ready to offload its Warner Chappell publishing arm in order to get the dea throughl. Analysts said the proposed sell-offs would seriously damage the value of the deal.

An EU spokesperson confirmed that EMI had withdrawn its application for approval of the meger. EMI and Warner say they will continue to hold negotiations about a deal.

Eric Nicoli, chairman of EMI, said: "The withdrawal of our application allows additional time to reassess regulators' concerns and to pursue solutions simultaneously in Europe and the US.

"We have been, and will continue to be, flexible in responding to the European Commission's concerns. However any concessions that are ultimately made must be consistent with shareholder value objectives."

All eyes will now turn to the proposed merger between AOL and Warner Music's parent company, Time Warner, which is expected to get the go-ahead from the EU competition commission. The regulators' main concern was possible control of the internet music market.

fields.headline: Teamtalk.com signs with AOL UK
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Football community site Teamtalk.com has signed a strategic content deal with AOL UK to distribute its content across AOL and CompuServe's member areas, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Football community site Teamtalk.com has signed a strategic content deal with AOL UK to distribute its content across AOL and CompuServe's member areas.

Teamtalk's network of over 60 in-house and 180 external reporters will provide club-specific football news which will be co-branded across AOL's Clubs Corner and CompuServe's Sports Channel, providing members with daily news, comments and previews about their favourite club. Bill Wilson, chief executive at Teamtalk, said: "Not only will this enhance Teamtalk's reputation, but it will also widen our fan base and increase our global footprint."

Teamtalk, which was set up in 1988, covers football, rugby league and union, golf, cricket, tennis, horse and greyhound racing, and has one of the largest user bases among UK sports websites. Teamtalk floated on AIM in April this year raising funds of £45m, however, its share price has flat-lined around the 80p mark since the market slowdown earlier this year.

webTitle: BA invites pitches for online venture

fields.headline: BA invites pitches for online venture
fields.trailText: 8am: British Airways has approached a number of agencies this week asking them to pitch for a new online venture, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
British Airways has approached a number of advertising agencies this week asking them to pitch for a new online venture.

Ogilvy & Mather, HHCL & Partners, and M&C Saatchi, BA's agency of record, have been asked to compete for the business, thought to be worth in the region of £6m. Miles Calcraft Briginshaw Duffy was also approached but declined to pitch due to an existing conflict.

The new venture, known only under the codename BA ISP, will be an internet portal servicing the needs of club card holders.

A source at one of the pitching agencies said:"The site will not be BA branded but it will be part owned by the airline."

The agencies will all present to BA this week with a decision expected shortly.

fields.headline: Where's the pride?
fields.standfirst:
Joy Francis, who yesterday quit as editor of black women's glossy magazine Pride, tells MediaGuardian why she left.
Pride editor quits blaming lack of support
fields.trailText: 8am: Joy Francis, who yesterday quit as editor of black women's glossy magazine Pride, tells MediaGuardian why she left.
fields.body:
Two weeks ago I became the fifth female editor to leave Pride magazine under less than satisfactory circumstances in just four years.

I was forced to take the silver medal in the editor-for-the-shortest-time category behind the holder Clare Gorham (she left after two issues). I managed to endure two months and produced three well-received issues including this month's, which is the biggest ever.

As Britain's only glossy black women's lifestyle magazine, Pride has no rivals. Close to its 10th birthday, it holds a prime position on the newsstands - often wedged between Elle and New Woman. Yet it seems to have a credibility problem. When I said yes to the job after two months of intense negotiation in July, the response from fellow journalists left me feeling as if I should check myself into The Priory.

'Are you sure you know what you're doing?' exclaimed a journalist friend of mine. 'Do you realise that the job should be advertised with a health warning?' another declared cryptically. You exaggerate, I said. Now I'm not so sure. The lack of editorial vision and a consistent commitment to BBT (Black British Talent) are behind my decision to call it quits. There is more to black British women than the salacious, sexy and stereotypical. Their leisure activities stretch beyond fawning over American R'n'B celebrities, tending to their hair and gossiping.

Yes, these items have their place, but as part of a broader, culturally diverse and exciting editorial landscape which all women's magazines are failing to embrace. Black women are earning more money, gaining more qualifications and taking more cultural risks. They read novels (not just Terry Macmillan or Alice Walker), listen to diverse music including pap-pop and indie, travel to countries other than Jamaica, Ghana and the US, and are looking for their soul mate.

Trying to produce a 120 (and now 160) page magazine with five editorial staff (two part-time) without the ability to plan ahead more than a month is ridiculous. I had more bylines than my freelancers. Yet assisted by the overworked but sterling staff, I managed to get an exclusive with Guy Ritchie on his 'there aren't any good black actors row' which was picked up as a news lead in the Evening Standard.

And this month we pulled off a coup by convincing top designer Wale Adeyemi to design a breast cancer awareness tee-shirt, the MOBO Awards to sponsor it and 25 talented black British celebrities to model them with a two-and-a-half week deadline. Oh, and we got singing sensation Kelis to exclusively reveal that she hates the white rap megastar, Eminem, and finds him talented but demented.

Letters from black, Asian and white women arrived expressing support and an appreciation of the editorial variety - from sexual health to meditation. And former readers appeared to be slowly coming back to the fold.

Pride has a tough job. It is catering for a broad spectrum of black women from 25 to 34 years old. It exists because the zillions of women's magazines, more recently Bare and Nova, are still colour blind (apart from Mel B and Naomi Campbell).

So I was less than happy to be faced with a male publisher who wanted to dictate the editorial terms of reference and backtrack on editorial commitments. But to be told by a male MD that 'he sets the tone' of the magazine was bordering on the farcical and led to the question 'Well why am I here?'

They have yet to provide an answer. And until they do, the editor revolving door syndrome will continue.

 Joy Francis is the former editor of Pride magazine and director of the Creative Collective media consultancy.

fields.headline: Emap poaches former BBC music chief
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Emap has lured former head of BBC music entertainment, Trevor Dann, to be Performance Network's managing director for pop. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
Emap has lured former head of BBC music entertainment, Trevor Dann, to be Performance Network's managing director for pop.

Kiss FM managing director Mark Story will also become managing director for dance, while former Kerrang! editor editor Dave Henderson has been recruited as managing director of rock.

The appointments are designed to help Emap focus on its cross-media brand strategy.

Mr Dann is expected to take responsibility for developing masthead television from Emap magazines.

fields.headline: ITV moves Millionaire to combat BBC1 changes
fields.trailText: 9.15am: The biggest change to ITV's line-up for the week BBC1 launches its 10pm news is the move of Ross Kemp drama Without Motive from Monday to Sunday, displacing Cold Feet, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The biggest change to ITV's line-up for the week BBC1 launches its 10pm news is the move of Ross Kemp drama Without Motive from Monday to Sunday, displacing Cold Feet.

The third episode of Without Motive will now go out at 9.10pm on Sunday 15, with the launch of the third series of Cold Feet expected to be delayed for four weeks until the Kemp drama completes its six-part run.

BBC1's new post-9pm schedule of One Foot in the Grave and The Royle Family will face fierce competition on its Monday 16 debut, with a 60-minute Who Wants to be a Millionaire? moving into the Without Motive slot.

On Tuesday 17 ITV is replacing Peak Practice with A Touch of Frost repeat at 9pm; while on Thursday 19 the 10pm factual show Dynasties is giving way to Andrew Morton documentary The Queen.

webTitle: Virgin poised to buy back music label

fields.headline: Virgin poised to buy back music label
fields.trailText: 8.45am: Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group is poised to make a shock £1bn swoop for the Virgin music label, as EU regulators pick apart the EMI and Warner Music merger. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group is poised to make a shock £1bn swoop for the Virgin music label, as EU regulators pick apart the EMI and Warner Music merger.

The multi-millionaire entrepreneur has said he would be interested in taking back the label he sold to EMI for $1bn in 1992 to shore up his debt-ridden Virgin Atlantic airline.

The speculation follows reports that EMI has offered to sell its Virgin arm to get EU clearance for its £14bn joint venture.

A source close to Branson's organisation said Virgin will wait for the verdict on the merger before deciding on a bid, although the group would be interested in buying back the label. Many ex-Virgin Records employees still work for the Virgin Group.

"Given the way the competition commission negotiations have gone, I don't think any other major labels could buy the company, which narrows the field down. Branson knows the business backwards and would not run into regulatory problems," said the source.

Virgin will face competition from US teenage pop label Jive Records, which said finding the money for a deal would "not be a problem". The label is home to top acts such as Britney Spears and 'Nsync, and is interested in acquiring Virgin artists such as the Spice Girls.

Bertelsmann, the German media giant, could also bid for the company as it tries to push its BMG label to the forefront of the world music industry.

Meanwhile, the EU has reconvened its mergers advisory committee to reconsider the deal in light of the latest concessions offered by EMI and Warner Music. The deadline for a decision is October 18.

webTitle: Paddington crash: station silent in tribute

fields.headline: Paddington crash: station silent in tribute
fields.standfirst: Interactive guide to how the trains crashed
fields.trailText: Paddington station was quiet today, as prayers, flowers and a poignant one-minute silence marked the first anniversary of the rail crash which claimed 31 lives.
fields.body:
Paddington station was quiet today, as prayers, flowers and a poignant one-minute silence marked the first anniversary of the rail crash which claimed 31 lives.

Survivors of the two-train smash gathered at Paddington station in west London for the silence, which took place at 8.11am.

That was the moment on 5 October last year when a Thames Trains' turbo crashed almost head-on with a London-bound Great Western train at Ladbroke Grove in west London.

As well as the loss of 31 lives, more than 400 people were injured in the crash, the worst in terms of fatalities since the December 1988 Clapham rail disaster.

While a silence was being observed at Paddington, the Bishop of Kensington, the Rt Rev Michael Colclough, was offering support and prayers for those attending a private ceremony close to the crash site.

Great Western cancelled today's 6.03am Cheltenham-London service, the same time as the one that was in the crash, as a mark of respect. Flowers were being laid at Reading station, in Berkshire, and at other stations on the Cheltenham to London route. A further minute's silence was being observed, with prayers being said at the crash site at noon.

Mr Colclough is preaching at a 4pm memorial service at Westminster Central Hall, the venue for the public inquiry into the crash.

The bishop was asking the injured and bereaved to remember those who died "with love and thankfulness ... not to bring back the past, but to set themselves to the future."

The victims of the crash, who are critical of the pace of safety improvements, were led by the badly-injured Pam Warren, 33, founder of the Paddington Survivors Group.

The group is particularly incensed that the Government, backed by an official report, is choosing a less-sophisticated and vastly cheaper form of train protection, the Train Protection Warning System, for nationwide introduction.

"One year on, my main thought is how horrible it is that nothing much has changed in rail safety," said Mrs Warren, from Reading, who has had to wear a plastic face mask for months because of her severe burns.

Survivors say the costly Automatic Train Protection system, due to be introduced gradually, should be installed at once, as was recommended after the 1988 Clapham rail disaster.

A public inquiry into train protection systems is continuing in London. Part two of the Paddington public inquiry, headed by Lord Cullen, starts later this month and is due to be concluded by the end of the year.

webTitle: Virgin Net opts out of ISP market

fields.headline: Virgin Net parts company with NTL
fields.trailText: 8.45am: Virgin Net is expected to complete its divorce from NTL, owner of 49% of Virgin Net, by the end of next week, a move that will take Virgin out of the ISP market, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Virgin Net is expected to complete its divorce from NTL, owner of 49% of Virgin Net, by the end of next week, a move that will take Virgin out of the ISP market.

NTL is understood to be paying around £100m, of which 10% will be in cash and the remainder in NTL common stock.

The deal will leave Virgin in sole control of the Virgin Net content and commerce business, while NTL will take on all the dial-up ISP subscribers, of which there are believed to be around 500,000. Overnight NTL will become one of the leading ISPs in the UK - NTL reckons the Virgin Net subscribers will take its ISP user tally to 1m, which would thrust it into third place in the UK ISP stakes.

After the two have gone their separate ways, Virgin Net will exist only as an entertainment portal, although it's likely to take the best part of a year before the consumer branding is changed and Virgin Net subscribers are fully migrated into NTL's ISP. Sources have suggested that the imminent parting of ways was the reason why Virgin Net has recently put its plans for unmetered access on hold, and that this plan will simply be rolled into NTL's unmetered package, NTLWorld.

NTL and Virgin Net announced their proposed separation at the start of August, almost a year after the development was first internally mooted at Virgin Net. The two parties have worked together on Virgin Net since the end of 1996 when it was agreed that NTL would provide the backbone and Virgin would develop the front-end, the content and handle all the marketing for the ISP. However, rumours started speculating about a year ago that Virgin Net was not happy with the quality of the service provided by NTL. Reports in the press at the time suggested a spat over plans to float Virgin Net, which was being pushed by NTL, and talked about a strained relationship and dual-sourcing (using two different backbone providers) using Cable & Wireless' network.

Since then the Virgin Group has developed a more integrated new media strategy and set up a separate business, Virgin.com, which acts as a portal for the whole group. The remnants of Virgin Net will be tied much tighter into Virgin.com. webTitle: SCi bags Great Escape game rights

fields.headline: SCi Entertainment bags The Great Escape game rights
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Computer game publisher SCi Entertainment is moving from match-making to jail-breaking with its latest venture, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Computer game publisher SCi Entertainment is moving from match-making to jail-breaking with its latest venture.

The company, which recently launched an online blind date service, has acquired the interactive and computer game rights to cult film The Great Escape from MGM studios of the US. The sixties action-adventure classic described a real-life escape attempt from a prisoner of war camp in Germany during the Second World War.

The game of the movie, which starred Steve McQueen and Charles Bronson, will be released in 2002 for next generation consoles such as PlayStation 2. It will be divided into three phases, from gathering escape equipment, to staging the break-out and then getting to a neutral country.

Jane Cavanagh, chief executive of SCi, said: "This is a classic movie and a tremendous brand with a strong storyline that will allow us to develop an exciting series of games that will be instantly recognizable at retail outlets.

"We are determined to deliver Triple A titles with excellent gameplay to the marke. Coupled with strong brands, this is the combination that will ensure our continued strength and growth."

Ms Cavanagh is negotiating with MGM over further link ups as it attempts to build up its catalogue of games brands. The company already holds the rights to spin-offs of the Thunderbirds TV series and Michael Caine classic The Italian Job. SCi plans to spend £2.4bn on developing the Great Escape game.

David Bishop, president of MGM Home Entertainment, said: "Given the context of the movie and the overall flavor of the story, we particularly wanted the rights to be allocated to a UK interactive games publisher."

In order to appeal to the lucrative German market, SCi is planning to emphasise the role of playing the prison guards in the game.

webTitle: Business: News Corp joins Russian imbroglio

fields.headline: News Corp joins Russian imbroglio
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is interested in buying Russia's biggest and most influential independent media group, according to reports in Moscow, though any deal would be controversial.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Moscow and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is interested in buying Russia's biggest and most influential independent media group, according to reports in Moscow, though any deal would be controversial.

The Media-most company of exiled mogul Vladimir Gusinsky is at the centre of a bitter battle for control of its assets with the Kremlin and Mr Gusinsky's main creditor, Gazprom, Russia's gas monopoly. It includes Russia's biggest private television channel, NTV, cable TV operations, a Moscow radio station, and a daily newspaper.

Rem Vyakhirev, the powerful head of Gazprom, Russia's biggest company which is part-owned by the state, said he was insisting on taking over Media-most and selling it on unless Mr Gusinsky came up with the $211m (£144m) it owes and a further $272m due for repayment next year.

"We are demanding the return of the debt. This is not politics," said Mr Vyakhirev in Delhi, where he is accompanying President Putin on an official visit. "If they can't pay the money, we'll take the Media-most shares and sell them to someone who will pay more."

An western media holding company was showing an interest, he added. Gazprom sources told the Kommersant newspaper the prospective buyer was News Corp, which had shown its interest "orally and in written form".

Martin Pompadur, an executive vice-president of News Corporation in charge of European operations, was understood to be on business in Russia this week, but News Corp declined to comment on what it called speculation.

There is no sizeable foreign ownership of the media in Russia as the sector is heavily indebted and barely profitable. A foreign takeover of such a substantial group could cause political problems for Mr Putin, with communists and nationalists complaining of the country's second biggest TV channel becoming anti-Russian.

Mr Gusinsky fled Russia for Spain in July after his offices were raided by heavily armed paramilitary police and he was briefly jailed. Criminal charges against him were suddenly dropped in return for his selling out to Gazprom. This agreement he now says was signed, under duress and at gunpoint.

Dmitry Ostalsky, a spokesman in Moscow for Mr Gusinsky, said he knew nothing of the proposed Murdoch bid. "We've got nothing against western investors, but, of course, this is not normal because Gazprom does not own Media-most."

Mr Vyakhirev said that under the deal signed on July 20, the gas company agreed to take on all of Media-most's debt and pay Mr Gusinsky a further $300m.

The signing of that agreement was the prelude to Mr Gusinsky's flight to Spain. Three weeks ago a row erupted in public between Gazprom and Media-most when Mr Gusinsky repudiated it and produced a confidential appendix, signed by a government minister, promising him his freedom and the dropping of all charges as a trade-off for surrendering the business.

NTV television has become the president's most formidable and most influential critic. The months-long battle for control of Media-most has raised fears in the West for press freedoms in Russia.

webTitle: Business: Ex-Sky chief pulls role at Ripcord

fields.headline: Ex-Sky chief pulls role at Ripcord
fields.trailText: Former BSkyB boss Mark Booth is to join the board of a US wireless technology company following the first major investment by one of his new interests, Softbank UK Ventures.
fields.body:
Former BSkyB boss Mark Booth is to join the board of a US wireless technology company following the first major investment by one of his new interests, Softbank UK Ventures.

Mr Booth and fellow SBUKV partner David Sola will become non-executive directors of Seattle-based Ripcord Systems after SBUKV invested $14m (£9.6m) of its $450m fund in the fledgling firm.

Ripcord raised a total of $16.5m from the fundraising round to secure a $40m valuation. The new funds will be used for European, American and Asian expansion.

The company plans to move its headquarters to London to be closer to the world-leading European wireless telecommunications sector.

"Europe is someway ahead of the more fragmented US wireless market and Ripcords products are far more saleable over here," Mr Sola said.

Ripcord has developed technology that enables mobile workforces to access securely information in their company's mainframe while they are out and about using net-enabled wireless devices. Marketing consultancy Frost & Sullivan predict this market will be worth $15.6bn in Europe by 2005.

SBUKV was introduced to Ripcord by a non-executive director and friend of Mr Booth's called Herbert Scholsser, a former chief executive of American broadcaster NBC.

Softbank, the large Japanese internet investment company, and ePartners, a vehicle funded by Rupert Murdoch and managed by Mr Booth, set up SBUKV in March at a time when venture money was pouring into Europe.

Mr Sola said that the time SBUKV had taken to make its first substantial investment did not signify that too much money was chasing too few opportunities.

"There is a lot of money around and some people are having a hard time finding places to put it, but we're seeing a steady stream of deals," he said.

"There are a lot of very impressive UK technology firms looking to be globalised."

fields.headline: Barclay brothers bid for Express
fields.trailText: The Barclay brothers have had an offer for the Express newspaper titles, understood to be £75m, rejected during negotiations with Labour peer Lord Hollick.
fields.body:
The Barclay brothers have had an offer for the Express newspaper titles, understood to be £75m, rejected during negotiations with Labour peer Lord Hollick.

United News and Media is believed to have told twins David and Frederick that it is seeking "double" - £150m - for the ailing papers which need substantial investment.

The possibility of the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star being sold to the Barclays will alarm Downing Street, with the Barclays likely to adopt a more independent editorial line or even one sympathetic to the Tories.

The Barclays, advised by former Sunday Times editor Andrew Neil, have indicated that they want to expand their newspaper portfolio and already own four titles, including the Scotsman and Sunday Business.

United and the Barclays declined to comment yesterday but the offer is thought to have been made during recent weeks after Lord Hollick opened the books. "The gap is too wide at the moment so don't think anything is imminent until the price comes down," said an executive close to the discussions.

Another executive said the Barclays were effectively being treated as the preferred bidder and claimed no other company was in the running despite speculation about Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed.

Negotiations are believed to centre on the titles and exclude the group's internet sites and Blackfriars headquarters in central London. A routine meeting of United's board is scheduled for today.

Sales of the Express hover just above 1m a day, those of its Sunday stablemate a little below 1m while the Star sells about 500,000 in the UK.

Lord Hollick turned the Express papers from staunch supporters of the Tories at the last election to new Labour enthusiasts, though he has fallen out with No 10 recently after a huge TV merger was blocked.

The titles recently have taken a robust line with the government, campaigning for a £10 rise in pensions and calling for the head of dome minister Lord Falconer.

After his TV plans were thwarted, Lord Hollick agreed the £1.75bn sale of the Meridian, HTV and Anglia franchises to rival Granada and made clear he intends to concentrate on business publishing, market research, exhibitions and the internet.

The Scotsman has taken a more critical approach to the Edinburgh establishment under the Barclays who are also anti-euro while the Express is a vocal supporter of the single currency.

fields.headline: PR Week round-up
fields.trailText: October 5: Coca-Cola's UK PR account is up for grabs.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola's UK PR account is up for grabs. The company wants to appoint a single agency to supersede the current two-layered system that uses Cohn & Wolfe to handle Coke's consumer PR and Clarion Communications for corporate. The news comes just weeks after the announcement from Britvic that the Pepsico and Tango briefs are up for grabs.

3I has appointed Burson-Mastellar as its global PR agency, on annual fees estimated to be £500,000, knocking incumbent Shandwyck off the top spot.

Superdrug has hired Cohn & Wolfe, who beat off competition from incumbent Lexis, the Red Consultancy and Jackie Cooper.

The Clydesdale and Yorkshire banks, both owned by the National Australia Group, want to hire a PR agency for political lobbying.

The Department of Trade & Industry has announced that Iain Hepplewhite will replace Matt Tee, who left his post as director of news six months ago. Hepplewhite joins from the Department of Culture, Media & Sport, where he has been head of news and deputy director of strategy and communications.

And Channel 4 has poached Sarah Booth from Avalon to be publicity manager for its forthcoming digital channel, E4.

webTitle: Is 'public interest' what interests the public?

fields.headline: Is 'public interest' what interests the public?
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Ever since Richard Nixon broke into a cold, grey sweat next to a fresh-faced John Kennedy forty years ago, television coverage of live presidential debates in the run-up to the elections has been more or less guaranteed across America.
fields.body:
Ever since Richard Nixon broke into a cold, grey sweat next to a fresh-faced John Kennedy forty years ago, television coverage of live presidential debates in the run-up to the elections has been more or less guaranteed across America.

Until this week, that is. Two of America's four major television networks - NBC and Fox - decided not to offer live coverage of Tuesday night's face-off between Al Gore and George W Bush. Instead of watching the first debate in what is shaping up to be the closest US presidential race since 1960, viewers were offered the chance to watch a baseball game or the premiere of Dark Angel, a new sci-fi adventure featuring a genetically enhanced prototype woman.

This decision - taken sheepishly by the National Broadcasting Corporation and with some gusto by the Rupert Murdoch-owned Fox channel - has reopened the debate about what constitutes public service broadcasting in the US. The row offers a transatlantic perspective on the industry battle between commercial organizations and government guardians as the UK debate rages on over whether the evening news should be seen at 9pm or later.

In some ways, it is difficult for outsiders to see what all the fuss is about. Most Americans can chose between 50 and 75 television channels. Even New Yorkers offered NBC's match between the local Yankees and Oakland Athletics could watch the political debate live on no fewer than eight channels.

The answer came in a blistering piece written by William Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, the US television watchdog, on the day of the planned debate. Under the headline 'Fox and NBC Renege on a Debt', Mr Kennard pointed out that the US congress had agreed to give public broadcasters extra spectrum to provide the next wave of digital television services four years ago as long as they continued to 'serve the public interest'. He estimated the commercial value of this extra air space at more than $70bn and added there was "no underestimating" the value of televised political debates.

Put simply, while America's numerous cable channels are allowed to offer as much entertainment as they want, public broadcasters are not because they receive licenses from the government to use the public airwaves.

"As trustees of the public airwaves, the networks must do more than just entertain: they must also serve the needs of citizens by facilitating an informed democratic process" wrote Mr Kennard. He ended his article in the New York Times with a warning that "in the future, the networks should remember that the public interest is far more important than their financial interest."

Fox, which does not intend to show any of the three planned presidential debates nor the vice-presidential one tonight, made a new offer as Mr Kennard's article was going to print. The station offered each of the contenders a blank half-hour slot on prime-time Friday night television at the end of October to answer the question: 'Why should Americans vote for you?'

Given that one of the participants himself - George W Bush - failed to change the allotted slot for air time agreed by the bipartisan debate committee, this plan is unlikely to change the official timetable.

Neither the FCC, nor the candidates, has replied to it. Indeed, the FCC, which has the power to revoke a network's public broadcasting license, has said little about the entire issue since the publication of Mr Kennard's article.

Television executives mutter that in the age of the internet, where there is so much choice over what to watch and when, the notion of public service is irrelevant anyway. "There's only a finite number of people who want to watch the debates," said one, who nevertheless refused to be named.

In the end, an estimated 75m people watched the first live debate of this year's election. With both NBC and Fox sticking to their plans not to offer live coverage, however, the debates could end with fewer viewers than a ball game and a Lara Croft-lookalike. If so, it will be a close-run thing to see which contestant turns grey and clammy first in the battle ahead between the government and the television industry.
