fields.headline: Serbia: the fuse is lit
fields.standfirst:
'Recognise the will of the people,' opposition tells Milosevic
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The political crisis rocking Yugoslavia was approaching a pivotal moment last night after thousands of opposition supporters pushed aside police trying to detain striking miners.
fields.body:
The political crisis rocking Yugoslavia was approaching a pivotal moment last night after thousands of opposition supporters pushed aside police trying to detain striking miners.

The confrontation at the Kolubara mine, 30 miles south of Belgrade, was sparked by Slobodan Milosevic 's attempts to regain control of a country paralysed by protests. It rebounded when hundreds of police abandoned their posts.

The failure to arrest the miners' leaders convinced the opposition that the president's grasp on the levers of state power was slipping. Buoyed by their victory, the opposition issued a fresh ultimatum calling on Mr Milosevic to recognise the will of people by 3pm today and publish the "real results" of the election.

It also urged people from all over the country to rally at the Yugoslav parliament building in Belgrade to show the extent of public opposition to what it described as "massive election fraud".

In an open letter to Mr Milosevic, Mr Kostunica last night warned that the country could plunge into armed clashes if he did not step down. "We are faced with the danger of open clashes in Serbia," he said. "We cannot accept any second round election because this would make us accomplices in the stealing of the first round votes."

Last night the federal constitutional court, responding to a chorus of opposition complaints, annulled "part" of the first round of the elections.

The Yugoslav state news agency Tanjug did not make it clear which part of the vote had been annulled, whether it would affect the overall result or if it would require a recount.

When news spread of a police raid on the giant Kolubara mine yesterday, a column of protesters sped there. A cordon of 30-40 regular police stood on a side road leading to the mine but after only one brief clash, officers gave way.

A bus carrying demonstrators from the opposition stronghold of Cacak shoved aside a police van and burst through the cordons into the strip mine complex.

The police lacked their usual determination. "Wait, slow, down, don't be nervous," one officer said. "Why should blood be spilled for nothing?"

After a further standoff, people simply flooded round the cordon. Police did not try to stop them. As sunset approached, the officers appeared to give up, withdrew from barricades and mingled with strikers inside the occupied compound.

"The battle for Serbia was won here," cried one jubilant opposition leader, Dragan Kovacevic.

"Kolubara is our Gdansk" said Professor Srbijanka Turajlic, an opposition supporter, referring to the shipyard strikes in the 1980s which sounded the death knell of communism in Poland.

Mr Kostunica, who claims outright victory in the September 24 presidential poll, raced to the mine to be greeted by tumultuous applause from an estimated 10,000 people.

"Is there anything more honest than the miners rising to defend their votes?" he told the cheering crowds. "We agreed to everything and we took part in elections under their rules. We won honestly ... Milosevic's people do not respect the constitution they had written themselves. Serbia has risen so that one man would leave."

In an earlier interview, shown on Channel 4 News, Mr Kostunica appeared confident that Mr Milosevic's powerbase was crumbling. "There are more and more signs that they [the army and police] are not going to follow Milosevic and his political party.

"The protests will go on. The most important base is the will of the people, their votes, their energy, their enthusiasm. Milosevic will be the last one to realise that he has lost this altogether."

The police action came after the state prosecutor named 11 strike leaders and two opposition politicians as suspects who should be detained "on suspicion of sabotage".

Millions in Serbia have joined the campaign of civil disobedience to force Mr Milosevic to concede that he lost the election. Few believed he would move against the miners, because the miners have the backing of the community.

The coal strike is the most serious stoppage so far in this week's campaign of civil disobedience. On Tuesday, the government threatened "special measures" against leaders of strikes and road blockades.

Among those joining the demonstrations was the Yugoslav soccer star, Savo Milosevic, formerly of Aston Villa."I came here to participate in this action, the fact that I am here speaks volumes on what I think," he said.

A further sign of the president's weakening hold on authority came when the main state-run daily newspaper in the northern province of Vojvodina declared that its editorial policy would switch from following the government line to objectivelyreporting on events.

fields.headline: Grave moral dilemmas
fields.standfirst:
Nash case shows the need for pragmatism

Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The touching photos of Adam Nash cradled in the arms of the sister whose life he has perhaps saved, have prompted not delight but panic.
fields.body:
The touching photos of Adam Nash cradled in the arms of the sister whose life he has perhaps saved, have prompted not delight but panic. It centres on three moral issues. First, was Adam created simply to cure his sister? Is this an instance of breaking the golden principle that a human being should never be used as a means to an end (however noble that end is, as in the case of saving Molly Nash's life)? The answer is unknowable - who can know the inner workings of a couple's decision to have a child? In recent years, other parents of sick children in need of transplants have made exactly the same decision as the Nashes and have had another child naturally. We cannot stop them, so what is different about the Nashes? Is not having a child to save a sibling a more valid reason than many put forward by prospective parents such as "my friend was having a baby" or "my job was boring"? The point about children is that for all the (often) stupid reasons for having them, we end up loving them so deeply.

Second, objections have been raised in the Nash case that the procedure for finding a transplant match meant that many embryos were created and presumably a large number of the rejects will be destroyed. This is a real dilemma, but one which the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority has been dealing with for over a decade; embryos end up being destroyed in the course of procedures such as in-vitro fertilisation.

Third, Adam was screened for the Fanconi anaemia, the terrible disease which afflicts his sister. But as his mother pointed out, the alternative is horrendous; if the doctors had refused to screen, she would have had to carry the baby until a test at 18 weeks revealed whether it had the disease and then it would have been terminated. That can not be ethically superior. Much of the alarm triggered by Adam Nash is couched in terms of "slippery slopes" and the "thin end of the wedge". This response is about fear of the future and the uncontrollability of this technology. It is not about the moral dilemmas thrown up by the Nash story, none of which are in fact new. The fear is that Adam Nash will be followed by a generation of genetically selected, athletic, six-foot blond haired blue-eyed "Genrich". These are issues for concern, not panic. In reality, it is unlikely that we will ever be able to identify accurately the genes for intelligence and beauty. Furthermore, the expense of genetic selection and the scarcity of donor eggs will limit access to the procedure. Besides, guidelines can be used to regulate genetic selection just as the HFEA has regulated embryology.

Detectable throughout this debate is a nostalgia for an era of moral certainties in which the state, the church or the community made moral decisions for us. The moral maps with which many of us were raised are ill-equipped to negotiate the kinds of dilemmas thrown up by dramatic developments in medical technology. Many of our oldest philosophical concepts - like what fate means in an age of genetic selection - are redundant. Philosophy should be on the curriculum; today's children will need its reasoning skills. We also need a system similar to that in the Netherlands where local panels draw on legal, medical, ethical and lay opinion to help the morally bewildered and take the case-by-case approach required. Blanket principles in this brave new world of contemporary medicine will be no help. The worst option is that these decisions end up in an adversarial courts system determined by narrow legal definitions as we witnessed in the case of the conjoined twins last month.

fields.headline: Widdecombe's fare
fields.standfirst: Her plans lack logic and coherence
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe may have just solved the Tories' trickiest conundrum. Until yesterday they could not explain how they would simultaneously spend more money on public services even as they cut taxes. But in Bournemouth the shadow home secretary hit upon a novel way to find the extra cash: she wants to fine one in four adults £100 for possessing cannabis.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe may have just solved the Tories' trickiest conundrum. Until yesterday they could not explain how they would simultaneously spend more money on public services even as they cut taxes. But in Bournemouth the shadow home secretary hit upon a novel way to find the extra cash: she wants to fine one in four adults £100 for possessing cannabis. One in four may sound huge, but that was the finding of 1998's British Crime Survey: it found 25% of us had tried cannabis at some point, rising to 42% among the under-30s. So Ms Widdecombe's call for a fixed penalty on all those millions may well be a stroke of fiscal genius: an instant money-maker.

Judged by any other criterion, however, the proposal is flat-out absurd - as ill-considered as Tony Blair's infamous "cashpoint" scheme for late night louts. Now, as then, the condemnation has come from all quarters. Despite Ms Widdecombe's claim to have consulted with them before her conference speech, the police have been unequivocal. The Police Federation said that, with only a limited number of officers available, arresting everyone who uses a tiny amount of dope would divert the force from fighting more serious crimes: burglary or vio lence. Others noted that Operation Widdecombe would leave millions of otherwise law-abiding people with a criminal record, barring them from work as teachers, social workers or carers. As if such a consensus of disapproval outside the Bournemouth centre was not evidence enough of the Conservatives' blunder, the party's former leader in the Lords, Robert Cranborne, joined in. He said "zero tolerance" of drugs would make the law into an ass, one that would be broken en masse and without guilt.

The noble lord's comments go to the heart of the Tories' problem this week: they keep treading on their own message. Either they send out mixed signals - cuddly tolerance from Michael Portillo, crackdown toughness from Ms Widdecombe - or they argue with each other: first Ken Clarke is warm on Europe, then Margaret Thatcher is characteristically chilly. The result is confusion and loss of credibility: a point emphasised by yesterday's equally muddled call for young workers to save for their own pensions, thereby depriving the state pension fund of £4bn. The Tories' plans may grab headlines, but they lack coherence or even basic logic. To coin a phrase, they lack common sense.

Others noted that Operation Widdecombe would leave millions of otherwise law-abiding people with a criminal record, barring them from work as teachers, social workers or carers. As if such a consensus of disapproval outside the Bournemouth centre was not evidence enough of the Conservatives' blunder, the party's former leader in the Lords, Robert Cranborne, joined in. He said "zero tolerance" of drugs would make the law into an ass, one that would be broken en masse and without guilt. The noble lord's comments go to the heart of the Tories' problem this week: they keep treading on their own message. Either they send out mixed signals - cuddly tolerance from Michael Portillo, crackdown toughness from Ms Widdecombe - or they argue with each other: first Ken Clarke is warm on Europe, then Margaret Thatcher is characteristically chilly. The result is confusion and loss of credibility: a point emphasised by yesterday's equally muddled call for young workers to save for their own pensions, thereby depriving the state pension fund of £4bn. The Tories' plans may grab headlines, but they lack coherence or even basic logic. To coin a phrase, they lack common sense.

webTitle: Why the Nashes are good parents

fields.headline: Why the Nashes are good parents
fields.standfirst:
A couple's decision to artificially conceive a baby who can help cure their sick daughter has been widely condemned. But Leah Wild, author of our Trying column, salutes them

Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: A couple's decision to artificially conceive a baby who can help cure their sick daughter has been widely condemned. But Leah Wild, author of our Trying column, salutes them
fields.body:
The Nashes of Colorado seem a very conventional family. Lisa Nash is a nurse, Jack Nash a hotel manager and they have a six-year-old, Molly. Like all good American couples, they longed for another child. But the Nashs have a rare genetic disorder, Fanconi anaemia, which their daughter has inherited. It could shortly be the cause of her death.

There was only one chance of saving her. The Nashes had pre-implantation genetic diagnosis (PGD), a procedure similar to IVF, which produced 15 embryos, five unaffected by the condition. Of these five, they chose one that might produce a stem cell donor match for Molly, and cure her. In August, their son Adam was born.

You may imagine that such great lengths to save - and create - a child might be applauded. But no; many have condemned the whole procedure. The language invoked is terrifying: spare part children, designer babies, Frankenstein.

I have an inherited chromosomal disorder so profound that three out of four of my pregnancies will lead to the foetus dying either in the womb or shortly after birth. Without pre-implantation genetic diagnosis (PGD), which sometimes goes under the far more scary title of genetic engineering, my chance of having a child would be slim. Thanks to a procedure very similar to the Nashes', I am now pregnant.

No one in their right mind would chose to have PGD. It involves taking significant amounts of powerful drugs, and involves health risks to the mother. People don't have PGD as a choice, but because they have no choice. There is simply no other way they can produce a child that will not either be very profoundly affected, or die.

This is the stark situation the Nash family was faced with. They wanted a second child, but feared it might inherit Fanconi anaemia for which there was a test available at the pre-implantation stage. At that same stage they could, also, find out which of these embryos would help to save their dying daughter.

Are they supposed to ignore this second fact? Would it really have been morally superior, knowing they might be able to save their daughter, to let her die?

The Nashes have clearly stated their list of priorities in conceiving their son. "We selected Adam firstly because we knew he would be healthy," says Lisa. "Secondly, we knew he would be able to give Molly the bone marrow she needed."

Creating one child for the bene fit of another is nothing new. When city financier Nicola Horlick's eldest daughter had leukaemia, she felt that another child might provide a bone marrow match that could save her life, and had another baby. There was no match.

But there was also no disapproving finger wagged around what she had done. This seemed a perfectly reasonable stance for a mother faced with the creeping death of her eldest child. Yet when PGD is involved, our attitudes change. The creation of that child is not seen as "natural", just because it takes place in a dish.

Critics of PGD almost always invoke the slippery slope argument; it begins with fatal diseases, and ends with designer babies, picked for little more than their looks. Yet we already have selection in invasive antenatal testing such as amniocentesis.

The same procedures often reveal the foetus's sex, yet this has not led many, if any, women to request a termination because "they always wanted a boy". So why is it presumed that this will be the widespread case with PGD?

There is an underlying assumption that PGD patients somehow don't make such good parents. Yesterday a spokesperson for the British Medical Association questioned whether the Nashes would love their new son as much as their daughter, or whether they would see him as a "medical commodity". But who are doctors, however eminent, to pass judgment on our love for our children?

The reasons couples choose to have a second child are often complicated. One of the most frequent reasons given is that they think it would be unfair on the first born to be an "only child", that this would make them different and lonely.

Does that mean these families should be condemned as viewing their second offspring simply as an "emotional commodity"? And does this mean that we ought to interfere and discourage families being planned around such considerations?

Those who, through an absence of choices most people take for granted, are faced with PGD, should not have their motives for becoming parents constantly challenged.

We are not seeking to determine the colour of our child's hair or the hue of their eyes. We are hoping to ensure that our children will not die. In doing so, the Nashes have created another, loved life. Surely this can only be for the good.

fields.headline: Lonely hearts
fields.standfirst: Wanted: US president with character
fields.trailText: What do American voters really want in a president? Try thinking of a small ad in the personal columns. "Large, fickle, undecided electorate, no stranger to heartbreak, WLTM easy-going, mentally-balanced middle-aged male, N/S, with GSOH, with view to four-year relationship, domestic bliss, and world domination.
fields.body:
What do American voters really want in a president? Try thinking of a small ad in the personal columns. "Large, fickle, undecided electorate, no stranger to heartbreak, WLTM easy-going, mentally-balanced middle-aged male, N/S, with GSOH, with view to four-year relationship, domestic bliss, and world domination. Must be brave, smart, and good-looking (like Harrison Ford in Air Force One), trustworthy (not like Richard Nixon), and real tough on invaders from outer space (as in Independence Day). Must like dogs, log fires, Elvis, the NFL, tax cuts and surgical strikes. And must be able to keep flies buttoned (unlike You Know Who). Please send photo." But what do these lonely hearts actually get? Judging by the first-date TV debate between Al Gore and George W Bush, they get two identically dressed fellas so totally prepped, coached and spun, they hardly know who they are any more.

Mr Bush (the nervous one from Texas) scored a lot of positive negatives. He was gaffe-free, did not mistake Tiananmen Square for a board game and figured (correctly) that Slobodan is the bad guy. Even his mud-slinging about the "character issue" was more pat-a-cake than killer punch. Mr Gore (the one with the undertaker's voice) did not do a lot of stuff, too. He managed not to frighten the horses (or those crazy soccer moms) and did not get aggressive and make George cry. After complaints that he exaggerates, the Veep eschewed claims to have invented the internet, halted global warming and to have been Burt Lancaster's role model in From Here to Eternity (with Deborah Kerr playing Tipper).

The strait-laced debate format imposed enormous, artificial pressure on both men. Advisers warned that one slip could tip the race. Whether true or not, the result was an uptight, uninspiring performance. Yet for either to have any hope of a happy union with voters, both must cast inhibition aside on their next date, lighten up and be themselves.

fields.headline: QXL price is bid down
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: QXL.com slumped to a new low yesterday when it emerged that chairman Jonathan Bulkeley had sold 750,000 shares in the beleaguered online auction company.
fields.body:
QXL.com slumped to a new low yesterday when it emerged that chairman Jonathan Bulkeley had sold 750,000 shares in the beleaguered online auction company.

His selling began on September 28 with the price at 51.5p and was announced yesterday, forcing the shares down 2.5p to 44.25p. The disposals follow two separate sales in August when a total of 825,000 shares were sold by a New Jersey trust over which Mr Bulkeley exerts no control but of which he is a beneficiary. QXL shares stood at 750p in March.

Analysts reacted tersely. "It doesn't exactly help sentiment does it?" said one. "Perhaps it would have been more intelligent to sell when the price was seven quid."

QXL says Mr Bulkeley was merely covering personal tax liabilities. Analysts say future funding issues and the retreating likelihood of a bid from eBay could force QXL shares even lower.

fields.headline: Tobacco firms face adverts ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: The government will announce plans today to ban tobacco advertising and sponsorship as the World Health Organisation piles on the pressure for an official inquiry into smuggling allegations against the tobacco giants.
fields.body:
The government will announce plans today to ban tobacco advertising and sponsorship as the World Health Organisation piles on the pressure for an official inquiry into smuggling allegations against the tobacco giants.

Public health minister Yvette Cooper is to promise legislation to significantly curb cigarette promotion within hours of the European Court of Justice ruling unlawful a Brussels directive intended to achieve the same end.

A bill is expected in the Queen's Speech next month to fulfill Labour's manifesto commitment to end advertising, with a fierce debate underway in Whitehall over whether motor racing and snooker should retain controversial three-year extensions.

Under a European Union proposal, the two sports could have continued taking tobacco money until 2006 rather than the 2003 deadline for other sectors after lobbying by Downing Street.

Labour was forced to return a £1m gift, and turn down a second, after it emerged the money had been donated by Formula One mogul Bernie Ecclestone who stood to gain a small fortune from the extension.

Downing Street is believed to be torn between treating the grand prix industry like all other sectors to "draw a line" under the Ecclestone affair and sleaze accusations or sticking with the longer period, fearing a shorter timescale could damage the sport.

The Commons health select committee supports a tougher line with motor racing. The World Motor Sport Council of the International Automobile Federation last night announced it would impose its own ban on tobacco advertising and sponsorship from 2006.

The EU directive is expected to be struck out by the court on technical grounds after the commission introduced it under EU single market legislation rather than as a health and safety issue.

The commitment to outlaw advertising comes as a senior WHO official urged ministers to investigate evidence that British American Tobacco and other companies have profitted hugely from smuggling.

The Commons health committee proposed a Whitehall inquiry earlier this year, but BAT, which set up an internal inquiry after the Guardian published internal documents, is lobbying against an investigation.

David Yach, director of the WHO's programmes on non-communicable diseases, said: "By forcing prices down, large-scale cigarette smuggling is contributing to the growth of smoking in developing countries."

webTitle: Blair to urge second chamber for EU

fields.headline: Blair to urge second chamber for EU
fields.standfirst:
PM's Poland speech will put case for nation states

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair flies to Poland today to deliver a speech on the future of Europe which has been billed as an attempt to reassert the authority of the nation state.
fields.body:
Tony Blair flies to Poland today to deliver a speech on the future of Europe which has been billed as an attempt to reassert the authority of the nation state.

Mr Blair will propose a new second chamber for the European Union drawn from member states' national parliaments.

It would act as a political check on both the European commission and the European parliament. It follows similar proposals for an EU senate from the German foreign secretary, Joschka Fischer and the Czech president, Vaclav Havel.

Mr Blair's speech, which takes as its theme the institutional value in restraining trends towards further European integration, has been given extra weight by last week's referendum in which Denmark rejected the euro.

The prime minister will not specify the size of the proposed second chamber, but he will say it could oversee areas such as defence, justice and home affairs, which are presently handled inter-governmentally, without direct input from the commission or European parliament. It could also bring national democracies closer to the institutions of the EU.

At present, many of the institutions dealing with these policy areas are swamped by large workloads. In the House of Commons, the EU standing committees, established to scrutinise draft legislation from Europe, have no legal status within EU treaties. The European court of justice can take up to five years to rule on whether the commission has overstepped its powers.

Overall, Mr Blair hopes the speech will both reassure his domestic audience by proposing a non-federal version of Europe while setting out a credible, positive plan which will influence the thinking of his fellow leaders.

Mr Blair had been urged by some advisers to propose a new two-part treaty for Europe clearly setting out the distinctive competences of national governments and the EU. This would to draw a line in the sand against further integration. However, Mr Blair has also been warned that such an idea could be interpreted by Eurosceptics as a constitution for Europe.

He will urge his fellow heads of state to take on a greater role in European affairs through the council of ministers, but will not mount a direct attack on the commission, arguing that the process of reform has now begun under its vice-pres ident, Neil Kinnock. Mr Blair is expected to refer to the Danish referendum result as a sign of growing alienation of all European electorates, who regard politicians as remote and unaccountable.

He is also considering tabling a call for sunset clauses - deadlines by which proposals floated in Brussels must either to be adopted or dropped altogether.

The choice of Warsaw as the venue will also ensure the speech contains a strong call for the EU to expand its borders to the east as swiftly as possible. Mr Blair will argue enlargement would represent a victory for European values of solidarity.

He is likely to echo a suggestion by Robin Cook, foreign secretary, that the first wave of applicants, six countries including Poland, should be admitted to the EU by 2005.

However, he will reject the idea of enhanced cooperation in which a small cabal of probably wealthier countries could cooperate more closely either inside or outside the EU. He will argue that such a proposal would merely set up a new waiting room for applicant countries.

fields.headline: Drugs speech backfires on Hague
fields.standfirst:
Police chiefs criticise Widdecombe's plan for £100 fixed penalty fines for possession of cannabis

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: William Hague was last night left struggling to get his party conference back on his "ready for government" message after Ann Widdecombe's latest hardline initiatives against minor drug offences met widespread criticism - even from the police.
fields.body:
William Hague was last night left struggling to get his party conference back on his "ready for government" message after Ann Widdecombe's latest hardline initiatives against minor drug offences met widespread criticism - even from the police.

With the Police Superintendents' Association calling the plans impractical and unenforceable, the Conservative leader was forced to stop polishing his keynote speech, to be delivered in Bournemouth today, in order to defend the shadow home secretary's pro posal for £100 "fixed penalty" fines for possession of cannabis.

Although Mr Hague was given advance warning of Miss Widdecombe's plan to tackle the issue of drugs, his aides were furious to learn of the details only in the early editions of yesterday's newspapers. The Tory leader was left with no option but to publicly back her.

Last night he found himself on TV being asked whether - in addition to his 14 pints in a day as a teenager - he had ever smoked marijuana, like up to 42% of young people between 16 and 29. "No, I did not," he said.

Insisting that US experience has shown what can be achieved, Mr Hague told Channel 4 News: "We have to take the fight against drugs further down the [supply] chain...we want to talk to the police about how to do it. The police have to fight harder against drugs, not surrender."

Miss Widdecombe defended her proposals, which would also mean longer sentences for dealers. But she conceded that her policy would need 2,500 extra police and a similar number of extra prison places.

Not only did the Widdecombe package come as a surprise to senior colleagues, including the shadow chancel lor, Michael Portillo - whose approval would be needed for the cost of extra police and prisons required - but its tone was at odds with the socially tolerant and inclusive "one nation" tone which Hague allies have been striking all week.

Buoyed by rising opinion polls and Labour's problems, the Tories have been enjoying what Mr Hague will today call their "biggest, most upbeat and successful conference for years" watched by voters who, the Tory leader believes, think he is fit to be prime minister.

He plans to open up a "second front" - promising that a Hague government would direct much of its energy to im proving the lives of the "least fortunate" people on bleak estates in inner cities, the old, poor and those scarred by drugs.

He will re-emphasise the inclusive nature of his campaign strategy by seeking to reach beyond the core Conservative vote - those people enthused by his message on tax, crime, asylum and Europe - to "govern for all hard-working families...for people of every community and background."

Mr Hague will deride New Labour - "never a philosophy, it was a fashion, and nothing is more unfashionable than fashion which is out of fashion. We saw them last week, divided, arrogant and out of touch. What a bunch they are, this soap opera of a government."

He will say voters "know that not only has Labour failed to deliver, but it's never going to deliver. They want to know what the alternative will be. They look at us, they want to know if we are ready, they want to know if they can trust us."

fields.headline: Very Rev Tom Baker
fields.standfirst:
Dean who ran 'the happiest cathedral in England'
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: When Tom Baker, who has died aged 79, was Dean of Worcester, from 1975-1986, his was said to be the happiest cathedral in England. He made astute appointments, and his well-informed love of music and good liturgy, together with clear, intelligent preaching, made it a natural setting for his gifts. His personality and sensitive leadership enabled a varied group of individuals to work well together.
fields.body:
When Tom Baker, who has died aged 79, was Dean of Worcester, from 1975-1986, his was said to be the happiest cathedral in England. He made astute appointments, and his well-informed love of music and good liturgy, together with clear, intelligent preaching, made it a natural setting for his gifts. His personality and sensitive leadership enabled a varied group of individuals to work well together.

Seven months after going to Worcester, his mother and aunt, with whom he had lived all his life and to whom he was utterly devoted, died. Then he was diagnosed with throat cancer. For a long time he totally lost his voice, and it was four years before he was able to use it properly.

As dean he restored the fine Norman crypt, previously a store-room, but now regarded as the finest part of the cathedral. He also oversaw many imaginative projects to mark the diocese's 1,300th anniversary.

Tom Baker was an only child in a house of nine adults, including grandparents on both sides and aunts, in Southampton. He was educated at the local King Edward VI School, Exeter College, Oxford, and Lincoln Theological College. He served his title at All Saints, Kings Heath, Birmingham. He was then sent to revive St James, Edgbaston, which he did.

From 1954 to 1960 he was sub-warden of Lincoln Theological College, and from 1960 until 1971 he was principal of Wells Theological College. Re-shaping the worship at Wells in a way that was at once modern and classically Christian, taking Wells staff to Taizé in Burgundy and other places of Christian excellence on the continent, it was the most creative and influential period of his life.

He persuaded the cathedral chapter to let the college use the undercroft for worship. In this in-the-round setting, worship that was well ordered, attentive and reflective of the concerns of the world was insisted on. Students also encountered biblical scholarship that was, to many, startlingly radical, and which set out to relate Christian truth to a culture rapidly moving away from traditional signposts.

With a growing number of older ordinands who had not studied for many years, seminars were carefully shaped to give them selective reading and focused questions. Another feature of the college was the emphasis on small groups. Every student had to belong to a house group with regular meetings, and there were in addition other special groups in which the psycho-dynamics of life together could be experienced and ex plored. The challenge of creating real community out of real relationships was always a priority.

With the declining number of ordinands, a merger of Wells with Salisbury seemed obvious. The college moved physically to Salisbury for reasons that quickly proved insubstantial. Eventually the Salisbury and Wells College had to close too. However, Tom kept up his influence in theological training as, in effect, the chief inspector of colleges and courses.

From 1971-75 he was Archdeacon of Bath and maintained that the archdeacon's role was ideally placed for the pastoral care of the clergy, because it meant that he met the incumbent and his wife round the kitchen table. He pioneered work on pastoral reorganisation, and the Bath and Wells report on this subject was a model which was followed by a number of other dioceses.

When Baker was a student at Lincoln Theological College, the principal was the enormously influential Eric Abbott. Tom continued his tradition of caring, individual friendship. A previous sub-warden of Lincoln was Michael Ramsay, whose combination of Catholic spirituality and biblical scholarship was also very much part of Baker. At the same time, he belonged to a tradition of Anglicans who combined radical New Testament scholarship with a liberal Catholic churchmanship, such as Dennis Nineham, Christopher Evans and John Fenton.

Tom Baker published What Is The New Testament? (1969) and Questioning Worship (1977). A book of essays in his honour, The Reality Of God, was published in 1986. His last years were spent at the Charterhouse in East London, where he was able to continue his wide reading and his love of the theatre, cinema and above all music.

David Mealand writes: At Wells, Tom Baker was a theological teacher who knew his tradition thoroughly, who knew it had always changed to meet new needs, and was fully aware of how it should still change. His faith was evident from concise speech expressing deep thinking that was evidently his own. He valued silence.

A man of great self-discipline, Tom knew how to give others responsibility for their decisions, individually and also collectively, while enabling them to see just how much was expected of them. This is a rare and precious skill, perhaps the greatest of his many gifts.

 Thomas George Adames Baker, priest, born December 22 1920; died September 25 2000

webTitle: BA suspends 11 pilots accused of drinking before flights

fields.headline: BA suspends 11 pilots accused of drinking before flights
fields.trailText: BA last night suspended 11 pilots and three cabin crew following allegations that they had breached the company's strict rules about drinking alcohol before flights.
fields.body:
BA last night suspended 11 pilots and three cabin crew following allegations that they had breached the company's strict rules about drinking alcohol before flights.

In a move which could result in a strike of its 3,500 pilots, BA said the staff involved had been removed from duty pending the outcome of an internal investigation. They face dismissal if the allegations are proved.

David Hyde, BA's director of safety, said: "We take any potential breach of regulations very seriously. We have launched a formal investigation and have notified the Civil Aviation Authority."

The allegations are made in a Channel 4 Dispatches programme due to be screened next week. BA said it had asked the makers of the documentary to hand over any evidence that will assist the investigation.

The allegations refer to staff employed on short haul flights from Europe to Gatwick over a period of several months earlier this year. The drinking incidents were mainly at European hotels and the three cabin crew members are said to have included at least one stewardess.

Under BA's rules, staff are only allowed to drink in moderation in the 24 hours before a flight and are not permitted any alcohol in the eight hours before reporting for duty or while on duty.

Staff were suspended on Friday, immediately after Channel 4 contacted BA, although it is understood that BA warned staff a month ago of the documentary team's activity.

Mr Hyde said that the company had to act swiftly because the safety of passengers and its aircraft was a priority.

"These allegations surprise us, but we are erring on the side of caution in removing staff from duty while the investigations are carried out," he declared.

He stressed that all BA flights are recorded so that management can monitor the behaviour of crews on duty.

"This enables us to identify drunken driving, and there is no suggestion that safety was compromised on any of the flights that followed these alleged drinking incidents," he said.

Mr Hyde refused to release the names of the staff involved because none of the allegations have been proven.

But the airline pilots' union, Balpa, is furious that at least one former BA cabin crew member took part in the programme, drinking with ex-colleagues while filming took place.

Christopher Darke, Balpa's general secretary, attacked the programme for its "underhand and disgraceful journalistic methods, which could be described as entrapment."

He went on: "Channel 4 has used ex-cabin crew members to befriend, entice and entrap flight and cabin crew, then filmed them secretly without their knowledge and consent. They have then levelled very grave allegations and have not provided the evidence to support it."

Mr Darke said that Channel 4 had been sitting on the evidence since March, yet chose "deliberately and calculatedly" to withhold the information from the civil aviation authority and BA for almost eight months. "If they had hard evidence, they should have raised it straight away with the appropriate authorities in the public interest."

He said that Channel 4's actions were not in the public interest and accused programme makers of trying to enhance the sensationalism of the programme without due regard for public safety. He also said that Balpa would defend its members by any means, including legal action.

BA's pilots are already angry with the company over two previous unrelated incidents in which staff have been reprimanded. One pilot has been sacked for ordering a woman off a plane after she falsely accused a fellow passenger of carrying a bomb.

webTitle: Bereaved couple demand right to baby girl

fields.headline: Bereaved couple demand right to baby girl
fields.standfirst:
Parents want to choose sex of next child after only daughter died aged three

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: A couple whose only daughter died in a bonfire accident are to launch a court action under the new Human Rights Act to try to choose the sex of a child.
fields.body:
A couple whose only daughter died in a bonfire accident are to launch a court action under the new Human Rights Act to try to choose the sex of a child.

Alan and Louise Masterton, from Monifieth, near Dundee, have four sons and want to use IVF and pre-implantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) to ensure their next child is a girl.

Their daughter, Nicole, died last summer at the age of three after a balloon containing flammable gas fell on to a bonfire at their home and exploded. Nicole suffered 90% burns and died two months later.

At the moment, embryo sex screening is only available for prospective parents who are carriers of medical conditions related to a particular gender.

The Mastertons plan to launch a court case against the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority under two articles of the European Convention on Human Rights, which guarantee a fair hearing from public authorities.

The couple, speaking at their home yesterday, said they were not trying to replace Nicole or create a designer baby, but had a deep psychological need for a girl in the family. Mrs Masterton, 42, was sterilised after Nicole's birth.

"It is difficult to explain," said Mr Masterton. "We tried for Nicole for 15 years. We were blessed with her and she was a fantastic child. We are looking for the opportunity to try for another daughter, not another Nicole, but to bring a female dimension to our family."

The couple approached the HFEA in January, asking for the rules governing PGD to be changed for their case and for Louise to be implanted with female-only embryos.

The process involves the selective destruction of male embryos and is usually employed for families with a history of hereditary diseases in male children, such as haemophilia or muscular dystrophy.

They were told to submit an application through one of the five IVF clinics in the UK. They approached the clinics and were turned down because, they say, the clinics were not prepared to put forward a case that went against HFEA policy.

"What the HFEA are saying is a smokescreen," said Mr Masterton. "They claim to have given permission to the clinics to apply, but they have to change the rule first."

HFEA spokesman James Yeandel said the authority's policy was that PGD should only be used when there was a risk of serious genetic disorder, but they had been moved by the tragic nature of the case and agreed that a licensing committee could examine it. To do that, they needed an application from the Mastertons through a clinic. "I don't know what else we can do," he said. However, the Bishop of Edinburgh, Richard Holloway, a former HFEA board member, said he hoped the case could be considered. He said the HFEA was responding cautiously because of a deep-rooted public fear over sex selection.

"I think, in this case, it probably ought to look hard at it because, while you could probably make a case for a general regulation that sex selection is a bad thing, there must be exceptional circumstances. I would think this one probably was, and I hope they can get a centre to send in an application to the HFEA."

But Ken Mason, who teaches medical law and ethics at Edinburgh University, said the Mastertons' case crossed the boundaries of ethically acceptable medical practice. "You could take this to the point of absurdity - for example, you could say you had five children with red hair and wanted one with black hair.

"It is an absurd example, but nonetheless if you open up the Pandora's box wider and wider, you will eventually get to an absurd situation like that."

If the case fails, however, the couple could look overseas for help - something they have already considered.

webTitle: Half of all Britons own mobile phones

fields.headline: Half of all Britons own mobile phones
fields.trailText: More than half of all people in Britain now own a mobile phone after record sales of almost 4m handsets in the past three months.
fields.body:
More than half of all people in Britain now own a mobile phone after record sales of almost 4m handsets in the past three months.

The figures confirm one of the most conspicuous social changes to have taken place over the past 10 years. The four UK networks now have 34m customers between them, equivalent to more than one per household.

The blistering pace of growth has been driven by pre-pay services which allow users to keep a tighter grip on costs by replacing monthly bills with credit vouchers.

Pre-pay has broadened the appeal of mobile phones to lower income groups and to new age groups. Parents now commonly buy pre-pay services for their children to keep them in touch without the threat of spiralling bills. Last week a report suggested that children were now spending more on their mobile phones than anything else.

In the last quarter, One2One, the traditional laggard of the four networks, managed to win the most customers, adding 1.1m new users. Of these, 98% were on pre-pay and 2% on contract.

Industry pundits said the figures could be inflated by some users owning more than one phone.

Mobile phone companies have become extremely hot properties. In a mark of the growth of the sector, Vodafone has become the largest company in the country, worth some £154bn. It is bigger than the oil company BP Amoco at £138bn and dwarfs British Telecom which is worth a mere £47bn.

An Orange spokesman said: "A few years ago people were still debating how many people would have mobile phones and how often would they use them.

It is now pretty well accepted that in the next couple of years virtually everyone in this country will own a mobile phone. The debate is no longer about will it happen but how long it will take."

In Finland, which has embraced mobile phones more keenly than anywhere else, 80% own mobile phones. The US, unusually, is far behind Europe due to the lack of national networks, older technology and the legacy of a system where the person receiving the call had to pay for it.

Vodafone remains the biggest network in Britain with 10.2m customers following the three-month period to the end of September in which it added 877,000.

BT Cellnet is the second largest with 8.7m, Orange is a close third with 8.3m and One2One has 7.1m. Virgin Mobile which launched last year on the One2One network now has more than 400,000 customers.

The introduction of Wap (wireless application protocol) phones this year, providing very basic internet access, has also driven new handset sales.

Although they were met with a lukewarm reception, Wap services are expected to improve rapidly. The government has just auctioned the next generation of mobile phone spectrums which will allow internet access at higher speeds than conventional modems, CD-quality sound and the arrival of video phones. The five licences went under the hammer for £23bn and services are expected to start in 2002/3.

fields.bylineHtml: David Teather, media business correspondent

fields.headline: Acorn refugees sell for £400m
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A start-up born from the remains of Acorn Computers and backed by £9m of financing little more than a year ago was yesterday snapped up by a Silicon Valley company for £409m.
fields.body:
A start-up born from the remains of Acorn Computers and backed by £9m of financing little more than a year ago was yesterday snapped up by a Silicon Valley company for £409m.

Cambridge-based Element 14 said it had accepted an all-share offer from the Nasdaq-listed semiconductor firm, Broadcom Corp, in a deal that is expected to make paper millionaires of most of its 68 employees.

The biggest winners are the chief executive, Stan Boland, and the handful of programmers who bought Element 14 from Acorn for a reported £1m last year. Engineers who later joined from ST Microelectronics are also likely to be amply rewarded.

Element 14 follows in a long line of hi-tech firms bred in Cambridge that have risen to international prominence, including Autonomy and ARM Holdings.

The deal echoes the success of ARM which was also spun out of Acorn nearly a decade ago and has since evolved into a stock market-listed firm valued at £7.4bn.

Element 14 designs chips for the digital subscriber systems that allow for high speed internet access over regular copper telephone lines. The technology is used in high-speed modems, third generation cellphones and set-top boxes.

Development centres have been built in Cambridge, Bristol and Mechelen, Belgium, and Element has been granted or filed applications for 19 patents.

The company's name stems from the fact that silicon - the base material used in computer chips - is the 14th element in the periodic table.

Broadcom delivers broadband solutions to homes and offices in the US. "We believe this acquisition will position Broadcom as a leader in the ADSL market," said Dr Henry T Nicholas III, the chief executive.

Mr Boland said: "We felt our technology already gave us leadership in ADSL solutions but to develop the next generation of subscriber products, we saw a clear need to have access to multiple network, protocol, voice and home networking technologies. Broadcom is clearly the market leader in these areas."

Atlas Ventures, Bessemer Venture Partners and Amadeus Capital Partners backed the original development team. The £9m they put up in August last year was said to make Element 14 the largest silicon chip start-up in Europe.

Amadeus is run by Herman Hauser, who also has a valuable stake in ARM.

Mr Boland said that Digital Signal Processor chips - the sort of chip that his firm designs - will be embedded in 2.6bn devices by 2005. He says Element's chips will be cheaper, easier to use and consume less power than those currently available.

Acorn, noted for its educational computers, disappeared from the stock market in April last year following a £270m break-up deal.

webTitle: Young women at the Conservative party conference accuse their elders of blocking their path to powe

fields.headline: Do women hold other women back?
fields.standfirst: As young women at the Conservative party conference accuse their elders of blocking their path to power, Joan Smith wonders whether the generations can ever get along
fields.trailText: As young women at the Conservative party conference accuse their elders of blocking their path to power,  Joan Smith wonders whether the generations can ever get along
fields.body:
Do women hold other women back? Is resent- ment from older women keeping a new generation out of public life? One of the most uncomfortable subjects in politics surfaced again this week, when a bitter accusation of inter-generational rivalry was made at the Conservative party conference in Bournemouth. Women who had tried unsuccessfully for selection as parliamentary candidates described the difficulties they faced in finding seats, claiming inexperienced men were often "parachuted in" to winnable constituencies.

The harshest words came from 32-year-old pharmacist Fiona Guest, who placed the blame for the Tories' poor record in selecting female candidates squarely on other women. "It's the old ladies on the selection committees, to put it bluntly," she said on Monday, confirming the stereotype of Tory ladies as upper-middle-class housewives in floral dresses with a weakness for personable men.

Her comments follow criticism of Betty Boothroyd, the Labour MP who recently stood down as Speaker of the House of Commons, by colleagues who felt she had not been sufficiently supportive of women. Boothroyd annoyed younger female MPs when she banned breastfeeding in working areas of the house; one unnamed MP recently told the Daily Telegraph there was a "real undercurrent of bitterness" among female colleagues about her performance as Speaker.

Yet the claim that Boothroyd dislikes women has been denied by MPs as diverse as Diane Abbott and cabinet office minister Mo Mowlam; the latter has expressed gratitude to Boothroyd for the practical help she offered when Mowlam was being treated for a brain tumour. It certainly looks as though some sections of the media, after praising Boothroyd to the skies when she announced she was to stand down, have done a characteristic volte-face and begun to look for ammunition against her.

It is this undeniable undertow of misogyny in public life that makes it all the harder to disentangle accusations about "Queen Bee" syndrome - the theory that older women resent their younger colleagues and sometimes deliberately hold them back.

That it happens can be demonstrated in two words: Margaret Thatcher. The former prime minister's record of excluding other women was extraordinary and left a legacy that is still being felt today. Over a period of 11 years, she appointed only two other women to her cabinets, creating an experience gap so severe that John Major apparently could not find any suitably-qualified women to serve in his own first cabinet. Thatcher seems to have been one of those women who revels in her uniqueness, relishing her role in a way that actually set back the cause of women in the Conservative party, an ironic bequest from Britain's first female PM.

But, according to Fiona Guest, there are plenty more women like her in today's Tory party. "There are still women who don't want women to be MPs and turn down able women," she insists. "I know. I have sat on selection committees."

Mary-Ann Stephenson, director of the Fawcett Society, confirms that this theory is widely held. "The tradition has always been that it was men who blocked women in the Labour party and women who blocked them in the Conservative party."

Now, though, she thinks Conservative men are just as likely to stand in the way of women candidates. "People may be more aware when women do it," she says, "because of the expectation that women should promote and encourage other women. But I do think there's a generational shift in the Conservative party. The older generation have traditional views, such as the idea that women have children at a young age and should wait until they grow up. But the age at which people have children is going up."

The new generation of Conservative women consists of professionals, who are the least likely of any group to take time off from their careers, turning traditional Tory thinking on its head. "They go back to work very quickly," Stephenson points out. "They expect to be able to win seats."

That a gap is opening up between these women and their older colleagues is indicated by recent remarks from Gillian Shepherd, a former Tory minister. If conditions in the House of Commons are unacceptable to parents of young children, she said, "then it is better to wait to get elected until it is an easier proposition". Was she suggesting William Hague take a break from parliament if he and Ffion have babies? It seems unlikely.

No wonder the Conservative party is uncomfortable with the entire subject, with some female MPs acknowledging the problem but without coming up with much in the way of remedies. As a direct result, the overall number of women in the Commons is actually expected to fall at the next general election as Labour women in marginal constituencies lose their seats and are replaced by Tory men. In a parliamentary democracy in which women make up less than 20% of MPs, this is an indictment of the Conservatives' selection process as well as infuriating for the party's would-be women candidates.

There is some evidence, though, that generational conflicts extend beyond the confines of the Conservative party. Some women Labour MPs oppose Gwyneth Dunwoody, the leading female contender to replace Boothroyd as Speaker, and say they want a modernising candidate. (Dunwoody has said she would support the existing ban on breastfeeding.) There are genuine disagreements between women MPs who came into parliament 20 or 30 years ago, determined to show they could succeed on the same terms as men, and younger women - perhaps more directly influenced by feminism - who do not see why they should accept working conditions that favour men.

It is hard to avoid the conclusion that, not just in parliament, women from different generations have yet to learn to live with each other and avoid the kind of rivalry that leads to gleeful headlines. Part of this is accounted for by Stephenson's point about expectations: a bad male boss is seen as a bad boss, whereas a woman who abuses her authority over younger female employees is viewed very much in terms of her gender. Nor is it the case that the hostility is all one-way, with some younger feminists showing themselves all too eager to dismiss the achievements of older writers and activists.

Some of these conflicts are real, others may be due to lack of communication. Anna Coote, a long-time feminist and editor of New Gender Agenda, recalls a recent meeting, organised by the Fawcett Society, that brought together women of different generations. "The disagreements are blown up," she says. "We found we agreed on practically everything."

This may be true of women on the centre-left, who have been grappling with the competing demands of work and family for several decades. Although some women Labour MPs are unhappy with their working conditions, the party currently has 101 of them, compared with the Conservatives' 14. But the dilemma facing the Tories is much more serious. A political party that has yet to come to terms with working mothers has discovered, this week, that some of its brightest young activists fall into that much-maligned category.

webTitle: Police will not back instant drug fines campaign

fields.headline: Police will not back instant drug fines campaign
fields.standfirst:
Cannabis: Plan for £100 penalties seen as unworkable

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The police last night took the shine off from Ann Widdecombe's conference triumph by making quite clear they could not support her plan for automatic £100 for anyone possessing even the smallest amount of cannabis.
fields.body:
The police last night took the shine off from Ann Widdecombe's conference triumph by making quite clear they could not support her plan for automatic £100 for anyone possessing even the smallest amount of cannabis.

Her promise that a future Conservative government would introduce a zero tolerance for possession of drugs wowed the Tory party's law and order activists who cheered and sang 'Happy Birthday' as William Hague toasted her 53rd birthday with champagne.

Miss Widdecombe's plans to give the police the power to order a bloodtest from anybody they suspect has been using drugs has broken a seven year bipartisan approach which targeted police efforts on the most dangerous drugs.

The Police Superintendents' Association were the most openly critical: "We would not support this proposal," said their spokesman, Peter Williams. "The policy is not to punish people for possession of drugs but to try to divert them from drugs." The other police organisations representing chief constables and rank and file police officers made clear they had not been consulted before the Conservative plan was finalised.

Miss Widdecombe was also implicitly criticised from within her own party. The former Tory leader of the Lords, Lord Cranborne, called for cannabis to be legalised and told the BBC: "You play into the hands of criminals if you make the law into an ass when nobody wants to obey the law and, indeed, regards breaking the law as a bit of a challenge."

But such reservations did not trouble the party faithful who rewarded Miss Widdecombe's proposed drugs clampdown and pledges to detain all asylum seekers and make prisoners work a full day with the kind of reception that they use to reserve for "hanging and flogging" home secretaries.

She made clear her new drugs policy came straight from the policy book of the New York Republican, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani: "Although we can't replicate exactly what I saw in New York, we can learn the lessons of tackling crime head on and not conceding a centimetre to the criminals. So today, I can announce a new policy. A policy that means no quarter for those who trade is dealing in human misery, despair and even death."

She made clear that a first time offender - schoolchildren included - would face a minimum fixed penalty - not an on-the-spot fine - of at least £100. Second time offenders would be taken straight to court for heavier punishment.

Miss Widdecombe also confirmed Tory plans to put all new asylum seekers into detention camps and promised "we will automatically house all new applicants in secure reception centres."

She added: "It's extraordinary, but Labour call that racist. Yet the biggest loser in the system is the genuine refugee who comes to this country with not only a legal but a moral case for a safe haven, and finds himself clogged up in a queue which has hit more than 100,000 cases - double what Labour inherited."

Real refugees, under her plan, would be given access to education for their children, and language and social services support.

webTitle: A year on from Paddington, signals errors are rising

fields.headline: A year on from Paddington, signals errors are rising
fields.standfirst: Special report: Paddington train crash
fields.trailText: The number of signals passed at danger (Spads) is beginning to rise again a year after the Paddington rail crash.
fields.body:
The number of signals passed at danger (Spads) is beginning to rise again a year after the Paddington rail crash.

Official industry sources last night confirmed that the number passed at danger last month was 48, the second highest for the year. In the month before the Paddington disaster, the total was 54.

News of the rise in Spads comes as survivors and relatives of the bereaved prepare to commemorate the first anniversary of the crash. Thirty-one people were killed and hundreds injured a year ago today when an eastbound Great Western express from Cheltenham collided with a Thames Turbo train a mile from Paddington.

Railway inspectors were worried that this September's Spad figures could exceed those of last year, but the final weeks of the month resulted in a levelling out. In August the number of incidents totalled 44, of which 18 were described as serious. Industry sources said it was essential that the impetus on reducing signals being passed at danger was maintained.

The number of railway inspectors is to be increased from 70 to 140 by 2002. This is because of the increasing workload, now that they have to examine the safety case of each train operating company.

Survivors of the crash have called for nationwide adoption of automatic train protection (ATP), the most efficient means of preventing trains passing red signals as happened at Paddington.

ATP was recommended following the Clapham rail disaster, which claimed 35 lives in 1988. However, a report by Sir David Davies, published in February, said the cheaper train protection warning system (TPWS) was the best solution in the short term.

Survivors of the crash condemn the decision. Martin Mimms, spokesman for the Paddington Survivors Group, said: "One year on little or nothing has changed as far as rail safety is concerned. The Ladbroke Grove crash could happen again tomorrow, trains are still going through red signals and the train stopping system being introduced would not have prevented Ladbroke Grove."

The group also expressed disquiet over the establishment of Railway Safety, a Railtrack company intended to replace the company's safety and standards directorate. They feel it will not have sufficient public accountability.

Louise Christian, the solicitor who represented the survivors and families at the Cullen inquiry into the Paddington disaster, called for greater commitment to rail safety.

"Everyone knows that if the findings of Justice Holden's inquiry into the Clapham rail crash in 1988, which recommended ATP, neither Southall or Paddington would have happened. That is heartbreaking."

Tracks and stations along the main rail route from London to Cheltenham were to observe a minute's silence today at 8.11am, the time of the crash. At Paddington station survivors and relatives of the victims meet to remember the bereaved. At 4pm, there will be a memorial service at Central Hall, Westminster. Great Western cancelled its 6.03am service from Cheltenham to London as a mark of respect.

webTitle: First TV debate sets out battle lines

fields.headline: First TV debate sets out battle lines
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush headed straight back to middle America yesterday, the day after a televised debate that underlined big political differences between the two candidates, and which saw Mr Gore consolidate his position as the favourite to win the US presidency next month.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush headed straight back to middle America yesterday, the day after a televised debate that underlined big political differences between the two candidates, and which saw Mr Gore consolidate his position as the favourite to win the US presidency next month.

Mr Bush spent the day campaigning in Pennsylvania, while Mr Gore travelled to Ohio, both key battleground states.

Early polls yesterday showed the Democratic vice-president making inroads among undecided voters in the aftermath of the head-to-head meeting, which drew an estimated audience of more than 60m viewers.

A poll of debate-watchers for CBS News showed that 56% thought Mr Gore performed better than his rival, compared with 42% for Mr Bush. A similar survey for CNN had Mr Gore with a 48%-41% advantage on debate performance, while an NBC poll gave Mr Gore a 46%-36% margin.

The first of this autumn's three presidential debates will certainly have put to rest the facile notion that the 2000 election is a contest between indistinguishable candidates with a common philosophy.

In 90 minutes of often fact-filled debate at the University of Massachusetts on Tuesday night, Mr Gore and Mr Bush set out starkly different approaches to the role of government in domestic and international affairs.

They repeatedly drew the battle lines on issues ranging from tax cuts to abortion, and from protection of the environment to Balkans peacekeeping.

Yesterday's press reactions were predictably varied.

Mr Bush "held his own in the first match", the Dallas Morning News concluded; "Bush got his clock cleaned", the online magazine Slate decided; The Washington Post judged that "both candidates cleared the bar of minimum requirements", while the Los Angeles Times said: "If the race is based on this debate, it remains a squeaker."

There were "surprisingly few of the usual gaffes and zingers that the public usually remembers from debates", the New York Times said. "Instead the powerful impression was of two advocates of different views of government."

Only in the closing exchanges did the debate turn anything like personal, as Mr Bush launched an attack on his opponent's character and trustworthiness with regard to campaign fundraising.

Mr Gore refused to be drawn into a personal exchange this time, but he may find such abstinence harder in the next debate on October 11.

Mr Gore spent most of the evening playing to his strengths as a man familiar with the details of policy and experienced in government and foreign policy. He reeled off a bewildering list of figures on his and Mr Bush's tax plans, health-spending proposals and pension plans.

Asked about the situation in Serbia, the vice-president talked crisply about President Slobodan Milosevic, Montenegro and opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica, words which the syllabically challenged Republican candidate carefully avoided pronouncing, probably wisely.

Neither man made more than a passing mention of President Bill Clinton, but Mr Bush repeatedly tried to present himself as an outsider, presenting his lack of Washington experience as an asset, not a liability.

"You've had your chance, and nothing has been done," Mr Bush told his opponent.

Before the debate began, Mr Gore's press spokesman Chris Lehane promised a contest between "two competing visions, one for the many, the other for the few". It was a characterisation that Mr Gore repeatedly asserted throughout the longest single section of the debate, a back-and-forth on the candidates' tax and spending plans.

"He would spend more money on tax cuts for the wealthiest 1% than all of the new spending that he proposes for education, healthcare, prescription drugs and national defence combined," Mr Gore charged.

In an echo of a key issue from the past two presidential elections, the two candidates revealed sharp disagreements about abortion, with Mr Gore supporting women's rights to choice and Mr Bush defending "life for the unborn".

With the next president perhaps having the opportunity to fill as many as four vacancies on the nine-member US supreme court during the coming years, the issue of abortion was "on the ballot in this election", Mr Gore claimed.

Personal attacks were kept to a minimum until the last few minutes. As the debate drew to a close however, the moderator, Jim Lehrer, asked each man to say something about his opponent's character, drawing some critical personal comments from Mr Bush.

"I believe they've moved that sign 'The Buck Stops Here' from the oval office desk to 'The Buck Stops Here' on the Lincoln bedroom, and that's not good for the country," Mr Bush said.

"You may want to focus on scandals. I want to focus on results," responded his opponent.
