fields.headline: Montenegrin ally may shun runoff
fields.standfirst:
Opposition leader urges compromise

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic's political allies in Montenegro dealt the Yugoslav president a blow yesterday, saying they had not yet decided whether to take part in a second round of presidential elections.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic's political allies in Montenegro dealt the Yugoslav president a blow yesterday, saying they had not yet decided whether to take part in a second round of presidential elections.

Arguing that the people of Serbia had clearly signalled a desire for change, the deputy chairman of Montenegro's Socialist People's party (SNP) called on Mr Milosevic to reach a compromise with the opposition regarding the contested vote.

"I am worried and not very happy about what is happening in Serbia," Predrag Bulatovic said.

Mr Milosevic has insisted that a runoff ballot is needed in the presidential battle, rejecting assertions by the opposition leader, Vojislav Kostunica, that his party won an outright majority in the September 24 vote.

Without saying so directly, Mr Bulatovic indicated that he thought Mr Milosevic was in the wrong.

"It is obvious the people of Serbia want a change," he said.

Asked whether he was disappointed by the Yugoslav president's reaction to the poll, he said Mr Milosevic was facing his first election defeat.

"Everyone needs to get used to losing if they are a democrat," Mr Bulatovic said.

Montenegro is Serbia's last remaining partner in Yugoslavia and the SNP is the republic's only mainstream party to back Mr Milosevic.

The party's popularity has fallen in recent years thanks to its close links to the Serbian strongman, and it is currently languishing in opposition in the republic's parliament.

Montenegro's pro-western government boycotted last month's elections, claiming the ballot was illegal; turnout in Montenegro was just 28.5%, with 91.5% of votes going to Mr Milosevic's party.

The Serbian opposition has offered to make Mr Bulatovic prime minister if the SNP abandons Mr Milosevic ahead of the second-round vote, scheduled for October 8.

A tired and pale-looking Mr Bulatovic said he was not interested in the position and added that his party had already agreed that its leader and current federal prime minister, Momir Bulatovic, should stay on in the post.

However splits are opening within SNP ranks.

Momir Bulatovic, no relative of Predrag, announced on Monday he thought a second-round vote should take place.

However, the party's executive board met the same day and failed to agree on the need for a runoff ballot.

Another meeting is due in the next 48 hours.

"It is a very complex situation. We don't know if there will be a second round and we have still not decided if we shall participate in it," Predrag Bulatovic said, adding that continued election controversy would fuel secessionist fires in Montenegro.

He urged Mr Milosevic and Mr Kostunica to work out their differences, saying that if needed the Serb Orthodox Church or Russia could mediate.

"A compromise would be a great step forward for our democracy, but compromises are very rare among politicians of our country," he said.
Reuters

fields.headline: Rosie Douglas
fields.standfirst: A Caribbean radical, he finally came to power as island premier after a lifetime devoted to the cause of international black solidarity
fields.trailText: Rosie Douglas, who has died aged 58, became prime minister of the eastern Caribbean island of Dominica only eight months ago, having spent much of his political life travelling the world in support of liberation struggles, the black diaspora and African unity. And it was that international dimension which defined him, a perspective forged during his student days in Canada, where he was jailed following the smashing of a university computer during "black power" protests.
fields.body:
Rosie Douglas, who has died aged 58, became prime minister of the eastern Caribbean island of Dominica only eight months ago, having spent much of his political life travelling the world in support of liberation struggles, the black diaspora and African unity. And it was that international dimension which defined him, a perspective forged during his student days in Canada, where he was jailed following the smashing of a university computer during "black power" protests.

In a sense, Douglas came to power a generation too late, for he represented the now lost spirit of 1970s Caribbean radical movements. Yet Dominicans who celebrated Douglas's electoral win last January felt that he could somehow re-invent that legacy. They also hoped - as did Douglas himself - that his international connections would bring benefits to his banana-dependent island.

His background was not typical of Caribbean leaders of his generation. He was neither from the light-skinned elite nor the landless poor. His father had been a rich landowner, albeit from humble beginnings, who had made his money in Curacao'soil fields. The Douglas coconut estate was large and bountiful, in the north of the island, close to the second town, Portsmouth.

The second eldest of 16 children, Rosie was christened Roosevelt (there were other brothers named Eisenhower and Adenauer). He went to school in the capital, Roseau, before applying to study at university in Canada. Impatient of the long wait to receive a visa, he rang up the office of the Canadian prime minister, John Diefenbaker. The story goes that Diefenbaker was so impressed that he invited Douglas to meet him. So it was that Douglas's first political act in the dominion was to join the Canadian Young Conservatives.

But then everything changed. Douglas experienced racism. His education in Roseau had been colonial; he had been privileged. In Canada, he heard Martin Luther King speak and met black power leaders such as Stokeley Carmichael - who campaigned for Douglas in the 1990 Dominica election. Meanwhile Douglas studied agriculture at Ontario Agricultural College, and political science and economy at Sir George Williams University, Montreal.

Then, in 1969, by then a McGill University post-graduate, he led an anti-racism sit-in at Sir George Williams which led to the occupation of the computer centre and its destruction when police broke up the protest. Charged with arson, Douglas served 18 months in prison. When he was released, to be deported, as he would tell, in handcuffs and leg-irons, he said he would only return as "prime minister of my own country".

Back in Dominica, he began to develop that balancing act of participation both in domestic politics and on the wider, grander stage that characterised the rest of his life. He formed the short-lived Political Independence Committee, before becoming a senator during a turbulent period after independence in 1978. But he was sacked for inviting Cuban troops to Dominica after the devastations of Hurricane David in 1979; the United States had demanded the action in return for relief aid.

Douglas had begun to build on his old student contacts. He secured scholarships for Dominicans to Cuba and the Soviet Union. He made links with Colonel Gaddafi, and the Libyan leader's Little Green Book began to appear in Dominica, much to the alarm of rightwingers. Douglas saw Gaddafi as being able to offer financial support to liberation movements and became a key figure in the somewhat ill-defined Mataba, a Tripoli-based organisation, which offered aid, training and education to Africans.

Restless in his small island, Douglas went trouble-shooting in the interests of the Caribbean and the black diaspora. Active in the Socialist International, he also attended Sinn Fein's annual conference for many years. Despite his Libyan connections, he was close to the British Labour party - he was at its annual conference last week and the late Bernie Grant, the Labour MP, was a close friend.

Douglas became an MP in 1985, but he only became leader of the Dominica Labour party in 1992, after the death of his brother, Michael. His party lost the 1995 election and there was the feeling that his absences - his critics said he was always "up in the air" - diverted his energies. Nevertheless, this year, in January's election, he became prime minister in a coalition administration. At the opening of the new parliament, the guest list included Martin Luther King III. It was a glittering reflection of Douglas's long years in the service of black solidarity. Dominica had never seen anything like it.

Desperate to attract investors, he encouraged an enterprise culture and was keen to develop closer relations with the neighbouring French islands of Martinique and Guadeloupe, and thus with Europe. His oratory was inspiring, yet some felt disheartened by his inability to plan and pay attention to domestic details. Others were also disappointed at his pro-Japan line on whaling.

He remained close to the people. Unstuffy, speaking in Creole, patient and big-hearted, he would hear their troubles at any time at his two-storey red and white painted house in the middle of Portsmouth. He was proud, he said, to live "in the ghetto". And in the mornings, he jogged with the town youth or played basketball, while the official car sent to take him to his office had to wait. Yet to stay at home was not his way; only by globe-trotting, he said, would business come to Dominica.

He is survived by his mother Bernadette, three sons, Tiyani, Cabral and Kim, and one daughter, Deborah.

webTitle: Marriage aid 'will give most help to rich' most

fields.headline: Marriage aid 'will give most help to rich' most
fields.standfirst:
Benefits

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Treasury ministers yesterday denounced Conservative plans for a transferable personal allowance to recognise marriage in the benefit system, claiming the scheme would most help rich married couples and penalise single mothers. A third of the total cash would go to the richest 20% of couples with less than 5% going to the bottom 20%.
fields.body:
Treasury ministers yesterday denounced Conservative plans for a transferable personal allowance to recognise marriage in the benefit system, claiming the scheme would most help rich married couples and penalise single mothers. A third of the total cash would go to the richest 20% of couples with less than 5% going to the bottom 20%.

The Treasury also released figures asserting a family with two children on £15,000 a year would save £965 a year. By contrast the working families tax credit would give the same couple £2,200 a year.

The basis of the calculations will be challenged by the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, who insists his party is still debating the merits of the transferable personal allowance.

He maintained however at a fringe meeting that there was a strong case for targeting benefits on specific categories in need such as young families, or older pensioners. He insisted such targeting was different from means testing which tapered benefits on the basis of individual income, or savings. The Treasury attack came as Mr Willetts told his party conference pensioners want the respect and dignity comes from the basic contributory pension.

He was explaining Tory plans for an uprating in the basic pension in 2001 ranging from £5.50 for a single pensioner under 75 to £10 for a married couple over 75. Some of this will be funded from an extra £320m saved from eslewhere in the social security budget. He promised: "If Gordon Brown uprates the pension by more than inflation we will accept that and still add our reform package on top." He insisted pensioners did not want extra payments such as the winter fuel allowance which were seen as patronising gimmicks. "What they want is the respect and dignity that comes from the basic contributory pension. Labour claims that instead of putting money into the basic state pension they have put more into means tested benefits.

"I cannot imagine why they should want to boast that more pensioners will have to wrestle with the complicated 40 page form for their so called minimim income guarantee. It requires 323 separate items of information including such gems are you or or your partner pregnant?"

webTitle: Byers fines will boost renewable energy

fields.headline: Byers fines will boost renewable energy
fields.trailText: Electricity companies will face hefty fines for failing to meet environmental targets under proposals to be outlined today by the industry secretary, Stephen Byers.
fields.body:
Electricity companies will face hefty fines for failing to meet environmental targets under proposals to be outlined today by the industry secretary, Stephen Byers.

He will delight the green lobby by ruling out waste incineration from his definition of "renewables" and by putting the emphasis on new forms of energy such as wind power.

An early consultation document suggested a "buyout" fee of 2p per kilowatt-hour for those who failed to buy 5% of their supplies from renewable sources by 2003 and 10% by 2010. Well-placed sources say Mr Byers has privately accepted the need to charge a "buyout" fee of 3p per kilowatt hour, which will anger the electricity companies but please the renewable industry.

"We anticipate this will kickstart our sector, lead to over £5bn worth of capital investment and create thousands of jobs," said one executive from a renewable energy company.

Big companies such as National Wind Power, a division of Innogy (formerly National Power) and PowerGen Renewables will be among the beneficiaries.

Stephen Tindale, chief policy adviser to Greenpeace UK, said dropping incineration would put the government "back on the right trajectory after a series of disappointments". But the green lobby admits that further financial help might be needed and say electricity companies will pass on some of their extra costs to consumers.

The Department of Environment has had a target of 10% of electricity from renewables by 2010 for more than two years as part of the government's manifesto pledge to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 20% by the same date. But deregulation has forced the price of electricity down, helping gas-fired power stations but penalising the less competitive renewable sector.

Pearson to float Spanish group

Pearson will float 21% of Spanish subsidiary Grupo Recoletos on the stock exchange in Madrid later this month in an initial public offering that values Recoletos at €1.6bn-€1.9bn (£1bn-£1.1bn).

Recoletos will sell just over 7.5m new shares, 5.7% of its existing equity, and nearly 20.5m shares, including a tranche, owned by Pearson, according to the offer document approved yesterday by the Madrid exchange.

Recoletos owns sports newspaper Marca and financial newspaper Expansion among other assets.

Vodafone signs deal in China

Vodafone, Britain's largest mobile operator, said yesterday it would invest $2.5bn (£1.7bn) in China Mobile (Hong Kong) in an alliance with China's biggest wireless carrier.

The deal, which further strengthened ties between the two groups, sets out terms for cooperation between the two parties in mobile services, technology, operations and management, Vodafone said.

But the completion of Vodafone's equity investment was not dependent on the conclusion of the agreements set out in the alliance, Vodafone said, adding that CMHK would use the investment to finance the purchase of mobile assets around China.

Boeing signs up partners

Boeing said yesterday it has agreed to form a partnership with BFGoodrich and InterContinental Aircraft Services to develop a passenger-to-freighter conversion programme for the 737 aircraft.

The 737 "is the best selling jetliner of all time and is an ideal airplane to meet the needs of the feeder and niche freighter markets," said Joe Gullion, president of Boeing Airplane Services.

The worldwide fleet of freighter airplanes is expected to double during the next 20 years with more than 2,600 airplanes added, Boeing said. Nearly 70% of the additions will come from modified passenger and combination aeroplanes.

Boeing expects this will include about 250 737s.

Both BFGoodrich Aerospace and InterContinental, an alliance of big Taiwanese companies, are members of Boeing Airplane Services' international network of modification and engineering facilities.

Representatives from the three companies are jointly developing the configuration and engineering statement of work for modifying both the 737-300 and 400 model airplanes. In addition, a "quick change" option is being evaluated, which allows airlines to convert from freighter to passenger operations in a short period of time.

EU widens post office inquiry

The European commission said yesterday it had widened an anti-monopoly investigation launched against German post office Deutsche Post on August 8.

The European Union executive said that Deutsche Post's contracts with leading mail order customers contain a combination of loyalty and target rebates.

"Deutsche Post's rebate scheme means that no private provider of parcel services to mail order firms has been able to achieve any firm foothold in Germany," a commission statement said.

webTitle: Business: Bupa could be forced to split

fields.headline: Bupa could be forced to split
fields.standfirst: Competition commission lists options
fields.trailText: Private healthcare group Bupa could be forced to split into two as a condition of its £260m takeover of Community Hospitals, according to a list of options published by the competition commission yesterday.
fields.body:
Private healthcare group Bupa could be forced to split into two as a condition of its £260m takeover of Community Hospitals, according to a list of options published by the competition commission yesterday.

In the first stage of its investigation into the proposed acquisition, the commission held out the possibility of ordering Bupa to separate its insurance arm from its medical facilities businesses - which includes doctors' surgeries, hospitals and nursing homes.

The measure was the most severe suggestion on the list, which also included strengthening the arms' length relationship between the two divisions, or ordering Bupa to sell a number of hospitals.

Bupa announced in April that it wanted to buy the 21-strong Community Hospitals network, to expand its own chain of 36 hospitals. Trade secretary Stephen Byers ordered an inquiry into the deal in June, following intensive lobbying by the Consumers' Association and the British Medical Association.

If the transaction goes ahead, Bupa will control one in four of Britain's private hospitals. Critics fear that the organisation could block access to patients from other healthcare insurers or charge higher rates to non-Bupa members.

A Bupa spokeswoman brushed aside the commission's statement yesterday, saying that it was a "blue-sky list of hypothetical options".

She said: "We have made it clear that we will co-operate fully with the investigation."

Bupa insists that it maintains strict "Chinese walls" between its insurance arm and its facilities, and says there is no question of discriminating against patients from other insurers. The group sees the acquisition of Community Hospitals as central to its strategy and is keen to proceed if it can find a way of satisfying regulators.

By owning more hospitals, Bupa believes it can make savings through economies of scale, as well as guaranteeing the quality of healthcare provided to its members. The group says competition concerns were dealt with fully last year in a report by the office of fair trading into the healthcare sector.

Bupa already owns 27% of Community Hospitals.

In its submission to the OFT objecting to the deal, the BMA said Bupa was acting with "the sole intention of reducing overall capacity in order that Bupa hospitals can subsequently increase their charges."

fields.headline: At this price?  Lastminute.com
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com, Britain's highest profile net stock, was back in focus yesterday on the back of a positive analyst's note. After meeting the youthful management, Lehman Brothers came away talking the stock up and forecasting "a blow-out" third quarter.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com, Britain's highest profile net stock, was back in focus yesterday on the back of a positive analyst's note. After meeting the youthful management, Lehman Brothers came away talking the stock up and forecasting "a blow-out" third quarter.

Analyst Heidi Fitzpatrick says July and August were record months and subscriber numbers "continue to see traction". She expects gross revenue estimates of £11.2m to be beaten and believes the recent Degriftour acquisition will bring forward profitability by about six months to the beginning of 2003.

But the main reason for her update is the 40% slump in shares in Priceline of the US. Lastminute has often been compared to Priceline but Ms Fitzpatrick says the Americans are far more dependent on airline ticket sales.

Weak sales due to higher fuel charges have been cited as the cause of Priceline's share price fall. A high number of cancelled flights compounded the effects of a $20 surcharge imposed in early September by the airlines because of rising fuel prices.

Some 80% of Priceline's revenues come from flights; for Lastminute the figure is 20%. "We would not apply Priceline's difficulties to Lastminute. Instead we feel that the Lastminute.com story is more compelling than ever," Ms Fitzpatrick says.

"Lastminute has been more successful than Priceline in developing its non-airline verticals, including holidays, hotels, entertainment tickets, gifts and auctions. Lastminute continues to grow its supplier base in all categories, not just airlines."

Despite positive vibes, the jury remains out. The rally in the shares since May appears to have petered out. Since the start of last month the price has fallen from around 190p to last night's close of 138p, up 0.5p on the day.

The shares remain perilously close to their all-time low of 120p. Only the brave should think about taking the plunge.

webTitle: Business: Telewest picks up Orange executive

fields.headline: Telewest picks up Orange executive
fields.trailText: Telewest, which has been laid low by a series of mishaps over the past few months, was hoping for a reversal of fortunes yesterday when it named Bob Fuller as chief executive of its cable division.
fields.body:
Telewest, which has been laid low by a series of mishaps over the past few months, was hoping for a reversal of fortunes yesterday when it named Bob Fuller as chief executive of its cable division.

Mr Fuller, 53, joins from mobile phone company Orange where he had been chief operating officer since 1997. He had been employed by the Hutchison Group, the Hong Kong conglomerate which started Orange, for 18 years.

Adam Singer, Telewest group chief executive said: "It is a serious coup for Telewest to have got its hands on top-flight talent and experience like Bob's. His operational skills and strategic thinking will underpin and accelerate our plans to exploit our network. His background in mobile telephony brings exactly the right cultural values that a fixed-wire business badly needs - a relentless focus on brand building, customer acquisition and customer service."

One of his first priorities will be to get the company's digital services moving again after a three-month delay due a shortage of set top boxes.

Mr Fuller replaces Tony Illsley, who had run Telewest before its merger with Flextech, the owner of pay television channels including UK Gold and UK Play. Mr Illsley left the company shortly after the merger owing to dissatisfaction at having to be number two in the organisation.

Mr Fuller will be responsible for all Telewest's network services - both residential and business. Despite the merger of Flextech and Telewest, the two sides of the company are still run fairly autonomously.

Before becoming chief operating officer at Orange, he held the post of commercial director, where he was in charge of customer service, logistics, sales and marketing.

Shares in Telewest were worth 563p in March but have fallen to 138p, down a further 4.5p yesterday.

fields.headline: Beer comes cheapest in north-west
fields.trailText: The north-west of England has Britain's cheapest beer and drinkers are being fleeced by a north-south price divide, according to the Good Pub Guide 2001.
fields.body:
The north-west of England has Britain's cheapest beer and drinkers are being fleeced by a north-south price divide, according to the Good Pub Guide 2001.

A locally brewed pint of bitter in Lancashire, Greater Manchester and Merseyside costs on average £1.16, compared to £1.67 in Surrey and £1.68 in London.

Out of 1,335 pubs, researchers found the highest prices in Surrey, Berkshire and Buckinghamshire. The cheapest after Lancashire were in Cheshire, Worcestershire and Derbyshire.

The average cost of a pint of bitter across Britain was £1.59. In Scotland the average was £1.51.

Rob Unsworth, associate editor of the guide, said: "The drinker is losing out. Even with economic differences accounted for by the north-south divide there is no real explanation for such a discrepancy in beer prices."

He said brewers of some large pub chains were overcharging for beer.

"The difference must come down to the fact that some big brewers have a stranglehold because some pubs are tied to their beer. Smaller breweries are getting bought out or going out of business because drinkers are not recognising the low prices."

fields.headline: Bowbelle's warning 'not heard'
fields.standfirst:
More about the Marchioness disaster
Marine Accident Investigation Branch
Thames Safety Inquiry: Lord Justice Clarke's Report
fields.trailText: The forward lookout on the dredger Bowbelle on the night it collided with the Marchioness in 1989 claimed yesterday that the pleasure boat changed direction to cross into the path of the larger vessel.
fields.body:
The forward lookout on the dredger Bowbelle on the night it collided with the Marchioness in 1989 claimed yesterday that the pleasure boat changed direction to cross into the path of the larger vessel.

Terence Blayney told the formal public investigation into the disaster, in which 51 died, that the Marchioness "turned to port as if to head through the centre of the arches that we were going through as we approached, and bang, we just hit her.

"I thought she would have kept out of our way or waited until we had gone through. I was screaming and shouting and whistling at the Marchioness to try to draw attention to us. There was a fellow standing inside the upper deck (aboard Marchioness).

"He was waving. I didn't know whether he was telling us to get out of the way, which we couldn't, or just waving."

Asked under cross-examination if there had been an opportunity for the Marchioness to get out of the way Mr Blayney said: "If he had put the wheel over to starboard and sped up a bit, he could have gone clear, but it would have been a very close thing."

The inquiry continues.

fields.headline: Toxic fears over suntan lotions
fields.trailText: A chemical used in 90% of suntan lotions worldwide might be toxic, according to new research by a team of Norwegian scientists.
fields.body:
A chemical used in 90% of suntan lotions worldwide might be toxic, according to new research by a team of Norwegian scientists.

And exposure to the sun could make the UVB filter octyl methoxycinnamate (OMC) even more deadly, according to a report published in New Scientist magazine.

Tests conducted by the Norwegian radiation protection authority found that half of mouse cells died when they came into contact with a weak dose of OMC, at a much lower concentration than is used in most of the world's sunscreens.

Shining a lamp on the OMC-impregnated cells, to simulate sunshine, made the chemical twice as deadly.

NRPA biophysicist Terji Christensen warned sunbathers to use sunscreens with caution.

The Cosmetic Toiletry and Perfumery Association said OMC had been "thoroughly tested for safety".

fields.headline: SAS author attacks war accounts
fields.trailText: A former senior SAS soldier has criticised the accounts of exploits which his colleagues have given in bestselling books about the role of Britain's special forces in the 1991 Gulf war.
fields.body:
A former senior SAS soldier has criticised the accounts of exploits which his colleagues have given in bestselling books about the role of Britain's special forces in the 1991 Gulf war.

In Eye of the Storm, published today, Peter Ratcliffe, an SAS regimental sergeant major at the time, accuses them either of making questionable claims or of indulging in "every exercise in wishful thinking".

Mr Ratcliffe, who retired from the SAS in 1997 with the rank of major, insisted on using his own name, the cause of one of many disputes with the Ministry of Defence which delayed the publication of his book for five months.

He says SAS soldiers had no need to embellish their involvement in what he admits were dramatic events.

Mr Ratcliffe questions accounts of firefights with Iraqi troops, which, he says, were not mentioned in official debriefings by SAS soldiers after the Gulf war.

He criticises former SAS soldiers for apparently ignoring advice that his patrol should take a vehicle when it was dropped behind Iraqi lines. He also criticises the patrol for trying to escape to Syria in the north-west, rather than south towards Saudi Arabia, where they were more likely to be rescued.

Mr Ratcliffe said yesterday that he felt let down by the SAS for not defending him against attacks in some of the books by his former colleagues.

Michael O'Mara, his publisher, said the MoD had threatened him with injunctions, asking him to omit passages, including information in the public domain.

webTitle: Scientists alarmed by speed of plant mutation near Chernobyl

fields.headline: Scientists alarmed by speed of plant mutation near Chernobyl
fields.trailText: Plants grown in contaminated soil near the Chernobyl nuclear power station in Ukraine have mutated at a much faster rate than expected.
fields.body:
Plants grown in contaminated soil near the Chernobyl nuclear power station in Ukraine have mutated at a much faster rate than expected.

Researchers from Switzerland, Britain and Ukraine warn in an article in the latest edition of the journal Nature that their experiments show that the effects of radiation on plants are not well understood and may be more severe than was previously thought.

The scientific team, led by Olga Kovalchuk from the Friedrich Miescher Institute in Basel, planted identical crops of wheat in two locations - one on a highly radioactive plot close to Chernobyl, the other in uncontaminated but otherwise similar soil 19 miles away. They then grew further crops from the seeds of each set of wheat.

Even though the plants close to the nuclear power station were exposed to radiation for only 10 months, the genes of the crop raised from this seed showed a sixfold increase in the mutation rate compared with the normal wheat.

What alarmed the scientists was that the wheat growing in the radioactive area was exposed to relatively low doses of radiation.

"This low-level exposure should not cause such a large increase in the mutation rate, suggesting that chronic exposure to ionising radiation has effects that are as yet unknown," they wrote in Nature.

The scientists do not believe the mutations could have been caused directly by a weak blast of radiation hitting the plants' DNA.

They suspect that some so far unidentified mechanism is affecting genes by upsetting the delicate mechanism of the plant cells as a whole.

The findings have troubling implications for future generations of plants, animals and humans living in and around the Chernobyl contamination zone, created in 1986 when one of the four reactors on the site exploded.

So far the only undisputed medical effect of the disaster has been a big rise in the number of cases of child and adolescent thyroid cancer in the regions of Ukraine, Belarus and Russia adjacent to Chernobyl.

But scientists fear that the worst consequences of Chernobyl will only emerge in future generations.

The disaster has had mixed consequences for the environment around the power station. In the short term the area, evacuated of human beings, has become a haven for wildlife. The danger now is from clumps of radioactive particles which were blown across Ukraine and Belarus by the wind and fell to earth.

But the of radioactive mutations - the generation of hideous monsters and giant insects - is unlikely to occur, since even with radiation speeding up changes in DNA, it would still take many generations for evolution to pick out useful new genes which would enable new species to emerge and survive.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Yojimbo | Primary Colors | Flesh And Blood | Red Heat
fields.body:
Yojimbo

(Akira Kurosawa, 1961)

6pm, FilmFour

A wandering samurai in 18th-century Japan arrives in a town that's ruled by two warring gangs. Siding with one, he plays them off against each other, right up to the point of mutual destruction. Director Kurosawa handles the frequent action scenes vigorously, and his old hand Toshiro Mifune is certainly a muscular ronin. If the story seems familiar to you, it's probably because it was remade both as A Fistful Of Dollars by Sergio Leone and as Last Man Standing by Walter Hill.

Primary Colors

(Mike Nichols, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

Funny, clever adaptation of the bestselling satirical novel that digs the dirt on Bill Clinton's 1990 campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. Some wonderful performances - Kathy Bates' lesbian troubleshooter, Billy Bob Thornton's adviser, Emma Thompson as the wife - but John Travolta's (pictured), as governor Jack Stanton, isn't one of them, never suggesting why anyone would ever actually vote for him.

Flesh And Blood

(Paul Verhoeven, 1985)

10pm, FilmFour

Plenty of flesh and blood in Verhoeven's rough and ready American debut feature, a medieval adventure packed with combat, pillage, rape and plague. In the full-blooded fight scenes you might just see hints of the future Robocop and Starship Troopers, but this is really only a middling middle-ages epic.

Red Heat

(Walter Hill, 1988)

10.10pm, UK Gold

Hill does his bit for glasnost with a typically crunching action tale that brings Arnold Schwarzenegger's Moscow cop to Chicago, on the trail of beastly drug dealer Viktor (Ed O'Ross). webTitle: Culture clash at heart of the party

fields.headline: Culture clash at heart of the party
fields.standfirst:
Tolerance: Portillo's plea exposes critical divide

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo's emotional appeal for tolerance, ethnic diversity and social inclusion may have won him a standing ovation at the Tory conference on Tuesday. But not everyone in the hall was pleased. "Tony Blair in Tory clothing," one irritated delegate whispered to his neighbour.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo's emotional appeal for tolerance, ethnic diversity and social inclusion may have won him a standing ovation at the Tory conference on Tuesday. But not everyone in the hall was pleased. "Tony Blair in Tory clothing," one irritated delegate whispered to his neighbour.

The irritation surfaced in a more public manner on Radio 4's Today programme yesterday. Asked what she thought about the shadow chancellor's talk of social tolerance - notably for gays, but also for black and brown Britons - Ann Widdecombe briskly replied: "I have never quite been sure what is meant by that phrase, social tolerance."

There was little doubt that the shadow home secretary's breezy reply was aimed at delegates and - beyond Bournemouth - voters who dislike the new, touchy-feely Portillo. They preferred the old SAS version.

Miss Widdecombe had already shown her disapproval in a more practical way, according to gossip circulating in the press room. She had moved to bump her rival's speech off the front page of yesterday's Daily Telegraph by briefing selected reporters - on her own initiative - on her latest drugs initiative soon after he sat down. Mr Portillo knew nothing of the crackdown until told by reporters. Unsurprisingly, he disapproves.

The very gay people and black people he sought to include in William Hague's big tent are certain to have their share of drug users, whose recreational gear might cost them a £100 fine if stopped by the police, as they so disproportionately are.

How serious is this renewed culture war in the Tory ranks between its liberal, even libertarian tendency and its social authoritarians? As Mr Hague struggles to find a new language in which to address disaffected, disrespectful voters it is potentially very serious - both with the voters and with those who may seek to wrest the leadership from him after the coming election.

Though he dabbles in rightwing populism few who know Mr Hague well doubt that he is anything but a privately tolerant man for whom Norman Tebbit's viscerally narrow agenda - cricket tests and all - is unpalatable as well as outdated. This week the internet is (as usual) awash with dodgy allegations about the private lives of "Tory hypocrites". Some colleagues believe Mr Portillo is the genuinely chastened man he appears to be precisely because he has been on the receiving end of some brutal social exclusion in the tabloids over his youthful sexual adventures.

His chastened mood, they muse, suggest he fears the newspaper files are not yet empty. Certainly he does not disport himself like a threat to Hague who has brought the Tories back from the near-dead, if not yet to electability.

Mr Hague's instinct for social tolerance is buttressed by key staff at Tory HQ, policy advisers like Danny Finkelstein ( ex-SDP) and Sebastian Coe and by the bulk of the shadow cabinet. Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, made a similar plea for inclusivity to Portillo's on the same day. He too has been on what Mr Portillo called a long journey: his gay brother died of Aids. The likes of Michael Ancram, David Willetts, Theresa May and Archie Norman are up for tolerance too.

Steve Norris, still a player in the party, showed the way forward in his inclusive campaign for London mayor.

They will prevail if Mr Hague survives the coming election with a decent result, a Labour majority halved for instance. Tory MPs are also increasingly aware that another reason for keeping him is that the post-Hague leadership battle would probably be Portillo against Widdecombe. Under Mr Hague's own rule book activists would then ballot on the winner. That is the underlying signficance of this week's conference beauty parade. "They'd pick Ann," murmur alarmed MPs.

John Redwood, ousted, then reinstated and still ambitious, is instinctively a Widdecomber. So is smooth Iain Duncan Smith, the Tory defence spokesman for whose speech Lady Thatcher got up early for, a sign of favour. He wants the armed forces exempt from the Human Rights Act, he said this week.

Andrew Lansley, the shadow cabinet's policy wonk, is a Tebbit protege. Other lesser lights think that way and many party activists and voters. Above all Miss Widdecombe - 53 yesterday - articulate, feisty, brave and rightwing, shows increasing signs of believing her own publicity.

Could I be leader, she must ask herself in the mirror ? Why not, Margaret was, comes back the answer. Is Miss Widdecombe, for all her popular virtues, the politician to take the Tories back to power? MPs ask each other. No. Tony Blair would be delighted by the prospect. So the Widdecombe-Portillo spat has one immediate benefit. It helps secure Mr Hague in his job.

Libertarians v authoritarians

Opposing voices in the Tory ranks

Michael Portillo
"We are a party for people, not against people. We are for all Britons: black Britons, British Asians, white Britons. Britain is a country of rich diversity... We are for people whatever their sexual orientation. The Conservative party isn't merely a party of tolerance: it's a party willing to accord every one of our citizens respect."
October 3 2000

Francis Maude
"Our party has always contained its representative share of gays, including my late brother. A national party has to be serious about being inclusive and tolerant. Tolerance is not an optional addition to this party's values; it is an absolutely vital part of it which sustains us." October 3 Steven Norris Policies such as support for section 28 are no more than "homophobic nonsense - and the gay community know it."
October 4 2000

Ann Widdecombe
"I have never quite been sure what is meant by that phrase social tolerance. What I believe is that the state should have a preferred model, that it should promote the traditional family."
October 4 2000

Iain Duncan Smith
On gays in the forces: "I believe, as the previous government did, that we should follow the advice of the armed forces, which has always been that lifting the ban would adversely affect operational effectiveness."
January 2000

fields.headline: Poetic justice
fields.trailText: As the literature programmer at an arts centre I am heavily involved in that "marketing" of poetry which Robert Potts so much despises (The curse of light verse, October 4).
fields.body:
As the literature programmer at an arts centre I am heavily involved in that "marketing" of poetry which Robert Potts so much despises (The curse of light verse, October 4). As part of today's National Poetry Day celebrations, staff will be reading poems of their choice around the centre. The poems chosen range from an ode by Keats through Lewis Carroll to Brian Patten and Seamus Heaney. When we held a rehearsal the atmosphere of shared pleasure in what language can do was palpable.
Sibyl Ruth
Midlands Arts Centre

webTitle: European court to rule on rights of transsexuals

fields.headline: European court to rule on rights of transsexuals
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: A former NHS nurse's legal challenge to entitle her transsexual "husband" to benefit from her pension if she dies was yesterday referred to the European court of justice by the court of appeal.
fields.body:
A former NHS nurse's legal challenge to entitle her transsexual "husband" to benefit from her pension if she dies was yesterday referred to the European court of justice by the court of appeal.

The nurse, who cannot be named, contends that the NHS pension scheme discriminates against her and her partner, who was born a woman, on grounds of sex. She also argues that the denial of a survivor's pension breaches the European convention on human rights, incorporated into UK law this week.

Since same-sex partners cannot legally marry, and transsexuals cannot marry someone of their own birth sex, both groups are excluded by rules that reserve survivors' pensions for married partners.

The court ordered anonymity for the nurse, who sat at the back of the courtroom without her partner. The pair, both in their 40s, live in the west country. They went through an adapted Church of England marriage ceremony conducted by a minister with the approval of a bishop who knew of their case.

Laura Cox QC, representing the nurse, told Lords Justices Aldous, Brooke and Sedley that the case had been referred to them by the employment appeal tribunal because of the "fundamental human rights" elements. "This court must rule on the extent to which the respondent [Alan Milburn, the health secretary] violates European convention rights."

The Human Rights Act, which came into force on Monday, incorporates the European convention on human rights into English law, making it enforceable in the English courts.

Ms Cox said her client, a nurse and care manager for 20 years, was backed by the pressure group Justice and the equal opportunities commission, which believed the refusal to allow her partner a survivor's pension was direct discrimination.

The employment appeal tribunal had held that they were barred from ruling in the nurse's favour by an earlier judgment denying travel benefits to the same sex partner of a railway worker.

Like same-sex partners, the nurse and her partner are unable to overcome their problem by marrying. The government is considering a change in the law, but at present legal sex is fixed at birth and the nurse's partner is considered legally female.

Ms Cox said the partner "lives as a man, presents as a man and to all intents and purposes the couple present to the world as man and wife".

She said 5,000 people in the UK were recognised as transsexuals, a recognised medical condition called gender dysphoria which can be treated by altering the body with drugs and operations.

He had gone through a "lengthy and painful process of treatment and operations" to be able to live in his true gender identity. The pair were not same sex partners but a man and woman in a heterosexual relationship.

"The European court of human rights has expressly acknowledged how serious are the problems caused to transsexuals by the continued refusal of the UK government to allow them to amend their birth certificates, to acknowledge their true gender and permit them to get married," Ms Cox said.

Lord Justice Aldous commented during the case: "In reality this person is a man."

The case will come back to the appeal court once the Luxembourg court has ruled on the questions of European law.

fields.headline: Same goal
fields.trailText: I was intrigued to read that Peter Ridsdale, chairman of Leeds United football club, is to run the city's new education service (Football chief to run school body, October 3). Last December, the secretary of state asked me to perform a similar function for Leicester.
fields.body:
I was intrigued to read that Peter Ridsdale, chairman of Leeds United football club, is to run the city's new education service (Football chief to run school body, October 3). Last December, the secretary of state asked me to perform a similar function for Leicester. I am delighted to report that not only has substantial progress been made in modernising the education department, but also that Leicester City football club is currently top of the Premier League. Perhaps the link between education and football has not been sufficiently recognised in recent education policy statements. No doubt we can now look forward to improvements in education in Leeds schools being matched by the performance of their football team.
Prof David Hopkins
Leicester Partnership Board

fields.headline: Bald facts
fields.trailText: On behalf of all baldies, I take issue with John O'Farrell's offensive column (October 4). He quotes his brother as saying about William Hague that he is a "bald-headed prat". Apparently Mr Hague's lack of hair is why "voters will not vote for him". If Mr Hague was disabled, would he have referred to him as a "disabled prat"?
fields.body:
On behalf of all baldies, I take issue with John O'Farrell's offensive column (October 4). He quotes his brother as saying about William Hague that he is a "bald-headed prat". Apparently Mr Hague's lack of hair is why "voters will not vote for him". If Mr Hague was disabled, would he have referred to him as a "disabled prat"? If he was gay would the Guardian have allowed him to be referred to as a "gay prat"? How do you think such offensive remarks go down with the parents of the thousands of children who suffer alopecia? Or for that matter with people going through chemotherapy and other treatments that result in loss of hair.

I hold no brief for Mr Hague - and I'm quite capable of dealing with insults myself. But there are many people who suffer from baldness who find remarks like this extremely upsetting. I thought you ought to be told.
David Yelland
Editor, The Sun

fields.headline: Inject some sense into drugs debate
fields.trailText: Concerns about the anti-heroin fungus (Anti-heroin fungus 'could be a disaster', October 2) have centred on ecological risks and legal questions, assuming that destroying poppy harvests will end the problem of opiate addiction.
fields.body:
Concerns about the anti-heroin fungus (Anti-heroin fungus 'could be a disaster', October 2) have centred on ecological risks and legal questions, assuming that destroying poppy harvests will end the problem of opiate addiction. If the fungus proved effective, a large reduction in supply could raise heroin street prices and lower purity levels, perhaps attracting fewer new users, but synthetic alternatives could easily fill the gap. Buprenorphine, a synthetic opiate, has gained great popularity in Scotland and there seems to be no shortage of criminal expertise to develop new substances for such purposes. And the alternatives may prove more dangerous, as did temazepam in Glasgow during the city's heroin shortage in the 80s.

The effects on the legal opium crop supplying medicinal morphine, heroin and codeine also appear to have been ignored. How will it be protected from these spores?
Sarah Mars
London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine
John Witton
National Addiction Centre

 The brutal economics of the illegal drug market mean crop eradication efforts can never succeed. The vast profits to be made means that when crops are destroyed production simply moves. Since crop eradication began in Colombia (using powerful herbicides) tens of thousands of acres of coca crops have been destoyed, yet total cocaine production has increased threefold. The US has long used the "war on drugs" as a smokescreen for military agendas in South America (and elsewhere). It is deeply worrying that the UK and the UN have been drawn into this nasty business.
Steve Rolles
Transform

 The Tories are right (Hard line against soft drug users, October 4) to condemn cannabis as the cause of untold misery - addiction, thousands of deaths in motor accidents, cirrhosis of the liver, domestic violence, hooliganism, brain damage. I raise my 14th pint of beer to Tory common sense.
Martin Johnson
Crows Nest, New South Wales

 Presumably Jack Straw will soon be proposing a £150 fine for possessing cannabis.
Dave Hanson Hull

fields.headline: British webs of success
fields.trailText: Over the past year we've launched a rash of initiatives to get the UK online by 2005. A big part of this has been measures to improve government's web presence and the services we provide (Web-master-general, October 3). On September 11, the prime minister launched UK online, backed up by £1bn in funding to get government online as well as people and business.
fields.body:
Over the past year we've launched a rash of initiatives to get the UK online by 2005. A big part of this has been measures to improve government's web presence and the services we provide (Web-master-general, October 3). On September 11, the prime minister launched UK online, backed up by £1bn in funding to get government online as well as people and business.

The centrepiece is a new report, e.gov: electronic government services for the 21st century. It puts in place incentives, levers and institutional structures to make sure the transformation happens in Whitehall. A third of government services are already online. These are being improved, and new ones developed all the time. Within the next year you will be able to learn subjects like maths and Japanese; apply for Employment Service jobs; and forecast your pension online. The quality of our sites is improving at pace. New guidelines on navigation, design and access have been welcomed by the private sector and organisations like the Royal National Institute for the Blind.
Ian McCartney MP
Cabinet Office minister

 The suggestion that FT.com turned down an offer to outsource our site development and pressed ahead with doing the job ourselves, with the assistance of some small subcontractors, is simply wrong (Notebook, October 3).

Huw van Steenis of JP Morgan named FT.com as one of the few European websites that were better than their US equivalents. Visits to the site and advertising revenues are two to three times higher than a year ago. Every day 1.5m FT.com pages are seen by 140,000 users. Our site is visited by over 1m individuals per month. This is one of Britain's great internet success stories.
Peter Martin
Editorial director, FT Internet Activities

fields.headline: Dead men walking
fields.trailText: A History Of Britain | The OJ Simpson Story | The Dream Academy
fields.body:
Why do I picture Tostig as being sandy, small and rather short-changed in the neck department?

The Norman Conquest turns out to be all Tostig's fault. Simon Schama's exhilarating A History Of Britain (BBC 2) has now reached 1066 and all that when "History comes at you with a rush, a truckload of trouble." Ganging up with the Viking Harald Hardrada, who sounds like rocks on a corrugated iron roof and looked like a large lump of Norway that had come adrift, Tostig invaded the north, forcing his brother, King Harold, to take his eye off William, who was pawing the ground in the south.

Harold virtually ran up the length of England and met the invaders at Stamford Bridge, where he reduced Tostig's already short stature by a head. Here's a taste of Schama in action: "What they saw on the banks of the river Derwent was not a forlorn group of hostages but a massive army, their weapons glittering like sheets of ice, as the Viking bard put it. Tostig knew it meant trouble. It was his Big Brother."

You want to put in your thumb and pull out particularly juicy plums in case they are missed in the gulping rush. "Humming with energetic piety...", "Impotence has its uses...", "A nauseating chorus of congratulation..." and, suddenly dipping into Yiddish like a plane hitting an air pocket, "Well, how much trouble was he in now!" Schama talks of Norman soldiers nervously fingering their chainmail before battle, and William, at the height of the fight, throwing back his helmet to show he is still alive. If a legend has poetic truth, in it goes, like the grieving image of Edith Swan-neck, Harold's lover, walking through heaps of corpses to identify the dead king by marks on his body known only to her. You can judge a man by the care that is taken of his corpse. When William died, his body was robbed and left to rot.

A ripping and, at times, downright distressing yarn about treachery, embroidery, brotherly hate, battle axes and income tax.

The OJ Simpson Story (BBC 1) explores new clues and possible culprits, including the notion that Nicole was killed because she cut a dinner party. Bill Dear, a chattily tenacious private detective, believes OJ to be innocent. "I could not picture myself killing my ex-wife and leaving my two minor children to walk out and see the mother lying there nearly decapitated. Nobody as a parent could do that." That clears Lord Lucan then.

Dear has his private eye on OJ's troublesome son, Jason, who was never interviewed by the police about Nicole's murder. Jason is young, muscular and, as a chef, carries his own knives. He suffers from intermittent rage disorder, though not as much as the girlfriends and restaurant owner he assaulted. On the night of the murder, according to Dear, he prepared dinner for Nicole and a party of ten at the restaurant where he worked. They never came. "Jason had to be embarrassed that night. God, that had to hurt!" If there is any truth in Dear's theory, then OJ is halfway to a hero.

Just when you are thinking "OK, it's Jason. Can I go now?" it veered off on quite another tack, the miasmic underworld of cocaine and contract killing. A drug dealer now doing 20 years ("with the bad and the baddest") for armed robbery claimed to have been offered $50,000 by a shadowy "friend of OJ" to kill Nicole - and refused.

The badly bitten LAPD shies away from the whole mess but, until it is cleared up, it will attract flies.

The Dream Academy (BBC 1) followed four students of the Italia Conti theatre school ("Very, very gently this afternoon we start humming.") Ben has a fine voice and can command a loyal coachload of Sunderland supporters when he appears in the West End. Tim is the back end of a cow in Wolverhampton ("I wanted to be the front end but they said no.") Kelli knows it cheers you up to kick critics who did not like Othello, the musical ("I just wanted to say, 'Did you actually watch the show?'") And Georgia, my favourite, could go on as an Essex Eeyore without rehearsal ("I work on a Sunday at B and Q and I can't stand it... Blokes come up and ask you how to fit loft insulation.") She was, much to her surprise, chosen to give a belting rendition of "Oom pah pah" from Oliver - in St Paul's of all places. "Thank God it's over," groaned Georgia, as heartfelt a prayer as ever Paul's heard.

fields.headline: Secret war on miners
fields.trailText: Seumas Milne's reference to hauliers rampaging through miners' picket lines stirred many memories (What Stella left out, October 2). While many know of the misuses of the law in the course of the strike, how many are aware of the ongoing hardship suffered by men still victimised?
fields.body:
Seumas Milne's reference to hauliers rampaging through miners' picket lines stirred many memories (What Stella left out, October 2). While many know of the misuses of the law in the course of the strike, how many are aware of the ongoing hardship suffered by men still victimised? Over 40 men are so effectively blacklisted that they have never been able to work after 15 years. In addition, there are many men who lost several years of employment because of the bloody-minded attitude of the Coal Board and the Tory government. Many of these men were convicted as a result of the dirty tricks campaign referred to by Milne. We had hoped to see some significant changes under a Labour government but so far there has been very little movement.

All we now ask for is these men to be given pension credits for their lost years. This money would not come from the Exchequer but from the miners pension scheme. That there are sufficient funds to meet this is shown by the fact that this government has, in the past three years, taken out of the fund £250m in "actuarial surpluses". In May, the DTI issued a 17-page consultation document on this issue but to date there has been no real movement. These men should at least have a reasonable retirement to look forward to.
Rick Sumner
National Justice for Mineworkers Campaign

What is frightening is not MI5's role in the miners' strike, that was to be expected, but MI5's apparent lack of action in the recent hauliers' and farmers' blockade. The secret police has to be and to be seen to be an agency of the elected government. From Milne's article there is reason to doubt whether this is the case.
Mike Woolliscroft
Holt, Norfolk

fields.headline: A fistful of dollars
fields.standfirst: If there's one unbreakable rule in films, it's this: never invest your own cash. If only somebody had told singer Dwight Yoakam. Because he might end up counting the cost of putting his money where his mouth is.  Clark Collis reports
fields.trailText: If there's one unbreakable rule in films, it's this: never invest your own cash. If only somebody had told singer Dwight Yoakam. Because he might end up counting the cost of putting his money where his mouth is. Clark Collis reports
fields.body:
One of cinema's greatest tale-tellers, it's easy to imagine that spaghetti western maestro Sergio Leone would have been a hoot when it came to inventing bedtime stories. In fact, though, when someone happened to find the director sending one of his girls to the land of nod while making For A Few Dollars More, they didn't hear him intoning a story, but words of fiscal wisdom.

"The first thing to learn", Sergio told the kid, "is never put a cent of your own money into a picture." It's advice that Dwight Yoakam may soon wish someone had given him at a formative age. Because the country singer recently sold his $825,000 Malibu home to help finance the movie South Of Heaven, West Of Hell, which he wrote, directed and stars in alongside Billy Bob Thornton, Vince Vaughn and Bridget Fonda. The movie, Yoakam's debut stab at directing, finds him playing a veteran of the Spanish Civil War, and was apparently inspired by Westerns like One-Eyed Jacks and Pat Garrett And Billy The Kid - neither of which, it has to be said, exactly set box-office cash tills ringing when they were originally released.

And Yoakam isn't the first person to fund a movie out of his own pocket.

Indeed, unless they already have some development deal it's customary for producers to pay seed money for scripts, location-scouting and a lot of expensive lunches in the hope that this will impress the money men enough to sign on the dotted line. When Untouchables producer Art Linson was trying to persuade Universal to pony up for his Hunter S Thompson adaptation Where The Buffalo Roam, for example, he paid for the notorious gonzo journalist to stay in a pricey LA hotel. It was a decision that soon began to melt his Amex card, as Linson recalls in his autobiography A Pound Of Flesh: "The first thing I noticed in the room was a gashing four-inch hole in the wall by the side of a picture above the couch. 'What's with the hole?' I shouted through to the bedroom where [Thompson] had gone to change. 'It was an accident.' He reappeared holding a gun. 'This wasn't supposed to carry past 15 feet.' He walked off seven paces from the wall, turned, and fired. Another gaping hole blasted through the wallpaper. 'Christ', he said, 'these specifications can't be trusted.' My hand instinctively reached for my wallet."

Of course, helping to finance a film can also enable film-makers to keep control of their movies. A theory most recently proven by James Cameron, who initially agreed to waive his titanic Titanic fee when it looked like the ship was about to go down with a brace of movie companies on deck.

"Yeah, that definitely shows the advantages of putting in our own money," agrees British producer Gregor Truter, who's just completed his debut movie Lava. "Because once it stops being one man's vision, that becomes a very dangerous situation. Once it becomes filming by committee you're in all sorts of trouble. I mean, I didn't like Titanic, but it is Cameron's vision. Funnily enough I saw it with Leslie Grantham, who's in Lava, and if he doesn't like a film he just starts talking. With about 20 minutes to go Leslie was going, 'Oh dear, oh fucking dear. Go on, hurry up and fucking drown.'"

The downside to this strategy is that if the film fails at the box office then the director stands to lose far more than just their reputation. It was just such a scenario that confronted Francis Ford Coppola during the production of Apocalypse Now - a film whose spiralling budget United Artists only agreed to finance as long as he put up pretty much everything he owned as collateral. While the film would show a profit, the pressures inherent in taking this risk are more than apparent in Apocalypse's accompanying documentary Hearts Of Darkness.

"Yeah, that rant he has when he says it's all a disaster is one of the most scary bits of film I've ever seen," says Truter. "It's like a horror film to me. I just hope I'm never in that situation." But what, then, is a film-maker like Dwight Yoakam supposed to do if he simply runs out of money?

"Well, it obviously helps if you've got a house worth $825,000," Truter laughs. "But I would suggest that trying to pay for it yourself is a particularly stupid thing to do. If you have a proven track record, like Steven Spielberg, I'd say fair enough. But your first feature... Well, I'd say good luck. And, you know, good on Dwight for having that kind of blind faith. I don't mean to do him down. But after the first day of shooting, blind faith means nothing."

webTitle: Letters: Tax breaks for married mothers

fields.headline: Mother of all tax breaks
fields.trailText: Your headline "Tories' £1bn for married mothers" is misleading (October 4). It should have read Tories' £1bn for married fathers.
fields.body:
Your headline "Tories' £1bn for married mothers" is misleading (October 4). It should have read Tories' £1bn for married fathers.

There is no guarantee that by handing over their tax allowances to their husbands, married mothers will ever see a penny. If the real aim of Willetts & Co were to give married mothers some money, they would either introduce a "marriage premium" in child benefit or allow parents to pay each other a wage for childcare on the same basis as they pay their childminders (attracting the working families tax credit childcare premium, but not tax deductible by the earner). This would enable wives in low-to-middle income families to make use of their tax allowances and to make pension contributions. They would also have the word "job" on their CVs instead of merely "years off work being worthless and useless" - which is still often employers'view of career breaks for childrearing.

Transferable tax allowances have the following adverse effects: (a) help the better-off without helping the poor (no extra money for married couples below the tax threshold); (b) benefit the richest most (40p in the pound to those on the higher rate, but only 22p in the pound to those on the standard rate, and if the Tories plan to restrict this to the standard rate, middle England should be told); (c) encourage married mothers to be financially dependent on their husbands; (d) give husbands an incentive to discourage their wives from earning (because their own income will be lower) and to encourage the work/family responsibility split between spouses (instead of job sharing).

Perhaps we should be grateful that the Tories have at last noticed that it is children (particularly small children) who cost, not marriage itself. Hoorah that they have dropped the idea of reintroducing the married couples' tax allowance. A few more steps along that road and Willetts (or Portillo) may develop a sensible policy.
Mary Campbell
London
mcampbell@london.edu

 I trust that the Tories are also proposing to allow the husband's tax allowance to be transferred to his wife should he be the one to stay at home.
Mike Brown
Newcastle upon Tyne
family@brownz.fsnet.co.uk

 So Tim Baker, commercial director of Norwich Union Healthcare, says that tax relief on private healthcare for average earners would help him to expand his business (Women doctors 'less efficient', October 4).

My wife and I, both 75, have been forced out of Norwich Union Healthcare by the expedient of their having trebled the premium. I wrote to the board querying the ethics of their scrapheap policy and my letter was passed down the ladder to a lady who wrote saying that they were sorry to lose us but that's how it is . . . private health insurance is very competitive and if at 75 you can't afford their demand . . . goodbye! I would be happy to pay a little more tax for a super efficient National Health Service that offers the security and peace of mind of health care from cradle to grave.
Shaw Taylor
Totland Bay, Isle of Wight
ShawTaylor@compuserve.com

From where is Senor Portillo going to get the staff for his expanded private health sector? China? Spain? The NHS of course! Watch waiting lists grow: more people going private; NHS staff being poached; waiting lists grow ... Hey presto! A two-tier, largely private health sector.
John Hall
Shipley, W Yorkshire

 I now realise why Mr Portillo addressed the conference without notes. He had absolutely nothing to say.
Stephen Cartmell
Tring, Herts

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: National Poetry Day: The Windrose | Costing The Earth
fields.body:
From 10am Radio 4 marks National Poetry Day with 14 sonnets from writers nominated by Poet Laureate, Andrew Motion (pictured). The poems, inserted between programmes and read by the authors, use a compass bearing as the starting point of their 14 lines. The whole sequence has been entitled Windrose (the old name for a compass face). Andrew Motion reflects on the results in National Poetry Day: The Windrose (3.45pm, Radio 4) and reads his own contribution, South-East.

A recent report for the Royal Astronomical Society predicted that within 25 years no one in Italy would be able to see the Milky Way. The cause, which already affects about three-quarters of the United States, is light pollution. From a small aircraft circling over Britain, Alex Kirby investigates the problem for Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4). Apparently the light of one street lamp can affect an astronomer's view of the night sky from 120 miles away.

Andrew Motion reflects on the results in National Poetry Day: The Windrose (3.45pm, Radio 4) and reads his own contribution, South-East. A recent report for the Royal Astronomical Society predicted that within 25 years no one in Italy would be able to see the Milky Way. The cause, which already affects about three-quarters of the United States, is light pollution. From a small aircraft circling over Britain, Alex Kirby investigates the problem for Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4). Apparently the light of one street lamp can affect an astronomer's view of the night sky from 120 miles away.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
A few days ago there was a warm southerly wind, dragging lower latitudes through the hills at a hell of a lick. When the rain came, it fled the already sodden ground and dived down brooks to fatten the river Severn, threatening floods. When it finally stopped, a lone buzzard took to the topmost beech tree in the hanging woods. It perched there and called a strange plaintive, gull-like phrase: three or four sharp, sky- slicing notes, over and over.

The south is also exerting a powerful force over other birds. By late afternoon the sky is full of housemartins: a clan gathering, swooping through their communal dance. The martins urge stragglers to hurry up and join in. After a late start, rebuilding the nest and raising a pair of chicks, the martins who share our house are finally ready. One day the chicks are peeping out of their teapot home under the eaves; the next they're flying with their hundred-strong clan above the woods and fields. The dance is to free the lodestones in their heads from the force which draws them to this place and holds them here all summer. Their minds spin to align with the mysterious longitude of their autumn migration road south. One day soon the sky will be empty.

Up in the morning fields an equally amazing collective journey has been written out. Over the foggy, freshly ploughed soil is what looks like frost. But it's gossamer: millions of long, inter-threaded strands, spun by spiders. Each length is an incredible voyage drawn across the earth, holding pearls of dew, waving and shimmering in the wind. It's a trap, devised and built by millions of spiders: a trap laid for the spirit of autumn.
