fields.headline: Galaxy hitcher
fields.standfirst: Douglas Adams is the author of the Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy
fields.trailText: Douglas Adams is the author of the Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy
fields.body:
What computers have you owned? When the world was ruled by dinosaurs, I had a word processor called a Nexus; now I have a house full of Macintoshes.

Have any IT specialists influenced your writing? Yes, Alan Kay, who invented object-oriented programming and the laptop. He also coined the term "personal computer".

How do you see our lives being affected by IT today? Technology is finally catching up to our needs. The net allows us to talk directly to each other in a way we haven't done since humanity lived in small groups. We're very lucky that it's evolved as an organic entity, a bottom-up design rather than being hierarchically controlled from above - that's part of its extraordinary power. I'm resolutely optimistic because we tend to get the future we imagine.

What are you hoping to achieve on your website www.h2g2.com? A powerful mode is created when our experiences and information are pooled together. So the site is a collection point containing as much communal information as possible, a real-time guide that encourages people to put in and take out information wherever they are.

What are your current projects? Another book and a novella, to be published on the web. Part of the reason I'm in California is to work on a movie version of The Guide, with my director, Jay Roach.

How is digital technology affecting your work? Digital animation makes creating special effects for films like The Guide possible. There's a specific proposal in front of me to make a digital video. It's particularly beguiling after making a digital radio series with Mark Rickards of the BBC which was edited on a computer_ he did part of the editing on the plane trip home!

Is there anything you hate on the web? Racist sites. I saw a particularly obnoxious site about Jews in Hollywood. But I also think people are too worried about pornography on the web. Children have to be protected, but it's better out in the open where unlimited scrutiny can function like sunlight on ice, softening its impact, rendering it unimportant. If you come across it, you just think, "what sad people".

Have you ever been attacked by a virus? Just once! I wrote a program to handle the complex layout and cross-referencing for The Meaning Of Liff, which I co-wrote with John Lloyd. A Trojan slipped in and completely fried my hard disk.

If you take the long view of our future, what do you see? We need to make a concerted effort as a species to get into space travel. Our future lies on other planets, especially as we will lose the moon in less than a billion years, making the earth uninhabitable.

 Douglas Adams' personal view of digital technology, The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Future, will be broadcast on Radio 4 at 11am, October 11, 18 and 25.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Don't ask Jack
Jack Schofield shows his usual Microsoft bias. Getting Microsoft Office might be the best solution to Anne-Marie's problem (Ask Jack September 28), if the documents she's being sent are all Microsoft Word or Microsoft Excel documents. But it's rather an expensive solution both in money and time.

I recommend the excellent MacLink Plus set of translators from Dataviz, which can convert from lots of different file formats into AppleWorks format, and vice-versa. They also integrate very nicely into AppleWorks, appearing as options on the pop-up menus in the Open and Save File dialogs. The latest version, 12.0, is available for under £90, including VAT.
Paul Durrant
paul@durrant.co.uk

Mr Schofield is either unaware of MacLink Plus, in which case he shouldn't really be offering advice to Mac users, or he is deliberately ignoring it to push a Microsoft product.

Mr Schofield, please either provide a less blinkered view of the Mac market or rename Online as The Microsoft Report. This is getting silly.
Jason Staines
jstaines@postmaster.co.uk

Missed out
I'm staggered that the Sinclair Spectrum didn't make the PC timeline: after all, it defined computing for British kids in the 80s, while Apple and DOS boxes remained impossibly expensive imports. (Didn't any of your writers remember Sinclair Research Ltd?) No sign of Amstrad, either, though its PCWs were the first to bring word processing to many British homes. Nick Sweeney
nick@nonspace.org

Welcome read
Douglas Rushkoff's take on net censorship (Second Sight September 28) got much right and was a very welcome contribution on a mostly ignored subject.

He could have drawn out the thread of the implications of napster a bit more. There's been a "consumer" (read "citizen") revolt against raw capitalism, an implication strangely absent from much of the coverage in the net press.

Neither does he directly mention "censorware" like NetNanny and others, and the implications of unrestrained, privatised, largely American censors deciding what is accessible to kids and others forced to use filtered net access (including workers in offices denied access to trade union sites).

The one point that had me flummoxed was his claim that Dreamweaver and Photoshop "make artists indirectly censor themselves". Please explain.
Paul Canning
cann03ing@yahoo.com

New look Mac
Craig McGill's review of OS X (Online, September 28) could be boiled down to one sentence: "It's different, so I don't like it".

He may genuinely prefer the current Mac OS, but perhaps he has forgotten that with a few weeks or even days of unbiased use, the quirks and differences of OS X could become equally familiar.

The loss of familiar landmarks like the Apple menu, for instance, may be disorientating at first but OS X includes new and powerful ways of navigating through the system.

A modern Mac OS with pre-emptive multitasking and protected memory is years overdue. Let's hope most Mac users take a more positive attitude than Mr McGill.
Cameron Paterson
cameronp@lineone.net

As the kind of Mac user who uses her Mac the way she uses her car - if it goes I'm happy and don't even want to think about why - I welcomed Craig McGill's piece on Mac's OS X.

It was a model of clarity in the way it spelled out the new operating system's downside. It was positively user-friendly - rather like the Macs I know and love, come to think of it.

What a pity Apple seems to be heading off into unfamiliar territory. I guess I'll just have to look after my herd of aging dinosaurs (from Classic to iMac OS 9) and hope they don't all die on me.
Christine Findlay
christine@maura.demon.co.uk

Censorship
John Carr's response to my article about blocking software (Second Sight, September 21) might have been more informative to readers had he noted that he and his wife, Labour Peer Baroness Thornton, were active in promoting the Regulation of Investigatory Powers bill and that Carr has long advocated the imposition of blocking software in public libraries as well as schools.

I also found it interesting that he referred to my alleged desire to look at pornography myself, since I have told him before that I do not use pornography recreationally and have managed to avoid seeing it on the internet by the no-doubt complicated hi-tech trick of not clicking on it.

Although Mr Carr claims to plead for tolerance and freedom of choice, he apparently wishes that only his own choice be observed in public and educational facilities.

Some of us would choose otherwise, preferring not to impose repression on young people when we know that it correlates so highly with sex crime.

Mr Carr may wish to avoid pornography, but I find this less compelling than my desire to avoid promoting rape.

He also ignored the substance of my article, which pointed out that blocking software does not simply block pornography, but also blocks a great deal of material that is not pornographic or even related to problematic subjects.

Most importantly, the software may block words like "Playboy", "pornography" and "breasts", but cannot be relied upon to do what it claims to do, which is block most erotic images. Why should the government waste money on an obstructive, intrusive policy that does not work?

Unfortunately, Mr Carr's letter is typical of the calibre of debate we have come to expect from the proponents of censorship and, alas, from government, who ignore the facts and instead repeat indefinitely things that are not true and do more harm than good.
Avedon Carol
avedon@cix.compulink.co.uk

fields.headline: The best nasal scene
fields.standfirst: Shaft
fields.trailText: Shaft
fields.body:
Harlem. Outside the Lenox Lounge, a young man's body lies on the sidewalk after being brutally attacked. His well-bred assailant, Walter Wade Jr (Christian Bale) watches the medics attempt to save his victim while a police officer reads him his rights.

"Get him on board!" one of the medics screams.

"He's starting to seize."

The man begins to have convulsions.

Arresting officer John Shaft (Samuel L Jackson) watches the scene unfold, horror in his eyes. As he passes Wade, the latter turns to Shaft, a sneer on his face.

"Homeboy's got rhythm, huh?"

Shaft meets Wade's gaze, then throws a punch. Wade staggers backwards, clutching his nose.

"Was it something I said?"

A gaggle of photographers start taking pictures, their flashbulbs lighting up the area. Wade calls out to the various members of the press.

"I think my nose is broken."

He gestures at Shaft.

"He broke my nose!"

Meanwhile, the medics continue their efforts to save the victim.

"Clear an airway..."

"We're losing him!"

Shaft's senior officer approaches him, scowling.

"Well, I've been waiting for this all year. You are gone."

Shaft turns, oozing contempt.

"Gone? For what? For that ?"

He moves to walk away, then spins back and floors the senior officer.

See also: Annie Hall, Chinatown, Pinocchio, The Invisible Man, A Hard Day's Night

Don't see also: Cyrano De Bergerac

Pointless trivia: Samuel L Jackson completed rehab for drug dependency two weeks before playing a crack addict in Spike Lee's Jungle Fever (1991).

webTitle: Ominous start to England's make-or-break tour

fields.headline: Ominous start to a tour of make or break
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver After injuries to Nick Knight and Ashley Giles, it is difficult to see the immediate future of English cricket as anything other than one long accident waiting to happen.
fields.body:
After all that has happened over the past three weeks it feels a little unfashionable to adopt the role of a wailing soothsayer but it is difficult to see the immediate future of English cricket as anything other than one long accident waiting to happen.

It has already started, with injuries to the one-day specialists Nick Knight and Ashley Giles in the past week. And England's exceptionally arduous winter has not even begun yet. It gets under way today, when they play Bangladesh in their opening match in the ICC Knockout Trophy in Kenya.

Who needs a long-faced soothsayer when there is Giles. This likeable but most unfortunate cricketer toured South Africa and Zimbabwe last winter without playing in a single match. When the management thought about giving him a run out in the final fixture, a one-day affair against Zimbabwe in Harare, torrential rain washed out the game.

He has been picked in the squad for 34 one-day internationals and played in five. When his poor fortune was explained to him in the lobby of his Harare hotel earlier this year he shrugged, rather heroically, and observed that on a match-appearance basis he must be better paid than David Beckham. At the end of the press conference he sat on an expensive glass table which immediately burst into a million pieces.

If England win today they will play South Africa in the quarter-finals next week and, if they win that, Australia in the semi-finals on Friday 13th. South Africa and Australia are the best one-day sides in the business.

At the end of the month they will play three one-day games in Pakistan. Then it gets really tough. Next month they will embark on a three-Test series in Pakistan.

England have won a single Test match in Pakistan, in 1961, and have not even bothered to try since 1987, the year of the infamous Mike Gatting-Shakoor Rana spat. If England draw the series they will be delighted.

At least they will be able to enjoy comfortable conditions. That was hardly the case in 1983-84. In Faisalabad there were ants and cockroaches in every room and in mine a rat so big I thought it was a cat at first; the light was not too good because there was no window.

After breakfast, declined because of the dead flies in the organge juice, I asked for a room with a view. "I wouldn't bother," said a colleague. "Have a look at mine." Through his window we could see fornicating buffaloes amid the dusty beggars.

This time the players can expect luxuriously appointed hotels. But the pitches, low and skiddy for the pacemen and turning for Saqlain Mushtaq, will be just as difficult for an England middle order that can still be as brittle as Melba toast.

Then, after coming home for Christmas, they are off to Sri Lanka. Man for man, England would back themselves to beat Sri Lanka. The only trouble is that Muttiah Muralitharan, this hill country Tamil and son of a biscuit maker, is so good that England's batsmen are likely to topple faster than Olympian weightlifters.

When these countries last played a Test match, at the Oval in 1988, it was astonishing stuff. England batted first and scored a fireproof-looking 445. Sri Lanka replied with a very fast 591 and then bowled England out for 181 before winning by 10 wickets; Muralitharan took 16 wickets and looked unplayable at times.

If that was tough it was nothing compared with what England can expect in Sri Lanka. Here the heat and humidity will be worse, far worse, than anything they might have experienced in Trinidad and Brisbane. And the pitches, dusty bunsens, will make Muralitharan a bigger handful than ever.

If England survive this little lot they can look forward to Australia at home next summer. A few years ago Australia were the best side in the world; then they got better.

After a series of nebbish captains and coaches England have made impressive progress under Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher. But if they still look good a year from now they deserve to be placed right up there with Steve Redgrave and Denise Lewis.

webTitle: Anger at slur on women doctors

fields.headline: Anger at slur on women doctors
fields.standfirst: Hague's health spokesman accused of living in the past after claiming that productivity rate is lower than for men
fields.trailText: Tory health spokesman Phillip Hammond was accused of being out of touch for suggesting that women doctors were less productive than their male counterparts during a career in the NHS.
fields.byline: Sarah Boseley, health correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Tory health spokesman Phillip Hammond was accused yesterday of being out of touch for suggesting that women doctors were less productive than their male counterparts during a career in the NHS.

Women doctors expressed disbelief at Mr Hammond's statement, at a private meeting during the Tory party conference in Bournemouth, that the NHS would get about 20% less work out of a female doctor than a man over a lifetime. Men, they pointed out, are increasingly looking to more flexible working hours, either to spend more time with their families or to pursue other interests.

The government is forging ahead with changes to working conditions within the NHS that are likely to allow more women doctors and nurses - who are in short supply - to work part-time. In Harrogate yesterday, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, announced a new focus on family-friendly policies.

Mr Milburn dismissed Mr Hammond's remarks. "The Conservatives are firmly stuck in the past," he said. "The NHS is the biggest employer in the country. Now it's got to be the best employer in the country. More flexible ways of working, family-friendly employment policies and the recognition that the way to get the best from people is to fit into the way their lives are lived today."

But Mr Hammond was unrepentant, insisting that the NHS would need still more doctors if more than half of them - reflecting the medical school intake - are to be women. "Over a working career they do not deliver the same number of hours as a male doctor because of taking time out for their family.

"When we hear we are going to have 8,000 extra doctors, if 70% of them are female then we are only really delivering an extra 7,000 careers over a working lifetime."

Mr Hammond claimed his figures came from the Royal College of Physicians. Yesterday Sir George Alberti, its president, cited a study in the British Medical Journal. "It shows that roughly half the women work half time at some point in their careers, so on average for every woman who qualifies in medicine, you get 75% of a whole time equivalent over a lifetime. For men, the rate is 90-95% because some retire early."

This is no reflection on the quality of those women doctors, he said, but the increasing trend among men and women to want to work fewer hours must be taken into account when planning manpower.

The 30% increase in consultants over the next four years in the national plan was the most that was possible at the moment given the numbers now in training. But to accommodate all of those who would want to work part time, the numbers would have to increase again.

The NHS Confederation, representing the trusts employing doctors, said maternity leave and part-time working by women doctors were not a problem over the period of a career in the NHS.

Molly McBride, of the Medical Women's Federation, said younger male doctors were increasingly feeling that they did not want to make the body and soul commitment to the health service that their forebears had done. A cohort study by the British Medical Association, looking at the attitudes of young doctors five years after graduation, found that 61% of women but also 15% of men intended to work part-time at some stage.

"They are saying there is more to life," said Dr McBride. Out of that cohort, she said, 20% had already been absent from the NHS for all or part of the preceding 12 months. The reasons included having children, but also working overseas.

The majority of medical graduates are now women. If they are not allowed to work less than full-time, then they would drop out when they had children, she said. "Patients say they want women doctors. They bring unique insight into women's issues. They work well in a team ... Women don't burn out because they have outside interests."

The Royal College of Surgeons has been campaigning to increase the number of women going into surgery in recognition of the fact that among them will be some of the best and brightest new doctors.

"In order to choose our consultants from the optimal group, we need to make opportunities in surgery very much more attractive and possible for women," said Su-Anna Boddy, the college's flexible training adviser and a consultant paediatric surgeon. It is traditionally a strongly male-dominated field. Only 239 out of 4,431 consultant posts are held by women.

Isobel Allen, professor of health and social policy at the Policy Studies Institute, said other factors besides women's maternity leave and part-time working would have to be considered to give an accurate picture of the strength of the workforce. "There is an increasing tendency to early retirement. We have got an ageing GP workforce. They and consultants talk of retiring early or as soon as possible"

webTitle: West Indies taken apart by Sri Lanka

fields.headline: West Indies taken apart by Sri Lanka
fields.standfirst:
Sri Lanka 287-6
West Indies 179
Sri Lanka won by 108 runs
fields.trailText: West Indies crashed out of the tournament after they managed only 179 in reply to Sri Lanka's 287 in the second match in Nairobi yesterday.
fields.body:
West Indies crashed to a 108-run defeat by Sri Lanka in the second match of the ICC Knockout Trophy in Nairobi yesterday. India beat Kenya in the first on Tuesday.

Sri Lanka had scored 287 for six in their 50 overs, with Avishka Gunawardene hitting 19 fours in his century, but West Indies were bowled out for 179. Sri Lanka now play Pakistan on Sunday.

Brian Lara made five before being caught off Nuwan Zoysa, who took three for 34 off seven overs to help bowl out West Indies in 46.4 overs.

After Sri Lanka lost their captain Sanath Jayasuriya and Marvan Atapattu for 10 runs, Gunawardene combined with Mahela Jayawardene for a third-wicket partnership of 160 that rescued the innings.

The partnership was broken by the 20-year-old Antiguan paceman Kerry Jeremy, who had Jayawardene caught behind for 72.

Gunawardene finally succumbed to Nixon McLean, who bowled him in the 45th over. His 132 came off 146 balls and tied up the man-of-the-match award .

The West Indies bowlers Mervyn Dillon and McLean each ended up with two wickets.

West Indies did not help themselves when their captain and opener Sherwin Campbell was run out for 20. They fell to 41 for four before Laurie Williams top-scored with 41.

fields.bodyText: West Indies crashed to a 108-run defeat by Sri Lanka in the second match of the ICC Knockout Trophy in Nairobi yesterday. India beat Kenya in the first on Tuesday. Sri Lanka had scored 287 for six in their 50 overs, with Avishka Gunawardene hitting 19 fours in his century, but West Indies were bowled out for 179. Sri Lanka now play Pakistan on Sunday. Brian Lara made five before being caught off Nuwan Zoysa, who took three for 34 off seven overs to help bowl out West Indies in 46.4 overs. After Sri Lanka lost their captain Sanath Jayasuriya and Marvan Atapattu for 10 runs, Gunawardene combined with Mahela Jayawardene for a third-wicket partnership of 160 that rescued the innings. The partnership was broken by the 20-year-old Antiguan paceman Kerry Jeremy, who had Jayawardene caught behind for 72. Gunawardene finally succumbed to Nixon McLean, who bowled him in the 45th over. His 132 came off 146 balls and tied up the man-of-the-match award . The West Indies bowlers Mervyn Dillon and McLean each ended up with two wickets. West Indies did not help themselves when their captain and opener Sherwin Campbell was run out for 20. They fell to 41 for four before Laurie Williams top-scored with 41.
